   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading">Italy</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" lang="en" dir="ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in Southern Europe
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Italy_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Italy (disambiguation)">Italy (disambiguation)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italia_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Italia (disambiguation)">Italia (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div>

        <tr>
         <td colspan="2" class="infobox-full-data">
          <div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
           <ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em;"> 
            <li value="1"><span style="font-size:100%;"><a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a> is co-official in <a href="/wiki/South_Tyrol" title="South Tyrol">South Tyrol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Friuli_Venezia_Giulia" title="Friuli Venezia Giulia">Friuli Venezia Giulia</a>; <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> is co-official in the <a href="/wiki/Aosta_Valley" title="Aosta Valley">Aosta Valley</a>; <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">Slovene</a> is co-official in the <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Trieste" title="Province of Trieste">province of Trieste</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Gorizia" title="Province of Gorizia">province of Gorizia</a>, and Friuli Venezia Giulia; <a href="/wiki/Ladin_language" title="Ladin language">Ladin</a> is co-official in South Tyrol, in <a href="/wiki/Trentino" title="Trentino">Trentino</a> and in other northern areas; <a href="/wiki/Friulian_language" title="Friulian language">Friulian</a> is co-official in Friuli Venezia Giulia; <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">Sardinian</a> is co-official in <a href="/wiki/Sardinia" title="Sardinia">Sardinia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup></span></li>
            <li value="2"><span style="font-size:100%;">Before 2002, the <a href="/wiki/Italian_lira" title="Italian lira">Italian lira</a>. The euro is accepted in <a href="/wiki/Campione_d%27Italia" title="Campione d'Italia">Campione d'Italia</a> but its official currency is the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_franc" title="Swiss franc">Swiss franc</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup></span></li>
            <li value="3"><span style="font-size:100%;">To call <a href="/wiki/Campione_d%27Italia" title="Campione d'Italia">Campione d'Italia</a>, it is necessary to use the Swiss code <a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Switzerland" title="Telephone numbers in Switzerland">+41</a>.</span></li>
            <li value="4"><span style="font-size:100%;">The <a href="/wiki/.eu" title=".eu">.eu</a> domain is also used, as it is shared with other <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> member states.</span></li> 
           </ol>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Italy</b> (<a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>: <i lang="it">Italia</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Italian" title="Help:IPA/Italian">[iˈtaːlja]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:It-Italia.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1d/It-Italia.ogg" class="internal" title="It-Italia.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>Italian Republic</b> (Italian: <i lang="it">Repubblica Italiana</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Italian" title="Help:IPA/Italian">[reˈpubːlika itaˈljaːna]</a></span>),<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> is a country consisting of a <a href="/wiki/Northern_Italy" title="Northern Italy">continental part</a>, delimited by the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">peninsula</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Italy" title="List of islands of Italy">several islands</a> surrounding it. Italy is located in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">Southern Europe</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-m49_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-m49-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_–_Italy_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_–_Italy-18">[18]</a></sup> and is also considered part of <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DGACM_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DGACM-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> with <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a> as its capital, the country covers a total area of 301,340&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (116,350&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and shares <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_by_land_borders" title="List of countries and territories by land borders">land borders</a> with France, Switzerland, Austria, Slovenia, and the <a href="/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave" title="Enclave and exclave">enclaved</a> microstates of <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a> and <a href="/wiki/San_Marino" title="San Marino">San Marino</a>. Italy has a territorial <a href="/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave" title="Enclave and exclave">enclave</a> in Switzerland (<a href="/wiki/Campione_d%27Italia" title="Campione d'Italia">Campione</a>) and a maritime exclave in Tunisian waters (<a href="/wiki/Lampedusa_e_Linosa" title="Lampedusa e Linosa">Lampedusa</a>). With around 60 million inhabitants, Italy is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_Union_member_states_by_population" title="List of European Union member states by population">third-most populous member state of the European Union</a>. </p>
      <p>Due to its central geographic location in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">Southern Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">the Mediterranean</a>, Italy has historically been home to myriad peoples and cultures. In addition to the <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_peoples_of_Italy" title="List of ancient peoples of Italy">various ancient peoples</a> dispersed throughout what is now modern-day Italy, the most predominant being the <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-Europeans" title="Proto-Indo-Europeans">Indo-European</a> <a href="/wiki/Italic_peoples" title="Italic peoples">Italic peoples</a> who gave the peninsula its name, beginning from the <a href="/wiki/Classical_antiquity" title="Classical antiquity">classical</a> era, <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">Phoenicians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Carthage" title="Ancient Carthage">Carthaginians</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Colony" title="Colony">colonies</a> mostly in <a href="/wiki/Insular_Italy" title="Insular Italy">insular Italy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-WaldmanMason2006_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WaldmanMason2006-21">[21]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greeks</a> established settlements in the so-called <i><a href="/wiki/Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia">Magna Graecia</a></i> of <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">Southern Italy</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Etruscan_civilization" title="Etruscan civilization">Etruscans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a> inhabited <a href="/wiki/Central_Italy" title="Central Italy">central</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Italy" title="Northern Italy">northern</a> Italy respectively. An Italic tribe known as the <a href="/wiki/Latins_(Italic_tribe)" title="Latins (Italic tribe)">Latins</a> formed the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Kingdom" title="Roman Kingdom">Roman Kingdom</a> in the 8th century BC, which eventually became a <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">republic</a> with a government of the <a href="/wiki/SPQR" title="SPQR">Senate and the People</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> initially <a href="/wiki/Roman_expansion_in_Italy" title="Roman expansion in Italy">conquered</a> and <a href="/wiki/Romanization_(cultural)" title="Romanization (cultural)">assimilated</a> its neighbours on the Italian peninsula, eventually <a href="/wiki/Roman_republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman republic">expanding and conquering</a> parts of <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>. By the first century BC, the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> emerged as the dominant power in the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">Mediterranean Basin</a> and became a <a href="/wiki/Legacy_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Legacy of the Roman Empire">leading cultural, political and religious</a> <a href="/wiki/Caput_Mundi" title="Caput Mundi">centre</a>, inaugurating the <a href="/wiki/Pax_Romana" title="Pax Romana">Pax Romana</a>, a period of more than 200 years during which Italy's <a href="/wiki/Roman_law" title="Roman law">law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman technology">technology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_economy" title="Roman economy">economy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_art" title="Roman art">art</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Latin_literature" title="Latin literature">literature</a> developed.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Italy remained the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Italy" title="Roman Italy">homeland of the Romans</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Metropole" title="Metropole">metropole</a> of the empire, whose <a href="/wiki/Legacy_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Legacy of the Roman Empire">legacy</a> can also be observed in the global distribution of culture, governments, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Latin_script" title="Latin script">Latin script</a>. </p>
      <p>During the <a href="/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages" title="Early Middle Ages">Early Middle Ages</a>, Italy endured the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">fall of the Western Roman Empire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">barbarian invasions</a>, but by the 11th century numerous rival <a href="/wiki/Italian_city-states" title="Italian city-states">city-states</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maritime_republics" title="Maritime republics">maritime republics</a>, mainly in the northern and central regions of Italy, rose to great prosperity through trade, commerce and banking, laying the groundwork for modern <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-24">[24]</a></sup> These mostly independent statelets served as Europe's main trading hubs with Asia and the Near East, often enjoying a greater degree of <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a> than the larger <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudal</a> monarchies that were consolidating throughout Europe; however, part of central Italy was under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Theocracy" title="Theocracy">theocratic</a> <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">Southern Italy</a> remained largely feudal until the 19th century, partially as a result of a succession of <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Islam_in_southern_Italy" title="History of Islam in southern Italy">Arab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_southern_Italy" title="Norman conquest of southern Italy">Norman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capetian_House_of_Anjou" title="Capetian House of Anjou">Angevin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Aragon" title="Crown of Aragon">Aragonese</a> and other foreign conquests of the region.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo-25">[25]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> began in Italy and spread to the rest of Europe, bringing a renewed interest in <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_humanism" title="Renaissance humanism">humanism</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_science_in_the_Renaissance" title="History of science in the Renaissance">science</a>, <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">exploration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_art" title="Renaissance art">art</a>. Italian culture flourished, producing famous scholars, artists and <a href="/wiki/Polymath" title="Polymath">polymaths</a>. During the Middle Ages, Italian explorers discovered new routes to the <a href="/wiki/Far_East" title="Far East">Far East</a> and the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a>, helping to usher in the European <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>. Nevertheless, Italy's commercial and political power significantly waned with the opening of trade routes that bypassed the Mediterranean.<sup id="cite_ref-bouchard_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bouchard-26">[26]</a></sup> Centuries of foreign meddling and conquest and the rivalry and infighting between the Italian city-states, such as the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Wars" title="Italian Wars">Italian Wars</a> of the 15th and 16th centuries, left Italy politically fragmented, and it was further conquered and divided among multiple foreign European powers over the centuries. </p>
      <p>By the mid-19th century, rising <a href="/wiki/Italian_nationalism" title="Italian nationalism">Italian nationalism</a> and calls for independence from foreign control led to a period of revolutionary political upheaval. After centuries of foreign domination and political division, <a href="/wiki/Italian_unification" title="Italian unification">Italy was almost entirely unified</a> in 1861, establishing the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> From the late 19th century to the early 20th century, Italy rapidly industrialised, mainly in the north, and acquired a <a href="/wiki/Italian_Empire" title="Italian Empire">colonial empire</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-allempires.com_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allempires.com-28">[28]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">the south</a> remained largely impoverished and <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Italy#North–South_divide" title="Economy of Italy">excluded from industrialisation</a>, fuelling a large and influential <a href="/wiki/Italian_diaspora" title="Italian diaspora">diaspora</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> Despite being one of the <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_(World_War_I)" title="Big Four (World War I)">four main allied powers in World War I</a>, Italy entered a period of economic crisis and social turmoil, leading to the rise of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Fascism" title="Italian Fascism">Italian fascist</a> dictatorship in 1922. Participation in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis</a> side ended in military defeat, economic destruction and the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Civil_War" title="Italian Civil War">Italian Civil War</a>. Following the liberation of Italy and the rise of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Resistance" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Resistance">Italian Resistance</a>, the country abolished their <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Italy" title="Monarchy of Italy">monarchy</a>, established a democratic Republic, enjoyed a prolonged <a href="/wiki/Italian_economic_miracle" title="Italian economic miracle">economic boom</a>, and became a highly <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-qq_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-qq-30">[30]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Today, Italy is considered to be one of the world's most culturally and economically advanced countries,<sup id="cite_ref-qq_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-qq-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cia_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wb_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wb-32">[32]</a></sup> with the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">eighth-largest economy</a> by nominal GDP (third in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>), sixth-largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_wealth" title="List of countries by total wealth">national wealth</a> and third-largest central bank <a href="/wiki/Gold_reserve" title="Gold reserve">gold reserve</a>. It ranks very highly in <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a>, quality of life,<sup id="cite_ref-economist.com_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist.com-33">[33]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Italy" title="Healthcare in Italy">healthcare</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> and education. The country plays a prominent role in regional and global economic, military, cultural and diplomatic affairs; it is both a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Canada_Among_Nations_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Canada_Among_Nations-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Milena_Sterio_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Milena_Sterio-38">[38]</a></sup> and is ranked the world's <a href="/wiki/Military#Capability_development" title="Military">eighth most-powerful military</a>. Italy is a <a href="/wiki/Inner_Six" title="Inner Six">founding</a> and <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_(Western_Europe)" title="Big Four (Western Europe)">leading</a> member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and a member of numerous international institutions, including the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven" title="Group of Seven">Group of Seven</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Union_for_the_Mediterranean" title="Union for the Mediterranean">Union for the Mediterranean</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uniting_for_Consensus" title="Uniting for Consensus">Uniting for Consensus</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a> and <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Italy#International_institutions" title="Foreign relations of Italy">many more</a>. The source of <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of Italian inventions and discoveries">many inventions and discoveries</a>, the country has long been a global centre of <a href="/wiki/Italian_art" title="Italian art">art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Italy" title="Music of Italy">music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_literature" title="Italian literature">literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_philosophy" title="Italian philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Italy" title="Science and technology in Italy">science and technology</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Italian_fashion" title="Italian fashion">fashion</a>, and has greatly influenced and contributed to diverse fields including <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Italy" title="Cinema of Italy">cinema</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">cuisine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Italy" title="Sport in Italy">sports</a>, jurisprudence, banking and business.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> As a reflection of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Italy" title="Culture of Italy">its cultural wealth</a>, Italy has the world's <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_by_country#Countries_with_major_concentrations_of_World_Heritage_Sites" title="World Heritage Sites by country">largest number</a> of <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Italy" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Italy">World Heritage Sites</a> alongside China, and is the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings" title="World Tourism rankings">fifth-most visited country</a>. </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style>

          <ul>

         <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-38"><a href="#Culture"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Culture</span></a> 
          <ul> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-39"><a href="#Architecture"><span class="tocnumber">7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Architecture</span></a></li> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-40"><a href="#Visual_art"><span class="tocnumber">7.2</span> <span class="toctext">Visual art</span></a></li> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-41"><a href="#Literature"><span class="tocnumber">7.3</span> <span class="toctext">Literature</span></a></li> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-42"><a href="#Philosophy"><span class="tocnumber">7.4</span> <span class="toctext">Philosophy</span></a></li> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-43"><a href="#Theatre"><span class="tocnumber">7.5</span> <span class="toctext">Theatre</span></a></li> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-44"><a href="#Music"><span class="tocnumber">7.6</span> <span class="toctext">Music</span></a></li> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-45"><a href="#Cinema"><span class="tocnumber">7.7</span> <span class="toctext">Cinema</span></a></li> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-46"><a href="#Sport"><span class="tocnumber">7.8</span> <span class="toctext">Sport</span></a></li> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-47"><a href="#Fashion_and_design"><span class="tocnumber">7.9</span> <span class="toctext">Fashion and design</span></a></li> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-48"><a href="#Cuisine"><span class="tocnumber">7.10</span> <span class="toctext">Cuisine</span></a></li> 
           <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-49"><a href="#Public_holidays_and_festivals"><span class="tocnumber">7.11</span> <span class="toctext">Public holidays and festivals</span></a></li> 
          </ul> </li> 
         <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-50"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li> 
         <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-51"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li> 
         <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-52"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> 
         <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-53"><a href="#Bibliography"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">Bibliography</span></a></li> 
         <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-54"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li> 
        </ul> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span></h2> 
      <p><span class="anchor" id="Etymology"></span> </p> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Italy" title="Name of Italy">Name of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:RomanItaly.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/RomanItaly.png/220px-RomanItaly.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="271" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/RomanItaly.png/330px-RomanItaly.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/RomanItaly.png/440px-RomanItaly.png 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="887"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:RomanItaly.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Expansion of the territory known as <a href="/wiki/Italy_(Roman_Empire)" class="mw-redirect" title="Italy (Roman Empire)">Italy</a> from the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> until <a href="/wiki/Diocletian" title="Diocletian">Diocletian</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Hypotheses for the etymology of the name "Italia" are numerous.<sup id="cite_ref-Manco_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Manco-40">[40]</a></sup> One is that it was borrowed via <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Greek</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Oscan_language" title="Oscan language">Oscan</a> <i>Víteliú</i> 'land of calves' (<i>cf.</i> <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Lat</a> <i>vitulus</i> "calf", <a href="/wiki/Umbrian_language" title="Umbrian language">Umb</a> <i>vitlo</i> "calf").<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> Greek historian <a href="/wiki/Dionysius_of_Halicarnassus" title="Dionysius of Halicarnassus">Dionysius of Halicarnassus</a> states this account together with the legend that Italy was named after <a href="/wiki/Italus" title="Italus">Italus</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> mentioned also by <a href="/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle">Aristotle</a><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Thucydides" title="Thucydides">Thucydides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/Antiochus_of_Syracuse" title="Antiochus of Syracuse">Antiochus of Syracuse</a>, the term Italy was used by the Greeks to initially refer only to the southern portion of the Bruttium peninsula corresponding to the modern province of <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Reggio_Calabria" title="Province of Reggio Calabria">Reggio</a> and part of the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Catanzaro" title="Catanzaro">Catanzaro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vibo_Valentia" title="Vibo Valentia">Vibo Valentia</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">southern Italy</a>. Nevertheless, by his time the larger concept of <a href="/wiki/Oenotria" class="mw-redirect" title="Oenotria">Oenotria</a> and "Italy" had become synonymous and the name also applied to most of <a href="/wiki/Lucania" title="Lucania">Lucania</a> as well. According to <a href="/wiki/Strabo" title="Strabo">Strabo</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Geographica" title="Geographica">Geographica</a></i>, before the expansion of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a>, the name was used by Greeks to indicate the land between the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Messina" title="Strait of Messina">strait of Messina</a> and the line connecting the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Salerno" title="Gulf of Salerno">gulf of Salerno</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Taranto" title="Gulf of Taranto">gulf of Taranto</a>, corresponding roughly to the current region of <a href="/wiki/Calabria" title="Calabria">Calabria</a>. The Greeks gradually came to apply the name "Italia" to a larger region<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> In addition to the "Greek Italy" in the south, historians have suggested the existence of an "Etruscan Italy" covering variable areas of central Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The borders of Roman Italy, <i>Italia</i>, are better established. Cato's <i><a href="/wiki/Origines" title="Origines">Origines</a></i>, the first work of <a href="/wiki/History" title="History">history</a> composed in <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>, described Italy as the entire peninsula south of the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> According to Cato and several Roman authors, the Alps formed the "walls of Italy".<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> In 264 BC, Roman Italy extended from the <a href="/wiki/Arno" title="Arno">Arno</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rubicon" title="Rubicon">Rubicon</a> rivers of the centre-north to the entire south. The northern area of <a href="/wiki/Cisalpine_Gaul" title="Cisalpine Gaul">Cisalpine Gaul</a> was occupied by Rome in the 220s BC and became considered geographically and <i>de facto</i> part of Italy,<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> but remained politically and <i>de jure</i> separated. It was legally merged into the administrative unit of Italy in 42 BC by the triumvir <a href="/wiki/Octavian" class="mw-redirect" title="Octavian">Octavian</a> as a ratification of <a href="/wiki/Caesar" class="mw-redirect" title="Caesar">Caesar</a>'s unpublished acts (<i>Acta Caesaris</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DRR_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DRR-51">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-au_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-au-54">[54]</a></sup> The islands of Sardinia, Corsica, Sicily and Malta were added to Italy by <a href="/wiki/Diocletian" title="Diocletian">Diocletian</a> in 292 AD.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Italy" title="History of Italy">History of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_antiquity">Prehistory and antiquity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Italy" title="Prehistoric Italy">Prehistoric Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italic_peoples" title="Italic peoples">Italic peoples</a>, <a href="/wiki/Etruscan_civilisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Etruscan civilisation">Etruscan civilisation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia">Magna Graecia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nuragic_civilisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuragic civilisation">Nuragic civilisation</a>
      </div> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:254px;max-width:254px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Matera_from_Piazzetta_Pascoli-2930.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Matera_from_Piazzetta_Pascoli-2930.jpg/250px-Matera_from_Piazzetta_Pascoli-2930.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Matera_from_Piazzetta_Pascoli-2930.jpg/375px-Matera_from_Piazzetta_Pascoli-2930.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Matera_from_Piazzetta_Pascoli-2930.jpg/500px-Matera_from_Piazzetta_Pascoli-2930.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5106" data-file-height="3404"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <i><a href="/wiki/Sassi_di_Matera" title="Sassi di Matera">Sassi</a></i> cave houses of <a href="/wiki/Matera" title="Matera">Matera</a> are among the first human settlements in Italy dating back to the Paleolithic.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Etruscan_Painting_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Etruscan_Painting_1.jpg/250px-Etruscan_Painting_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="156" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Etruscan_Painting_1.jpg/375px-Etruscan_Painting_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Etruscan_Painting_1.jpg/500px-Etruscan_Painting_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="755" data-file-height="470"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Etruscan_civilization" title="Etruscan civilization">Etruscan</a> fresco in the <a href="/wiki/Monterozzi_necropolis" title="Monterozzi necropolis">Monterozzi necropolis</a>, 5th century BC
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Thousands of <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a>-era artifacts have been recovered from <a href="/wiki/Monte_Poggiolo" title="Monte Poggiolo">Monte Poggiolo</a> and dated to around 850,000 years before the present, making them the oldest evidence of first hominins habitation in the peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-nationalgeographic.it_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nationalgeographic.it-57">[57]</a></sup> Excavations throughout Italy revealed a <a href="/wiki/Neanderthal" title="Neanderthal">Neanderthal</a> presence dating back to the Palaeolithic period some 200,000 years ago,<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Anatomically_modern_humans" class="mw-redirect" title="Anatomically modern humans">modern Humans</a> appeared about 40,000 years ago at <a href="/wiki/Riparo_Mochi" class="mw-redirect" title="Riparo Mochi">Riparo Mochi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> Archaeological sites from this period include <a href="/wiki/Grotta_dell%27Addaura" title="Grotta dell'Addaura">Addaura cave</a>, <a href="/wiki/Altamura_Man" title="Altamura Man">Altamura</a>, <a href="/wiki/Homo_cepranensis" class="mw-redirect" title="Homo cepranensis">Ceprano</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gravina_in_Puglia" title="Gravina in Puglia">Gravina in Puglia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ancient_peoples_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient peoples of Italy">Ancient peoples</a> of pre-Roman Italy – such as the <a href="/wiki/Umbri" title="Umbri">Umbrians</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Latins_(Italic_tribe)" title="Latins (Italic tribe)">Latins</a> (from which the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Romans</a> emerged), <a href="/wiki/Volsci" title="Volsci">Volsci</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oscans" class="mw-redirect" title="Oscans">Oscans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samnites" title="Samnites">Samnites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sabines" title="Sabines">Sabines</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ligures" title="Ligures">Ligures</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Veneti" title="Adriatic Veneti">Veneti</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Iapygians" title="Iapygians">Iapygians</a> and many others – were <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-Europeans" title="Proto-Indo-Europeans">Indo-European</a> peoples, most of them specifically of the <a href="/wiki/Italic_peoples" title="Italic peoples">Italic</a> group. The main historic peoples of possible non-Indo-European or <a href="/wiki/Pre-Indo-European_languages" title="Pre-Indo-European languages">pre-Indo-European</a> heritage include the <a href="/wiki/Etruscans" class="mw-redirect" title="Etruscans">Etruscans</a> of central and northern Italy, the <a href="/wiki/Elymians" title="Elymians">Elymians</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sicani" title="Sicani">Sicani</a> in Sicily, and the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Sardinia" title="History of Sardinia">prehistoric</a> <a href="/wiki/Sardinians" class="mw-redirect" title="Sardinians">Sardinians</a>, who gave birth to the <a href="/wiki/Nuragic_civilisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuragic civilisation">Nuragic civilisation</a>. Other ancient populations being of undetermined language families and of possible non-Indo-European origin include the <a href="/wiki/Rhaetian_people" title="Rhaetian people">Rhaetian people</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cammuni" class="mw-redirect" title="Cammuni">Cammuni</a>, known for their <a href="/wiki/Rock_Drawings_in_Valcamonica" title="Rock Drawings in Valcamonica">rock carvings in Valcamonica</a>, the largest collections of prehistoric petroglyphs in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> A well-preserved natural mummy known as <a href="/wiki/%C3%96tzi_the_Iceman" class="mw-redirect" title="Ötzi the Iceman">Ötzi the Iceman</a>, determined to be 5,000 years old (between 3400 and 3100 BCE, Copper Age), was discovered in the Similaun glacier of <a href="/wiki/South_Tyrol" title="South Tyrol">South Tyrol</a> in 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The first foreign colonizers were the <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">Phoenicians</a>, who initially established colonies and founded various emporiums on the coasts of Sicily and Sardinia. Some of these soon became small urban centres and were developed parallel to the Greek colonies; among the main centres there were the cities of <a href="/wiki/Motya" title="Motya">Motya</a>, Zyz (modern <a href="/wiki/Palermo" title="Palermo">Palermo</a>), <a href="/wiki/Soluntum" title="Soluntum">Soluntum</a> in Sicily and <a href="/wiki/Nora,_Italy" title="Nora, Italy">Nora</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sulci" title="Sulci">Sulci</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tharros" title="Tharros">Tharros</a> in Sardinia.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Between the 17th and the 11th centuries BC <a href="/wiki/Mycenaean_Greece" title="Mycenaean Greece">Mycenaean Greeks</a> established contacts with Italy<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> and in the 8th and 7th centuries BC a number of <a href="/wiki/Greek_colonies" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek colonies">Greek colonies</a> were established all along the coast of Sicily and the southern part of the Italian Peninsula, that became known as <a href="/wiki/Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia">Magna Graecia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Ionians" title="Ionians">Ionian</a> settlers founded <a href="/wiki/Velia" title="Velia">Elaia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cumae" title="Cumae">Kyme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rhegion" class="mw-redirect" title="Rhegion">Rhegion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Naxos" title="Naxos">Naxos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zanclus" title="Zanclus">Zankles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Himera" title="Himera">Hymera</a> and <a href="/wiki/Katane" class="mw-redirect" title="Katane">Katane</a>. <a href="/wiki/Doric_Greek" title="Doric Greek">Doric</a> colonists founded <a href="/wiki/Taras,_Italy" title="Taras, Italy">Taras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syrakousai" class="mw-redirect" title="Syrakousai">Syrakousai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Megara_Hyblaea" title="Megara Hyblaea">Megara Hyblaia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leontinoi" class="mw-redirect" title="Leontinoi">Leontinoi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Akragas" class="mw-redirect" title="Akragas">Akragas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gela" title="Gela">Ghelas</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Syracusan" class="mw-redirect" title="Syracusan">Syracusans</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Ankon_(Picenum)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ankon (Picenum)">Ankón</a> and <a href="/wiki/Adria" title="Adria">Adria</a>; the megarese founded <a href="/wiki/Selinunte" title="Selinunte">Selinunte</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Achaeans_(tribe)" title="Achaeans (tribe)">Achaeans</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Sybaris" title="Sybaris">Sybaris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poseidonia" title="Poseidonia">Poseidonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crotone" title="Crotone">Kroton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Locri_Epizefiri" class="mw-redirect" title="Locri Epizefiri">Lokroi Epizephyrioi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Metapontum" title="Metapontum">Metapontum</a>; <a href="/wiki/Tarantine" class="mw-redirect" title="Tarantine">tarantini</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thurii" title="Thurii">thuriots</a> found <a href="/wiki/Eraclea" title="Eraclea">Herakleia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Greek_colonization_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek colonization of Italy">Greek colonization</a> places the <a href="/wiki/Italic_peoples" title="Italic peoples">Italic peoples</a> in contact with democratic forms of government and with high artistic and cultural expressions.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ancient_Rome">Ancient Rome</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Ancient Rome</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Roman_Kingdom" title="Roman Kingdom">Roman Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:254px;max-width:254px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Colosseum_in_Rome,_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg/250px-Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg/375px-Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg/500px-Colosseum_in_Rome%2C_Italy_-_April_2007.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4827" data-file-height="2833"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Colosseum" title="Colosseum">Colosseum</a> in Rome, built c. 70–80 AD, is considered one of the greatest works of <a href="/wiki/Architecture" title="Architecture">architecture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Engineering" title="Engineering">engineering</a> of ancient history.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png/250px-Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="159" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png/375px-Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png/500px-Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png 2x" data-file-width="2534" data-file-height="1614"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> at its greatest extent, 117 AD
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Rome</a>, a settlement around a ford on the river <a href="/wiki/Tiber" title="Tiber">Tiber</a> in central Italy conventionally <a href="/wiki/Founding_of_Rome" title="Founding of Rome">founded</a> in 753 BC, was ruled for a period of 244 years by a <a href="/wiki/Roman_Kingdom" title="Roman Kingdom">monarchical</a> system, initially with sovereigns of <a href="/wiki/Latins_(Italic_tribe)" title="Latins (Italic tribe)">Latin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sabines" title="Sabines">Sabine</a> origin, later by Etruscan kings. The tradition handed down seven kings: <a href="/wiki/Romulus" title="Romulus">Romulus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Numa_Pompilius" title="Numa Pompilius">Numa Pompilius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tullus_Hostilius" title="Tullus Hostilius">Tullus Hostilius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancus_Marcius" title="Ancus Marcius">Ancus Marcius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tarquinius_Priscus" class="mw-redirect" title="Tarquinius Priscus">Tarquinius Priscus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Servius_Tullius" title="Servius Tullius">Servius Tullius</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tarquinius_Superbus" class="mw-redirect" title="Tarquinius Superbus">Tarquinius Superbus</a>. In 509 BC, the Romans <a href="/wiki/Overthrow_of_the_Roman_monarchy" title="Overthrow of the Roman monarchy">expelled the last king</a> from their city, favouring a government of the <a href="/wiki/SPQR" title="SPQR">Senate and the People</a> (SPQR) and establishing an <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">oligarchic republic</a>. </p>
      <p>The Italian Peninsula, named <a href="/wiki/Roman_Italy" title="Roman Italy">Italia</a>, was consolidated into a single entity during the Roman <a href="/wiki/Roman_expansion_in_Italy" title="Roman expansion in Italy">expansion</a> and conquest of new lands at the expense of the <a href="/wiki/Samnite_Wars" title="Samnite Wars">other Italic tribes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman%E2%80%93Etruscan_Wars" title="Roman–Etruscan Wars">Etruscans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman%E2%80%93Gallic_wars" title="Roman–Gallic wars">Celts</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pyrrhic_War" title="Pyrrhic War">Greeks</a>. A <a href="/wiki/Socii" title="Socii">permanent association</a> with most of the local tribes and cities was formed, and Rome began the conquest of Western Europe, Northern Africa and the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Middle_East#Greek_and_Roman_Empire" title="History of the Middle East">Middle East</a>. In the wake of <a href="/wiki/Julius_Caesar" title="Julius Caesar">Julius Caesar</a>'s rise and <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Julius_Caesar" title="Assassination of Julius Caesar">death</a> in the first century BC, Rome grew over the course of centuries into a massive <a href="/wiki/Roman_empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman empire">empire</a> stretching from <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">Britain</a> to the borders of <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia_(Roman_province)" title="Mesopotamia (Roman province)">Persia</a>, and engulfing the whole <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> basin, in which Greek and Roman and many other cultures merged into a unique <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_world" title="Greco-Roman world">civilisation</a>. The long and triumphant reign of the first emperor, <a href="/wiki/Augustus" title="Augustus">Augustus</a>, began a golden age of peace and prosperity. Italy remained the metropole of the empire, and as the homeland of the Romans and the territory of the capital, maintained a special status which made it "not a province, but the <i><a href="/wiki/Dominus_(title)" title="Dominus (title)">Domina</a></i> (ruler) of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_province" title="Roman province">provinces</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> More than <a href="/wiki/Pax_Romana" title="Pax Romana">two centuries of stability</a> followed, during which Italy was referred to as the <i>rectrix mundi</i> (queen of the world) and <i>omnium terrarum parens</i> (motherland of all lands).<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Roman Empire was among the most powerful economic, cultural, political and military forces in the world of its time, and it was one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires" title="List of largest empires">largest empires in world history</a>. At its height under <a href="/wiki/Trajan" title="Trajan">Trajan</a>, it covered 5 million square kilometres.<sup id="cite_ref-size_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-size-72">[72]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cliodynamics.info_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cliodynamics.info-73">[73]</a></sup> The Roman <a href="/wiki/Legacy_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Legacy of the Roman Empire">legacy</a> has deeply influenced the Western civilisation, shaping most of the modern world; among the many legacies of Roman dominance are the widespread use of the <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">Romance languages</a> derived from Latin, the <a href="/wiki/Roman_numerals" title="Roman numerals">numerical system</a>, the modern Western <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">alphabet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_calendar" class="mw-redirect" title="Western calendar">calendar</a>, and the emergence of Christianity as a major world religion.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Indo-Roman_trade_relations" title="Indo-Roman trade relations">Indo-Roman trade relations</a>, beginning around the 1st century BCE, testifies to extensive Roman trade in far away regions; many reminders of the commercial trade between the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> and Italy have been found, such as the ivory statuette <a href="/wiki/Pompeii_Lakshmi" title="Pompeii Lakshmi">Pompeii Lakshmi</a> from the ruins of <a href="/wiki/Pompeii" title="Pompeii">Pompeii</a>. </p>
      <p>In a slow <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Roman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Decline of the Roman Empire">decline</a> since the third century AD, the Empire split in two in 395 AD. The <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Western Empire</a>, under the pressure of the <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">barbarian invasions</a>, eventually dissolved in 476 AD when its last emperor, <a href="/wiki/Romulus_Augustulus" title="Romulus Augustulus">Romulus Augustulus</a>, was deposed by the Germanic chief <a href="/wiki/Odoacer" title="Odoacer">Odoacer</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Roman Empire">Eastern</a> half of the Empire survived for another thousand years. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Italy_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Italy in the Middle Ages">Italy in the Middle Ages</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Barbarian_kingdoms" title="Barbarian kingdoms">Barbarian kingdoms</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Iron_Crown.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Iron_Crown.JPG/220px-Iron_Crown.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Iron_Crown.JPG/330px-Iron_Crown.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Iron_Crown.JPG/440px-Iron_Crown.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1890" data-file-height="1154"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Iron_Crown.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Iron_Crown_of_Lombardy" title="Iron Crown of Lombardy">Iron Crown of Lombardy</a>, for centuries a symbol of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy_(Holy_Roman_Empire)" title="Kingdom of Italy (Holy Roman Empire)">Kings of Italy</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">fall of the Western Roman Empire</a>, Italy fell under the power of Odoacer's <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy_(476%E2%80%93493)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Italy (476–493)">kingdom</a>, and, later, was seized by the <a href="/wiki/Ostrogoths" title="Ostrogoths">Ostrogoths</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> followed in the 6th century by a brief <a href="/wiki/Gothic_War_(535%E2%80%93554)" title="Gothic War (535–554)">reconquest</a> under <a href="/wiki/Byzantine" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine">Byzantine</a> Emperor <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">Justinian</a>. The invasion of another <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic tribe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Lombards" title="Lombards">Lombards</a>, late in the same century, reduced the Byzantine presence to the rump realm of the <a href="/wiki/Exarchate_of_Ravenna" title="Exarchate of Ravenna">Exarchate of Ravenna</a> and started the end of political unity of the peninsula for the next 1,300 years. Invasions of the peninsula caused a chaotic succession of barbarian kingdoms and the so-called "<a href="/wiki/Dark_Ages_(historiography)" title="Dark Ages (historiography)">dark ages</a>". The Lombard kingdom was subsequently absorbed into the <a href="/wiki/Frankish_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Frankish Empire">Frankish Empire</a> by <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a> in the late 8th century. The Franks also helped the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a> in central Italy. Until the 13th century, Italian politics was dominated by the relations between the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Holy Roman Emperor">Holy Roman Emperors</a> and the Papacy, with most of the Italian city-states siding with the former (<a href="/wiki/Ghibellines" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghibellines">Ghibellines</a>) or with the latter (<a href="/wiki/Guelphs" class="mw-redirect" title="Guelphs">Guelphs</a>) from momentary convenience.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Marco_Polo_Mosaic_from_Palazzo_Tursi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Marco_Polo_Mosaic_from_Palazzo_Tursi.jpg/170px-Marco_Polo_Mosaic_from_Palazzo_Tursi.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="213" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Marco_Polo_Mosaic_from_Palazzo_Tursi.jpg/255px-Marco_Polo_Mosaic_from_Palazzo_Tursi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Marco_Polo_Mosaic_from_Palazzo_Tursi.jpg/340px-Marco_Polo_Mosaic_from_Palazzo_Tursi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1286"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Marco_Polo_Mosaic_from_Palazzo_Tursi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo" title="Marco Polo">Marco Polo</a>, explorer of the 13th century, recorded his 24 years-long travels in the <i><a href="/wiki/The_Travels_of_Marco_Polo" title="The Travels of Marco Polo">Book of the Marvels of the World</a></i>, introducing Europeans to Central Asia and China.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Germanic Emperor and the Roman Pontiff became the <a href="/wiki/Universal_power" title="Universal power">universal powers</a> of medieval Europe. However, the conflict for the <a href="/wiki/Investiture_controversy" class="mw-redirect" title="Investiture controversy">investiture controversy</a> (a conflict over two radically different views of whether secular authorities such as kings, counts, or dukes, had any legitimate role in appointments to ecclesiastical offices) and the clash between Guelphs and Ghibellines led to the end of the Imperial-feudal system in the north of Italy where city-states gained independence. It was during this chaotic era that Italian towns saw the rise of a peculiar institution, the <a href="/wiki/Medieval_commune" title="Medieval commune">medieval commune</a>. Given the power vacuum caused by extreme territorial fragmentation and the struggle between the Empire and the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>, local communities sought autonomous ways to maintain law and order.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> The investiture controversy was finally resolved by the <a href="/wiki/Concordat_of_Worms" class="mw-redirect" title="Concordat of Worms">Concordat of Worms</a>. In 1176 a league of city-states, the <a href="/wiki/Lombard_League" title="Lombard League">Lombard League</a>, defeated the German emperor <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Barbarossa" class="mw-redirect" title="Frederick Barbarossa">Frederick Barbarossa</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Legnano" title="Battle of Legnano">Battle of Legnano</a>, thus ensuring effective independence for most of northern and central Italian cities. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:NuovaFlorence.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/NuovaFlorence.jpg/220px-NuovaFlorence.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="113" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/NuovaFlorence.jpg/330px-NuovaFlorence.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/27/NuovaFlorence.jpg 2x" data-file-width="373" data-file-height="191"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:NuovaFlorence.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A 14th century conflict between <a href="/wiki/Guelph_and_Ghibelline" class="mw-redirect" title="Guelph and Ghibelline">Guelph and Ghibelline</a> factions as portrayed in the <i><a href="/wiki/Nuova_Cronica" title="Nuova Cronica">Nuova Cronica</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Villani" title="Giovanni Villani">Giovanni Villani</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italian city-states such as Milan, Florence and Venice played a crucial innovative role in financial development, devising the main instruments and practices of banking and the emergence of new forms of social and economic organization.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> In coastal and southern areas, the <a href="/wiki/Maritime_republics" title="Maritime republics">maritime republics</a> grew to eventually dominate the Mediterranean and monopolise trade routes to the <a href="/wiki/Orient" title="Orient">Orient</a>. They were independent thalassocratic city-states, though most of them originated from territories once belonging to the Byzantine Empire. All these cities during the time of their independence had similar systems of government in which the merchant class had considerable power. Although in practice these were oligarchical, and bore little resemblance to a modern <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a>, the relative political freedom they afforded was conducive to academic and artistic advancement.<sup id="cite_ref-Lane_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lane-80">[80]</a></sup> The four best known maritime republics were <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Venice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">Genoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Pisa" title="Republic of Pisa">Pisa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Amalfi" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Amalfi">Amalfi</a>; the others were <a href="/wiki/Ancona#Maritime_Republic_of_Ancona" title="Ancona">Ancona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Gaeta" title="Duchy of Gaeta">Gaeta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Noli" title="Republic of Noli">Noli</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa" title="Republic of Ragusa">Ragusa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> Each of the maritime republics had dominion over different overseas lands, including many Mediterranean islands (especially Sardinia and Corsica), lands on the Adriatic, Aegean, and Black Sea (Crimea), and commercial colonies in the Near East and in North Africa. Venice maintained enormous tracts of land in Greece, Cyprus, Istria and Dalmatia until as late as the mid-17th century.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:337px;max-width:337px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:116px;max-width:116px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:114px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Naval_Jack_of_Italy.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Naval_Jack_of_Italy.svg/114px-Naval_Jack_of_Italy.svg.png" decoding="async" width="114" height="114" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Naval_Jack_of_Italy.svg/171px-Naval_Jack_of_Italy.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Naval_Jack_of_Italy.svg/228px-Naval_Jack_of_Italy.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="256" data-file-height="256"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:114px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Republik_Venedig_Handelswege01.png" class="image"><img alt="Map" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Republik_Venedig_Handelswege01.png/215px-Republik_Venedig_Handelswege01.png" decoding="async" width="215" height="114" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Republik_Venedig_Handelswege01.png/323px-Republik_Venedig_Handelswege01.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Republik_Venedig_Handelswege01.png/430px-Republik_Venedig_Handelswege01.png 2x" data-file-width="943" data-file-height="501"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <i>Left</i>: Flag of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Navy" title="Italian Navy">Italian Navy</a>, displaying the coat of arms of <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Venice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">Genoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Pisa" title="Republic of Pisa">Pisa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Amalfi" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Amalfi">Amalfi</a>, the most prominent <a href="/wiki/Maritime_republics" title="Maritime republics">maritime republics</a>.
          <br><i>Right</i>: Trade routes and colonies of the <a href="/wiki/Genoese_colonies" title="Genoese colonies">Genoese</a> <small>(red)</small> and <a href="/wiki/Stato_da_M%C3%A0r" title="Stato da Màr">Venetian</a> <small>(green)</small> empires.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venice and Genoa were Europe's main gateway to trade with the East, and a producer of fine glass, while <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Florence" title="Republic of Florence">Florence</a> was a capital of silk, wool, banks and jewellery. The wealth such business brought to Italy meant that large public and private artistic projects could be commissioned. The republics were heavily involved in the <a href="/wiki/Crusades" title="Crusades">Crusades</a>, providing support and transport, but most especially taking advantage of the political and trading opportunities resulting from these wars.<sup id="cite_ref-Lane_80-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lane-80">[80]</a></sup> Italy first felt huge economic changes in Europe which led to the <a href="/wiki/Commercial_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="Commercial revolution">commercial revolution</a>: the Republic of Venice was able to <a href="/wiki/Sack_of_Constantinople" title="Sack of Constantinople">defeat the Byzantine Empire</a> and finance the voyages of <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo" title="Marco Polo">Marco Polo</a> to Asia; the first universities were formed in Italian cities, and scholars such as <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Aquinas" title="Thomas Aquinas">Thomas Aquinas</a> obtained international fame; <a href="/wiki/Frederick_of_Sicily" class="mw-redirect" title="Frederick of Sicily">Frederick of Sicily</a> made Italy the political-<a href="/wiki/Dolce_stil_novo" class="mw-redirect" title="Dolce stil novo">cultural centre</a> of a reign that temporarily included the Holy Roman Empire and the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Jerusalem" title="Kingdom of Jerusalem">Kingdom of Jerusalem</a>; capitalism and banking families emerged in Florence, where <a href="/wiki/Dante" class="mw-redirect" title="Dante">Dante</a> and <a href="/wiki/Giotto" title="Giotto">Giotto</a> were active around 1300.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-24">[24]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the south, Sicily had become an <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Sicily" title="Emirate of Sicily">Islamic emirate</a> in the 9th century, thriving until the <a href="/wiki/Italo-Normans" title="Italo-Normans">Italo-Normans</a> conquered it in the late 11th century together with most of the Lombard and Byzantine principalities of southern Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> Through a complex series of events, southern Italy developed as a unified kingdom, first under the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Hohenstaufen" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Hohenstaufen">House of Hohenstaufen</a>, then under the <a href="/wiki/Capetian_House_of_Anjou" title="Capetian House of Anjou">Capetian House of Anjou</a> and, from the 15th century, the House of Aragon. In <a href="/wiki/Sardinia" title="Sardinia">Sardinia</a>, the former Byzantine provinces became independent states known in Italian as <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_medieval_kingdoms" title="Sardinian medieval kingdoms">Judicates</a>, although some parts of the island fell under Genoese or Pisan rule until the eventual Aragonese annexation in the 15th century. The <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a> <a href="/wiki/Pandemic" title="Pandemic">pandemic</a> of 1348 left its mark on Italy by killing perhaps one third of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> However, the recovery from the plague led to a resurgence of cities, trade and economy which allowed the bloom of <a href="/wiki/Humanism" title="Humanism">Humanism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>, that later spread to Europe. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Modern">Early Modern</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Italian_Renaissance" title="Italian Renaissance">Italian Renaissance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Wars" title="Italian Wars">Italian Wars</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Italy_(1559%E2%80%931814)" title="History of Italy (1559–1814)">History of Italy (1559–1814)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Italy_1494.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Italy_1494.svg/220px-Italy_1494.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="263" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Italy_1494.svg/330px-Italy_1494.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Italy_1494.svg/440px-Italy_1494.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="3481" data-file-height="4167"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Italy_1494.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/List_of_historic_states_of_Italy#Late_Middle_Ages" title="List of historic states of Italy">Italian states</a> before the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Wars" title="Italian Wars">Italian Wars</a> in 1494
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy was the birthplace and heart of the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> during the 1400s and 1500s. The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Renaissance" title="Italian Renaissance">Italian Renaissance</a> marked the transition from the medieval period to the modern age as Europe recovered, economically and culturally, from the crises of the <a href="/wiki/Late_Middle_Ages" title="Late Middle Ages">Late Middle Ages</a> and entered the <a href="/wiki/Early_Modern_Period" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Modern Period">Early Modern Period</a>. The Italian polities were now regional states effectively ruled by <a href="/wiki/Prince" title="Prince">Princes</a>, <i>de facto</i> monarchs in control of trade and administration, and their courts became major centres of <a href="/wiki/Arts" class="mw-redirect" title="Arts">Arts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sciences" class="mw-redirect" title="Sciences">Sciences</a>. The Italian princedoms represented a first form of modern states as opposed to feudal monarchies and multinational empires. The princedoms were led by political dynasties and merchant families such as the <a href="/wiki/Medici" class="mw-redirect" title="Medici">Medici</a> in <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">Florence</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Visconti_of_Milan" title="Visconti of Milan">Visconti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sforza" class="mw-redirect" title="Sforza">Sforza</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Milan" title="Duchy of Milan">Duchy of Milan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Doria_(family)" title="Doria (family)">Doria</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">Republic of Genoa</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mocenigo" class="mw-redirect" title="Mocenigo">Mocenigo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Barbarigo_family" title="Barbarigo family">Barbarigo</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Republic of Venice</a>, the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Este" title="House of Este">Este</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ferrara" title="Ferrara">Ferrara</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Gonzaga" title="House of Gonzaga">Gonzaga</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mantua" title="Mantua">Mantua</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-strathern_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-strathern-88">[88]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> The Renaissance was therefore a result of the great wealth accumulated by Italian merchant cities combined with the <a href="/wiki/Patronage" title="Patronage">patronage</a> of its dominant families.<sup id="cite_ref-strathern_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-strathern-88">[88]</a></sup> Italian Renaissance exercised a dominant influence on subsequent European painting and sculpture for centuries afterwards, with artists such as <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brunelleschi" class="mw-redirect" title="Brunelleschi">Brunelleschi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Botticelli" class="mw-redirect" title="Botticelli">Botticelli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michelangelo" title="Michelangelo">Michelangelo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Raphael" title="Raphael">Raphael</a>, <a href="/wiki/Giotto" title="Giotto">Giotto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donatello" title="Donatello">Donatello</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Titian" title="Titian">Titian</a>, and architects such as <a href="/wiki/Filippo_Brunelleschi" title="Filippo Brunelleschi">Filippo Brunelleschi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leon_Battista_Alberti" title="Leon Battista Alberti">Leon Battista Alberti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Palladio" title="Andrea Palladio">Andrea Palladio</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Donato_Bramante" title="Donato Bramante">Donato Bramante</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Leonardo_self.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Leonardo_self.jpg/170px-Leonardo_self.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="267" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Leonardo_self.jpg/255px-Leonardo_self.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Leonardo_self.jpg/340px-Leonardo_self.jpg 2x" data-file-width="420" data-file-height="659"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Leonardo_self.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a>, the quintessential <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_man" class="mw-redirect" title="Renaissance man">Renaissance man</a>, in a self-portrait (ca. 1512, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Library_of_Turin" title="Royal Library of Turin">Royal Library</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turin" title="Turin">Turin</a>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Following the conclusion of the <a href="/wiki/Western_schism" class="mw-redirect" title="Western schism">western schism</a> in favour of Rome at the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Constance" title="Council of Constance">Council of Constance</a> (1415–1417), the new <a href="/wiki/Pope_Martin_V" title="Pope Martin V">Pope Martin V</a> returned to the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a> after a three years-long journey that touched many Italian cities and restored Italy as the sole centre of Western Christianity. During the course of this voyage, the <a href="/wiki/Medici_Bank" title="Medici Bank">Medici Bank</a> was made the official credit institution of the Papacy and several significant ties were established between the Church and the new political dynasties of the peninsula. The Popes' status as elective monarchs turned the <a href="/wiki/Conclave" class="mw-redirect" title="Conclave">conclaves</a> and <a href="/wiki/Papal_consistory" title="Papal consistory">consistories</a> of the Renaissance into political battles between the courts of Italy for primacy in the peninsula and access to the immense resources of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a>.
