In 1439, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Eugenius_IV" class="mw-redirect" title="Pope Eugenius IV">Pope Eugenius IV</a> and the Byzantine Emperor <a href="/wiki/John_VIII_Palaiologos" title="John VIII Palaiologos">John VIII Palaiologos</a> signed a reconciliation agreement between the Catholic Church and the Orthodox Church at the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Florence" title="Council of Florence">Council of Florence</a> hosted by <a href="/wiki/Cosimo_de_Medici" class="mw-redirect" title="Cosimo de Medici">Cosimo <i>the old</i> de Medici</a>. In 1453, Italian forces under <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Giustiniani" title="Giovanni Giustiniani">Giovanni Giustiniani</a> were sent by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Nicholas_V" title="Pope Nicholas V">Pope Nicholas V</a> to defend the <a href="/wiki/Walls_of_Constantinople" title="Walls of Constantinople">Walls of Constantinople</a> but the decisive battle was lost to the more advanced Turkish army equipped with cannons, and <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">Byzantium fell</a> to Sultan <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Mehmed II">Mehmed II</a>. </p>
      <p>The fall of Constantinople led to the migration of <a href="/wiki/Greek_scholars_in_the_Renaissance" title="Greek scholars in the Renaissance">Greek scholars</a> and texts to Italy, fueling the rediscovery of Greco-Roman <a href="/wiki/Humanism" title="Humanism">Humanism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica1_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica1-90">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Harris_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-91">[91]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Norwich_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Norwich-92">[92]</a></sup> Humanist rulers such as <a href="/wiki/Federico_da_Montefeltro" title="Federico da Montefeltro">Federico da Montefeltro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_II" title="Pope Pius II">Pope Pius II</a> worked to establish <a href="/wiki/Ideal_city" title="Ideal city">ideal cities</a> where <i>man is the measure of all things</i>, and therefore founded <a href="/wiki/Urbino" title="Urbino">Urbino</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pienza" title="Pienza">Pienza</a> respectively. <a href="/wiki/Pico_della_Mirandola" class="mw-redirect" title="Pico della Mirandola">Pico della Mirandola</a> wrote the <i><a href="/wiki/Oration_on_the_Dignity_of_Man" title="Oration on the Dignity of Man">Oration on the Dignity of Man</a></i>, considered the manifesto of <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_Humanism" class="mw-redirect" title="Renaissance Humanism">Renaissance Humanism</a>, in which he stressed the importance of <a href="/wiki/Free_will" title="Free will">free will</a> in human beings. The humanist historian <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_Bruni" title="Leonardo Bruni">Leonardo Bruni</a> was the first to divide human history in three periods: Antiquity, Middle Ages and Modernity.<sup id="cite_ref-hankins-2001_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hankins-2001-93">[93]</a></sup> The second consequence of the Fall of Constantinople was the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Columbus_Taking_Possession.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Columbus_Taking_Possession.jpg/220px-Columbus_Taking_Possession.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Columbus_Taking_Possession.jpg/330px-Columbus_Taking_Possession.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Columbus_Taking_Possession.jpg/440px-Columbus_Taking_Possession.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2724" data-file-height="2062"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Columbus_Taking_Possession.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> leads an expedition to the New World, 1492. <a href="/wiki/Voyages_of_Christopher_Columbus" title="Voyages of Christopher Columbus">His voyages</a> are celebrated as the discovery of the Americas from a European perspective, and they opened a <a href="/wiki/Early_modern_period" title="Early modern period">new era</a> in the history of humankind and sustained contact between the two worlds.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italian <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_explorers" title="List of Italian explorers">explorers</a> and navigators from the dominant maritime republics, eager to find an alternative route to the Indies in order to bypass the Ottoman Empire, offered their services to monarchs of Atlantic countries and played a key role in ushering the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a> and the European colonization of the Americas. The most notable among them were: <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a>, colonizer in the name of Spain, who is credited with discovering the New World and the opening of the Americas for conquest and settlement by Europeans;<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/John_Cabot" title="John Cabot">John Cabot</a>, sailing for England, who was the first European to set foot in "New Found Land" and explore parts of the North American continent in 1497;<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Amerigo_Vespucci" title="Amerigo Vespucci">Amerigo Vespucci</a>, sailing for Portugal, who first demonstrated in about 1501 that the New World (in particular Brazil) was not Asia as initially conjectured, but a fourth continent previously unknown to people of the Old World (America is named after him);<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMartone2016504_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMartone2016504-96">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESider2007226_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESider2007226-97">[97]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_da_Verrazzano" title="Giovanni da Verrazzano">Giovanni da Verrazzano</a>, at the service of France, renowned as the first European to explore the Atlantic coast of North America between Florida and New Brunswick in 1524;<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Following the fall of Constantinople, the <a href="/wiki/Wars_in_Lombardy" title="Wars in Lombardy">wars in Lombardy</a> came to an end and a defensive alliance known as <a href="/wiki/Italic_League" title="Italic League">Italic League</a> was formed between Venice, Naples, Florence, Milan, and the Papacy. <a href="/wiki/Lorenzo_de_Medici" class="mw-redirect" title="Lorenzo de Medici">Lorenzo <i>the Magnificent</i> de Medici</a> was the greatest Florentine patron of the Renaissance and supporter of the Italic League. He notably avoided the collapse of the League in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Pazzi_Conspiracy" class="mw-redirect" title="Pazzi Conspiracy">Pazzi Conspiracy</a> and during the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Otranto" class="mw-redirect" title="Siege of Otranto">aborted invasion of Italy</a> by the Turks. However, the military campaign of <a href="/wiki/Charles_VIII_of_France" title="Charles VIII of France">Charles VIII of France</a> in Italy caused the end of the Italic League and initiated the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Wars" title="Italian Wars">Italian Wars</a> between the Valois and the Habsburgs. During the <a href="/wiki/High_Renaissance" title="High Renaissance">High Renaissance</a> of the 1500s, Italy was therefore both the main European battleground and the cultural-economic centre of the continent. Popes such as <a href="/wiki/Pope_Julius_II" title="Pope Julius II">Julius II</a> (1503–1513) fought for the control of Italy against foreign monarchs, others such as <a href="/wiki/Pope_Paul_III" title="Pope Paul III">Paul III</a> (1534–1549) preferred to mediate between the European powers in order to secure peace in Italy. In the middle of this conflict, the Medici popes <a href="/wiki/Pope_Leo_X" title="Pope Leo X">Leo X</a> (1513–1521) and <a href="/wiki/Pope_Clement_VII" title="Pope Clement VII">Clement VII</a> (1523–1534) opposed the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant reformation">Protestant reformation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caterina_de_Medici" class="mw-redirect" title="Caterina de Medici">advanced the interests of their family</a>. The end of the wars ultimately left <a href="/wiki/Northern_Italy" title="Northern Italy">northern Italy</a> indirectly subject to the Austrian Habsburgs and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">Southern Italy</a> under direct Spanish Habsburg rule. </p>
      <p>The Papacy remained independent and launched the <a href="/wiki/Counter-reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Counter-reformation">Counter-reformation</a>. Key events of the period include: the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a> (1545–1563); the excommunication of <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_I" title="Elizabeth I">Elizabeth I</a> (1570) and the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Lepanto" title="Battle of Lepanto">Battle of Lepanto</a> (1571), both occurring during the pontificate of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_V" title="Pope Pius V">Pius V</a>; the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Gregorian_Tower" title="Gregorian Tower">Gregorian observatory</a>, the adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Gregorian_calendar" title="Gregorian calendar">Gregorian calendar</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Jesuit_China_mission" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesuit China mission">Jesuit China mission</a> of <a href="/wiki/Matteo_Ricci" title="Matteo Ricci">Matteo Ricci</a> under <a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_XIII" title="Pope Gregory XIII">Pope Gregory XIII</a>; the <a href="/wiki/French_Wars_of_Religion" title="French Wars of Religion">French Wars of Religion</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Long_Turkish_War" title="Long Turkish War">Long Turkish War</a> and the execution of <a href="/wiki/Giordano_Bruno" title="Giordano Bruno">Giordano Bruno</a> in 1600, under <a href="/wiki/Pope_Clement_VIII" title="Pope Clement VIII">Pope Clement VIII</a>; the birth of the <a href="/wiki/Lyncean_Academy" class="mw-redirect" title="Lyncean Academy">Lyncean Academy</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a>, of which the main figure was <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Galilei" title="Galileo Galilei">Galileo Galilei</a> (later put <a href="/wiki/Galileo_affair" title="Galileo affair">on trial</a>); the final phases of the <a href="/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War" title="Thirty Years' War">Thirty Years' War</a> (1618–1648) during the pontificates of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Urban_VIII" title="Pope Urban VIII">Urban VIII</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pope_Innocent_X" title="Pope Innocent X">Innocent X</a>; and the formation of the last <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1684)" title="Holy League (1684)">Holy League</a> by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Innocent_XI" title="Pope Innocent XI">Innocent XI</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Turkish_War" title="Great Turkish War">Great Turkish War</a> </p>
      <p>The Italian economy declined during the 1600s and 1700s, as the peninsula was excluded from the rising <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">Atlantic slave trade</a>. Following the European wars of succession of the 18th century, the south passed to a cadet branch of the Spanish Bourbons and the North fell under the influence of the Habsburg-Lorraine of Austria. During the <a href="/wiki/Coalition_Wars" title="Coalition Wars">Coalition Wars</a>, northern-central Italy was reorganised by Napoleon in a number of <a href="/wiki/Sister_Republics" class="mw-redirect" title="Sister Republics">Sister Republics</a> of <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> and later as a <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy_(Napoleonic)" title="Kingdom of Italy (Napoleonic)">Kingdom of Italy</a> in <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">personal union</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Napoleonic France">French Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> The southern half of the peninsula was administered by <a href="/wiki/Joachim_Murat" title="Joachim Murat">Joachim Murat</a>, Napoleon's brother-in-law, who was crowned as <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Naples" title="Kingdom of Naples">King of Naples</a>. The 1814 <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a> restored the situation of the late 18th century, but the ideals of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a> could not be eradicated, and soon re-surfaced during the <a href="/wiki/Political_revolution" title="Political revolution">political upheavals</a> that characterised the first part of the 19th century. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Italian_unification">Italian unification</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Italian_unification" title="Italian unification">Italian unification</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:275px;max-width:275px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:128px;max-width:128px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Gebr%C3%BCder_Alinari_-_Giuseppe_Mazzini_(Zeno_Fotografie).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Gebr%C3%BCder_Alinari_-_Giuseppe_Mazzini_%28Zeno_Fotografie%29.jpg/126px-Gebr%C3%BCder_Alinari_-_Giuseppe_Mazzini_%28Zeno_Fotografie%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="126" height="183" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Gebr%C3%BCder_Alinari_-_Giuseppe_Mazzini_%28Zeno_Fotografie%29.jpg/189px-Gebr%C3%BCder_Alinari_-_Giuseppe_Mazzini_%28Zeno_Fotografie%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Gebr%C3%BCder_Alinari_-_Giuseppe_Mazzini_%28Zeno_Fotografie%29.jpg/252px-Gebr%C3%BCder_Alinari_-_Giuseppe_Mazzini_%28Zeno_Fotografie%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="776" data-file-height="1129"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:143px;max-width:143px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Giuseppe_Garibaldi_(1866).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Giuseppe_Garibaldi_%281866%29.jpg/141px-Giuseppe_Garibaldi_%281866%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="141" height="183" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Giuseppe_Garibaldi_%281866%29.jpg/212px-Giuseppe_Garibaldi_%281866%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Giuseppe_Garibaldi_%281866%29.jpg/282px-Giuseppe_Garibaldi_%281866%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="366" data-file-height="476"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Mazzini" title="Giuseppe Mazzini">Giuseppe Mazzini</a> <i>(left)</i>, highly influential leader of the Italian revolutionary movement; and <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Garibaldi" title="Giuseppe Garibaldi">Giuseppe Garibaldi</a> <i>(right)</i>, celebrated as one of the greatest generals of modern times<sup id="cite_ref-scholar_and_patriot_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scholar_and_patriot-100">[100]</a></sup> and as the "Hero of the Two Worlds",<sup id="cite_ref-Garibaldi_on_Encyclopædia_Britannica_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Garibaldi_on_Encyclopædia_Britannica-101">[101]</a></sup> who commanded and fought in many military campaigns that led to Italian unification
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Birth_of_the_Kingdom_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Birth of the Kingdom of Italy">birth of the Kingdom of Italy</a> was the result of efforts by Italian nationalists and monarchists loyal to the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Savoy" title="House of Savoy">House of Savoy</a> to establish a united kingdom encompassing the entire <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">Italian Peninsula</a>. Following the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a> in 1815, the political and social <a href="/wiki/Italian_unification" title="Italian unification">Italian unification</a> movement, or <i>Risorgimento</i>, emerged to unite Italy consolidating the different states of the peninsula and liberate it from foreign control. A prominent radical figure was the patriotic journalist <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Mazzini" title="Giuseppe Mazzini">Giuseppe Mazzini</a>, member of the secret revolutionary society <i><a href="/wiki/Carbonari" title="Carbonari">Carbonari</a></i> and founder of the influential political movement <a href="/wiki/Young_Italy_(historical)" class="mw-redirect" title="Young Italy (historical)">Young Italy</a> in the early 1830s, who favoured a unitary republic and advocated a broad nationalist movement. His prolific output of propaganda helped the unification movement stay active. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Italian-unification.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Italian-unification.gif/220px-Italian-unification.gif" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Italian-unification.gif/330px-Italian-unification.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Italian-unification.gif/440px-Italian-unification.gif 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="640"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Italian-unification.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Animated map of the Italian unification from 1829 to 1871
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The most famous member of Young Italy was the revolutionary and general <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Garibaldi" title="Giuseppe Garibaldi">Giuseppe Garibaldi</a>, renowned for his extremely loyal followers,<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> who led the Italian republican drive for unification in Southern Italy. However, the Northern Italy monarchy of the House of Savoy in the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sardinia" title="Kingdom of Sardinia">Kingdom of Sardinia</a>, whose government was led by <a href="/wiki/Camillo_Benso,_Count_of_Cavour" title="Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour">Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour</a>, also had ambitions of establishing a united Italian state. In the context of the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1848" title="Revolutions of 1848">1848 liberal revolutions</a> that swept through Europe, an unsuccessful <a href="/wiki/First_Italian_War_of_Independence" title="First Italian War of Independence">first war of independence</a> was declared on <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria</a>. In 1855, the Kingdom of Sardinia became an ally of Britain and France in the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_War" title="Crimean War">Crimean War</a>, giving Cavour's diplomacy legitimacy in the eyes of the great powers.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> The Kingdom of Sardinia again attacked the Austrian Empire in the <a href="/wiki/Second_Italian_War_of_Independence" title="Second Italian War of Independence">Second Italian War of Independence</a> of 1859, with the aid of <a href="/wiki/Second_French_Empire" title="Second French Empire">France</a>, resulting in liberating <a href="/wiki/Lombardy" title="Lombardy">Lombardy</a>. On the basis of the <a href="/wiki/Plombi%C3%A8res_Agreement" title="Plombières Agreement">Plombières Agreement</a>, the Kingdom of Sardinia ceded <a href="/wiki/Savoy" title="Savoy">Savoy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nice" title="Nice">Nice</a> to France, an event that caused the <a href="/wiki/Ni%C3%A7ard_exodus" title="Niçard exodus">Niçard exodus</a>, that was the emigration of a quarter of the <a href="/wiki/Ni%C3%A7ard_Italians" title="Niçard Italians">Niçard Italians</a> to Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1860–1861, Garibaldi led the drive for unification in Naples and Sicily (the <a href="/wiki/Expedition_of_the_Thousand" title="Expedition of the Thousand">Expedition of the Thousand</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> while the House of Savoy troops occupied the central territories of the Italian peninsula, except Rome and part of Papal States. <a href="/wiki/Teano" title="Teano">Teano</a> was the site of the famous meeting of 26 October 1860 between Giuseppe Garibaldi and <a href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_II_of_Italy" title="Victor Emmanuel II of Italy">Victor Emmanuel II</a>, last King of Sardinia, in which Garibaldi shook Victor Emanuel's hand and hailed him as King of Italy; thus, Garibaldi sacrificed republican hopes for the sake of Italian unity under a monarchy. Cavour agreed to include Garibaldi's Southern Italy allowing it to join the union with the Kingdom of Sardinia in 1860. This allowed the Sardinian government to declare a united Italian kingdom on 17 March 1861.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> Victor Emmanuel II then became the first king of a united Italy, and the capital was moved from Turin to Florence. </p>
      <p>In 1866, Victor Emmanuel II allied with <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">Prussia</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Prussian_War" title="Austro-Prussian War">Austro-Prussian War</a>, waging the <a href="/wiki/Third_Italian_War_of_Independence" title="Third Italian War of Independence">Third Italian War of Independence</a> which allowed Italy to annexe <a href="/wiki/Veneto" title="Veneto">Venetia</a>. Finally, in 1870, as France abandoned its garrisons in Rome during the disastrous <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a> to keep the large Prussian Army at bay, the Italians rushed to fill the power gap by <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_Rome" title="Capture of Rome">taking over the Papal States</a>. Italian unification was completed and shortly afterwards Italy's capital was moved to Rome. Victor Emmanuel, Garibaldi, Cavour and Mazzini have been referred as Italy's <i>Four Fathers of the Fatherland</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-scholar_and_patriot_100-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scholar_and_patriot-100">[100]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monarchical_period">Monarchical period</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Empire" title="Italian Empire">Italian Empire</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Italy_during_World_War_I" title="Military history of Italy during World War I">Military history of Italy during World War I</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:286px;max-width:286px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:141px;max-width:141px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ritratto_di_S.M._Vittorio_Emanuele_II.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Ritratto_di_S.M._Vittorio_Emanuele_II.jpg/139px-Ritratto_di_S.M._Vittorio_Emanuele_II.jpg" decoding="async" width="139" height="188" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Ritratto_di_S.M._Vittorio_Emanuele_II.jpg/209px-Ritratto_di_S.M._Vittorio_Emanuele_II.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Ritratto_di_S.M._Vittorio_Emanuele_II.jpg/278px-Ritratto_di_S.M._Vittorio_Emanuele_II.jpg 2x" data-file-width="708" data-file-height="960"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:141px;max-width:141px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Camillo_Benso_Cavour_di_Ciseri.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Camillo_Benso_Cavour_di_Ciseri.jpg/139px-Camillo_Benso_Cavour_di_Ciseri.jpg" decoding="async" width="139" height="189" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Camillo_Benso_Cavour_di_Ciseri.jpg/209px-Camillo_Benso_Cavour_di_Ciseri.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Camillo_Benso_Cavour_di_Ciseri.jpg/278px-Camillo_Benso_Cavour_di_Ciseri.jpg 2x" data-file-width="581" data-file-height="789"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <a href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_II_of_Italy" title="Victor Emmanuel II of Italy">Victor Emmanuel II</a> and <a href="/wiki/Camillo_Benso,_Count_of_Cavour" title="Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour">Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour</a>, leading figures in the Italian unification, became respectively the 1st king and 1st Prime Minister of unified Italy
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The new Kingdom of Italy obtained <a href="/wiki/Great_Power" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Power">Great Power</a> status. The Constitutional Law of the Kingdom of Sardinia the <a href="/wiki/Statuto_Albertino" title="Statuto Albertino">Albertine Statute</a> of 1848, was extended to the whole Kingdom of Italy in 1861, and provided for basic freedoms of the new State, but electoral laws excluded the non-propertied and uneducated classes from voting. The government of the new kingdom took place in a framework of parliamentary constitutional monarchy dominated by liberal forces. As <a href="/wiki/Northern_Italy" title="Northern Italy">Northern Italy</a> quickly industrialised, the South and rural areas of the North remained underdeveloped and overpopulated, forcing millions of people to migrate abroad and fuelling a large and influential <a href="/wiki/Italian_diaspora" title="Italian diaspora">diaspora</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Socialist_Party" title="Italian Socialist Party">Italian Socialist Party</a> constantly increased in strength, challenging the traditional liberal and conservative establishment. </p>
      <p>Starting from the last two decades of the 19th century, Italy developed into a <a href="/wiki/Italian_Empire" title="Italian Empire">colonial power</a> by forcing under its rule <a href="/wiki/Italian_Eritrea" title="Italian Eritrea">Eritrea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_Somalia" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Somalia">Somalia</a> in East Africa, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Tripolitania" title="Italian Tripolitania">Tripolitania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_Cyrenaica" title="Italian Cyrenaica">Cyrenaica</a> in North Africa (later unified in the colony of <a href="/wiki/Italian_Libya" title="Italian Libya">Libya</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Dodecanese" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Dodecanese">Dodecanese</a> islands.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> From 2 November 1899 to 7 September 1901, Italy also participated as part of the <a href="/wiki/Eight-Nation_Alliance" title="Eight-Nation Alliance">Eight-Nation Alliance</a> forces during the <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Rebellion" title="Boxer Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a> in China; on 7 September 1901, a <a href="/wiki/Italian_concession_of_Tientsin" title="Italian concession of Tientsin">concession in Tientsin</a> was ceded to the country, and on 7 June 1902, the concession was taken into Italian possession and administered by a <a href="/wiki/Consul_(representative)" title="Consul (representative)">consul</a>. In 1913, male universal suffrage was adopted. The pre-war period dominated by <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Giolitti" title="Giovanni Giolitti">Giovanni Giolitti</a>, Prime Minister five times between 1892 and 1921, was characterized by the economic, industrial and political-cultural modernization of Italian society. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Vittoriano_Altare_della_Patria_2013-09-16.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Vittoriano_Altare_della_Patria_2013-09-16.jpg/260px-Vittoriano_Altare_della_Patria_2013-09-16.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Vittoriano_Altare_della_Patria_2013-09-16.jpg/390px-Vittoriano_Altare_della_Patria_2013-09-16.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Vittoriano_Altare_della_Patria_2013-09-16.jpg/520px-Vittoriano_Altare_della_Patria_2013-09-16.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4086" data-file-height="2299"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Vittoriano_Altare_della_Patria_2013-09-16.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_II_Monument" title="Victor Emmanuel II Monument">Victor Emmanuel II Monument</a> in Rome, a national symbol of Italy celebrating the first king of the unified country, and resting place of the <a href="/wiki/Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier_(Italy)" title="Tomb of the Unknown Soldier (Italy)">Italian Unknown Soldier</a> since the end of World War I
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy entered into the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">First World War</a> in 1915 with the aim of completing national unity: for this reason, the Italian intervention in the First World War is also considered the <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Italian_War_of_Independence" class="mw-redirect" title="Fourth Italian War of Independence">Fourth Italian War of Independence</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> in a historiographical perspective that identifies in the latter the conclusion of the <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Unification of Italy">unification of Italy</a>, whose military actions began during the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1848" title="Revolutions of 1848">revolutions of 1848</a> with the <a href="/wiki/First_Italian_War_of_Independence" title="First Italian War of Independence">First Italian War of Independence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-110">[110]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy, nominally allied with the <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Empire</a> and the Empire of <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Alliance_(1882)" title="Triple Alliance (1882)">Triple Alliance</a>, in 1915 joined the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allies</a> into World War I with a <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1915)" title="Treaty of London (1915)">promise</a> of substantial territorial gains, that included western <a href="/wiki/Inner_Carniola" title="Inner Carniola">Inner Carniola</a>, former <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Littoral" title="Austrian Littoral">Austrian Littoral</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a> as well as parts of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. The country gave a fundamental contribution to the victory of the conflict as one of the "<a href="/wiki/The_Big_Four_(World_War_I)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Big Four (World War I)">Big Four</a>" top Allied powers. The war on the <a href="/wiki/Italian_front_(World_War_I)" title="Italian front (World War I)">Italian Front</a> was initially inconclusive, as the Italian army got stuck in a long <a href="/wiki/Trench_warfare" title="Trench warfare">attrition war</a> in the Alps, making little progress and suffering very heavy losses. However, the reorganization of the army and the conscription of the so-called '<i>99 Boys</i> (<i>Ragazzi del '99</i>, all males born in 1899 who were turning 18) led to more effective Italian victories in major battles, such as on <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_Monte_Grappa" title="First Battle of Monte Grappa">Monte Grappa</a> and in a series of battles on the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Monte_Grappa" title="Battle of Monte Grappa">Piave river</a>. Eventually, in October 1918, the Italians launched a massive offensive, culminating in the victory of <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vittorio_Veneto" title="Battle of Vittorio Veneto">Vittorio Veneto</a>. The Italian victory,<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> which was announced by the <i><a href="/wiki/Bollettino_della_Vittoria" title="Bollettino della Vittoria">Bollettino della Vittoria</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Bollettino_della_Vittoria_Navale" title="Bollettino della Vittoria Navale">Bollettino della Vittoria Navale</a></i>, marked the end of the war on the Italian Front, secured the dissolution of the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Austro-Hungarian Empire">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a> and was chiefly instrumental in <a href="/wiki/Armistice_with_Germany" class="mw-redirect" title="Armistice with Germany">ending</a> the First World War less than two weeks later. Italian armed forces were also involved in the <a href="/wiki/African_theatre_of_World_War_I" title="African theatre of World War I">African theatre</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Balkans_Campaign_(World_War_I)" class="mw-redirect" title="Balkans Campaign (World War I)">Balkan theatre</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Eastern_theatre_of_World_War_I" title="Middle Eastern theatre of World War I">Middle Eastern theatre</a> and then took part in the <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Constantinople" title="Occupation of Constantinople">Occupation of Constantinople</a>. </p>
      <p>During the war, more than 650,000 Italian soldiers and as many civilians died<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> and the kingdom went to the brink of bankruptcy. The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Saint-Germain-en-Laye_(1919)" title="Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye (1919)">Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye</a> (1919) and the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rapallo_(1920)" title="Treaty of Rapallo (1920)">Treaty of Rapallo</a> (1920) allowed the annexation of <a href="/wiki/Trentino-Alto_Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol" title="Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol">Trentino Alto-Adige</a>, <a href="/wiki/Julian_March" title="Julian March">Julian March</a>, <a href="/wiki/Istria" title="Istria">Istria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kvarner_Gulf" title="Kvarner Gulf">Kvarner</a> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">Dalmatian</a> city of <a href="/wiki/Zadar" title="Zadar">Zara</a>. The subsequent <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome_(1924)" title="Treaty of Rome (1924)">Treaty of Rome</a> (1924) led to the annexation of the city of <a href="/wiki/Fiume" class="mw-redirect" title="Fiume">Fiume</a> to Italy. Italy did not receive other territories promised by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1915)" title="Treaty of London (1915)">Treaty of London (1915)</a>, so this outcome was denounced as a "<a href="/wiki/Mutilated_victory" title="Mutilated victory">Mutilated victory</a>". The rhetoric of "Mutilated victory" was adopted by <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a> and led to the <a href="/wiki/Fascist_Italy_(1922%E2%80%931943)" title="Fascist Italy (1922–1943)">rise of</a> <a href="/wiki/Italian_fascism" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian fascism">Italian fascism</a>, becoming a key point in the <a href="/wiki/Propaganda_of_Fascist_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Propaganda of Fascist Italy">propaganda of Fascist Italy</a>. Historians regard "Mutilated victory" as a "political myth", used by fascists to fuel <a href="/wiki/Italian_imperialism" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian imperialism">Italian imperialism</a> and obscure the successes of <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Liberal Italy">liberal Italy</a> in the aftermath of World War I.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> Italy also gained a permanent seat in the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>'s executive council. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fascist_regime">Fascist regime</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Italian_Fascism" title="Italian Fascism">Italian Fascism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fascist_Italy_(1922%E2%80%931943)" title="Fascist Italy (1922–1943)">Fascist Italy (1922–1943)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_irredentism" title="Italian irredentism">Italian irredentism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Italy_during_World_War_II" title="Military history of Italy during World War II">Military history of Italy during World War II</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Italian_Civil_War" title="Italian Civil War">Italian Civil War</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Duce_Benito_Mussolini.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Duce_Benito_Mussolini.jpg/170px-Duce_Benito_Mussolini.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="216" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Duce_Benito_Mussolini.jpg/255px-Duce_Benito_Mussolini.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Duce_Benito_Mussolini.jpg/340px-Duce_Benito_Mussolini.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3660" data-file-height="4646"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Duce_Benito_Mussolini.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Duce" title="Duce">Duce</a> of <a href="/wiki/Fascist_Italy_(1922%E2%80%931943)" title="Fascist Italy (1922–1943)">Fascist Italy</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Biennio_Rosso" title="Biennio Rosso">socialist agitations</a> that followed the devastation of the Great War, inspired by the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a>, led to counter-revolution and repression throughout Italy. The liberal establishment, fearing a Soviet-style revolution, started to endorse the small <a href="/wiki/National_Fascist_Party" title="National Fascist Party">National Fascist Party</a>, led by <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a>. In October 1922 the <a href="/wiki/Blackshirts" title="Blackshirts">Blackshirts</a> of the National Fascist Party attempted a <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">coup</a> named the "<a href="/wiki/March_on_Rome" title="March on Rome">March on Rome</a>" which failed but at the last minute, King <a href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III" class="mw-redirect" title="Victor Emmanuel III">Victor Emmanuel III</a> refused to proclaim a state of siege and appointed Mussolini prime minister. Over the next few years, Mussolini banned all political parties and curtailed personal liberties, thus forming a <a href="/wiki/Totalitarianism" title="Totalitarianism">dictatorship</a>. These actions attracted international attention and eventually inspired similar dictatorships such as <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> and <a href="/wiki/Francoist_Spain" title="Francoist Spain">Francoist Spain</a>. </p>
      <p>Italian Fascism is based upon Italian nationalism and in particular seeks to complete what it considers as the incomplete project of <i><a href="/wiki/Risorgimento" class="mw-redirect" title="Risorgimento">Risorgimento</a></i> by incorporating <i><a href="/wiki/Italian_irredentism" title="Italian irredentism">Italia Irredenta</a></i> (unredeemed Italy) into the state of Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1922_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1922-117">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-118">[118]</a></sup> To the east of Italy, the Fascists claimed that <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a> was a land of Italian culture whose Italians, including those of Italianized <a href="/wiki/South_Slavs" title="South Slavs">South Slavic</a> descent, had been driven out of Dalmatia and into exile in Italy, and supported the return of Italians of Dalmatian heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> Mussolini identified Dalmatia as having strong Italian cultural roots for centuries via the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Republic of Venice</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-120">[120]</a></sup> To the west of Italy, the Fascists claimed that the territories of <a href="/wiki/Corsica" title="Corsica">Corsica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nice" title="Nice">Nice</a> and <a href="/wiki/Savoy" title="Savoy">Savoy</a> held by France were Italian lands.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> The Fascist regime produced literature on Corsica that presented evidence of the island's <i>italianità</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Davide_Rodogno_2006._P._88_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davide_Rodogno_2006._P._88-123">[123]</a></sup> The Fascist regime produced literature on Nice that justified that Nice was an Italian land based on historic, ethnic and linguistic grounds.<sup id="cite_ref-Davide_Rodogno_2006._P._88_123-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davide_Rodogno_2006._P._88-123">[123]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Italy%27s_colonial_empire.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Italy%27s_colonial_empire.png/200px-Italy%27s_colonial_empire.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="201" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Italy%27s_colonial_empire.png/300px-Italy%27s_colonial_empire.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Italy%27s_colonial_empire.png/400px-Italy%27s_colonial_empire.png 2x" data-file-width="802" data-file-height="807"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Italy%27s_colonial_empire.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Areas controlled by the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Empire" title="Italian Empire">Italian Empire</a> at its peak
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1935, Mussolini <a href="/wiki/Second_Italo-Abyssinian_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Second Italo-Abyssinian War">invaded Ethiopia</a> and founded the <a href="/wiki/Italian_East_Africa" title="Italian East Africa">Italian East Africa</a>, resulting in an international alienation and leading to Italy's withdrawal from the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>; Italy <a href="/wiki/Pact_of_Steel" title="Pact of Steel">allied with Nazi Germany</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tripartite_Pact" title="Tripartite Pact">Empire of Japan</a> and strongly supported <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Franco" title="Francisco Franco">Francisco Franco</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_civil_war" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish civil war">Spanish civil war</a>. In 1939, Italy <a href="/wiki/Italian_invasion_of_Albania" title="Italian invasion of Albania">annexed Albania</a>, a <i>de facto</i> protectorate for decades. Italy entered World War II on 10 June 1940. After initially advancing in <a href="/wiki/Italian_conquest_of_British_Somaliland" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian conquest of British Somaliland">British Somaliland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_invasion_of_Egypt" title="Italian invasion of Egypt">Egypt</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Campaign_(World_War_II)" class="mw-redirect" title="Balkan Campaign (World War II)">Balkans</a> and eastern fronts, the Italians were defeated in East Africa, <a href="/wiki/Italian_participation_in_the_Eastern_Front" title="Italian participation in the Eastern Front">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_Battle_of_El_Alamein" title="Second Battle of El Alamein">North Africa</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Villa_Giusti" title="Armistice of Villa Giusti">Armistice of Villa Giusti</a>, which ended fighting between Italy and Austria-Hungary at the end of World War I, resulted in Italian annexation of neighbouring parts of Yugoslavia. During the interwar period, the fascist Italian government undertook a campaign of <a href="/wiki/Italianization" title="Italianization">Italianisation</a> in the areas it annexed, which suppressed Slavic language, schools, political parties, and cultural institutions. During World War II, <a href="/wiki/Italian_war_crimes" title="Italian war crimes">Italian war crimes</a> included <a href="/wiki/Extrajudicial_killing" title="Extrajudicial killing">extrajudicial killings</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a><sup id="cite_ref-JamesBurgwyn_2004_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JamesBurgwyn_2004-124">[124]</a></sup> by deportation of about 25,000 people, mainly Jews, Croats, and Slovenians, to the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_concentration_camps" title="List of Italian concentration camps">Italian concentration camps</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Rab_concentration_camp" title="Rab concentration camp">Rab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gonars_concentration_camp" title="Gonars concentration camp">Gonars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monigo" class="mw-redirect" title="Monigo">Monigo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renicci_di_Anghiari" title="Renicci di Anghiari">Renicci di Anghiari</a> and elsewhere. In Italy and Yugoslavia, unlike in Germany, few war crimes were prosecuted.<sup id="cite_ref-RoryCarroll_2001_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RoryCarroll_2001-125">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Pedaliu_JContHistory_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pedaliu_JContHistory-126">[126]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-oliva06_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oliva06-127">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-blpp2004_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-blpp2004-128">[128]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisans" title="Yugoslav Partisans">Yugoslav Partisans</a> perpetrated their own crimes against the Italians during and after the war, including the <a href="/wiki/Foibe_massacres" title="Foibe massacres">foibe massacres</a>, which refers to mass killings against the local ethnic Italian population (<a href="/wiki/Istrian_Italians" title="Istrian Italians">Istrian Italians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dalmatian_Italians" title="Dalmatian Italians">Dalmatian Italians</a>), mainly in <a href="/wiki/Julian_March" title="Julian March">Julian March</a>, <a href="/wiki/Istria" title="Istria">Istria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kvarner" class="mw-redirect" title="Kvarner">Kvarner</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a>. The term refers to the victims who were often thrown alive into <i><a href="/wiki/Foiba" title="Foiba">foibas</a></i> (deep natural <a href="/wiki/Sinkhole" title="Sinkhole">sinkholes</a>; by extension, it also was applied to the use of mine shafts, etc. to hide the bodies). </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:01_partigiani_a_milano1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/01_partigiani_a_milano1.jpg/220px-01_partigiani_a_milano1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/01_partigiani_a_milano1.jpg/330px-01_partigiani_a_milano1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/01_partigiani_a_milano1.jpg/440px-01_partigiani_a_milano1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="501" data-file-height="347"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:01_partigiani_a_milano1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Italian_resistance_movement" title="Italian resistance movement">Italian partisans</a> in Milan, April 1945
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>An <a href="/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_Sicily" title="Allied invasion of Sicily">Allied invasion of Sicily</a> began in July 1943, leading to the collapse of the Fascist regime and the fall of Mussolini on <a href="/wiki/25_Luglio" class="mw-redirect" title="25 Luglio">25 July</a>. Mussolini was deposed and arrested by order of King Victor Emmanuel III in co-operation with the majority of the members of the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Council_of_Fascism" title="Grand Council of Fascism">Grand Council of Fascism</a>, which passed a motion of no confidence. On 8 September, Italy signed the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Cassibile" title="Armistice of Cassibile">Armistice of Cassibile</a>, ending its war with the Allies. The Germans helped by the Italian fascists shortly succeeded in taking control of northern and central Italy. The country remained a <a href="/wiki/Italian_Campaign_(World_War_II)" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Campaign (World War II)">battlefield</a> for the rest of the war, as the Allies were slowly moving up from the south. </p>
      <p>In the north, the Germans set up the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Social_Republic" title="Italian Social Republic">Italian Social Republic</a> (RSI), a Nazi <a href="/wiki/Puppet_state" title="Puppet state">puppet state</a> with Mussolini installed as leader after he was <a href="/wiki/Gran_Sasso_raid" title="Gran Sasso raid">rescued</a> by German paratroopers. Some Italian troops in the south were organized into the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Co-belligerent_Army" title="Italian Co-belligerent Army">Italian Co-belligerent Army</a>, which fought alongside the Allies for the rest of the war, while other Italian troops, loyal to Mussolini and his RSI, continued to fight alongside the Germans in the <a href="/wiki/National_Republican_Army" title="National Republican Army">National Republican Army</a>. As result, the country descended into <a href="/wiki/Italian_Civil_War" title="Italian Civil War">civil war</a>. Also, the post-armistice period saw the rise of a large anti-fascist resistance movement, the <i><a href="/wiki/Resistenza" class="mw-redirect" title="Resistenza">Resistenza</a></i>, which fought a guerilla war against the German and RSI forces. In late April 1945, with total defeat looming, Mussolini attempted to escape north,<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> but was captured and <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Benito_Mussolini" title="Death of Benito Mussolini">summarily executed</a> near <a href="/wiki/Lake_Como" title="Lake Como">Lake Como</a> by Italian partisans. His body was then taken to <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">Milan</a>, where it was hung upside down at a service station for public viewing and to provide confirmation of his demise.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> Hostilities ended on 29 April 1945, when the German forces in Italy surrendered. <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">Nearly half a million Italians (including civilians) died</a> in the conflict,<sup id="cite_ref-britannica.com_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica.com-131">[131]</a></sup> and the Italian economy had been all but destroyed; per capita income in 1944 was at its lowest point since the beginning of the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Republican_Italy">Republican Italy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Italian_Republic" title="History of the Italian Republic">History of the Italian Republic</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg/170px-Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="226" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg/255px-Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg/340px-Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="506" data-file-height="672"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Alcide_de_Gasperi_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Alcide_De_Gasperi" title="Alcide De Gasperi">Alcide De Gasperi</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Prime Ministers of Italy">first</a> republican <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Italy" title="Prime Minister of Italy">Prime Minister of Italy</a> and one of the <a href="/wiki/Founding_fathers_of_the_European_Union" title="Founding fathers of the European Union">Founding Fathers of the European Union</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy became a republic after a <a href="/wiki/Italian_constitutional_referendum,_1946" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian constitutional referendum, 1946">referendum</a><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> held on 2 June 1946, a day celebrated since as <a href="/wiki/Republic_Day_(Italy)" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic Day (Italy)">Republic Day</a>. This was also the first time that Italian women were entitled to vote.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III" class="mw-redirect" title="Victor Emmanuel III">Victor Emmanuel III</a>'s son, <a href="/wiki/Umberto_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Umberto II">Umberto II</a>, was forced to abdicate and exiled. The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy" title="Constitution of Italy">Republican Constitution</a> was approved on 1 January 1948. Under the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Peace_with_Italy,_1947" title="Treaty of Peace with Italy, 1947">Treaty of Peace with Italy, 1947</a>, <a href="/wiki/Istria" title="Istria">Istria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kvarner_Gulf" title="Kvarner Gulf">Kvarner</a>, most of the <a href="/wiki/Julian_March" title="Julian March">Julian March</a> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">Dalmatian</a> city of <a href="/wiki/Zadar" title="Zadar">Zara</a> was annexed by <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a> causing the <a href="/wiki/Istrian-Dalmatian_exodus" title="Istrian-Dalmatian exodus">Istrian-Dalmatian exodus</a>, which led to the emigration of between 230,000 and 350,000 of local ethnic Italians (<a href="/wiki/Istrian_Italians" title="Istrian Italians">Istrian Italians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dalmatian_Italians" title="Dalmatian Italians">Dalmatian Italians</a>), the others being ethnic Slovenians, ethnic Croatians, and ethnic <a href="/wiki/Istro-Romanians" title="Istro-Romanians">Istro-Romanians</a>, choosing to maintain Italian citizenship.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> Later, the <a href="/wiki/Free_Territory_of_Trieste" title="Free Territory of Trieste">Free Territory of Trieste</a> was divided between the two states. Italy also lost all of its colonial possessions, formally ending the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Empire" title="Italian Empire">Italian Empire</a>. In 1950, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Somaliland" title="Italian Somaliland">Italian Somaliland</a> was made a <a href="/wiki/Trust_Territory_of_Somaliland" title="Trust Territory of Somaliland">United Nations Trust Territory</a> under Italian administration until 1 July 1960. The Italian border that applies today has existed since 1975, when <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">Trieste</a> was formally re-annexed to Italy. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A0%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%80.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/%D0%A0%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%80.jpg/220px-%D0%A0%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%80.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/%D0%A0%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%80.jpg/330px-%D0%A0%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%80.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/%D0%A0%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%80.jpg/440px-%D0%A0%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%80.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="519"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A0%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%80.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The signing ceremony of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome" title="Treaty of Rome">Treaty of Rome</a> on 25 March 1957, creating the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a>, forerunner of the present-day <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Fears of a possible Communist takeover (especially in the United States) proved crucial for the first universal suffrage electoral outcome on <a href="/wiki/Italian_general_election,_1948" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian general election, 1948">18 April 1948</a>, when the <a href="/wiki/Christian_Democracy_(Italy)" title="Christian Democracy (Italy)">Christian Democrats</a>, under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Alcide_De_Gasperi" title="Alcide De Gasperi">Alcide De Gasperi</a>, obtained a landslide victory.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> Consequently, in 1949 Italy became a member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a> helped to revive the Italian economy which, until the late 1960s, enjoyed a period of sustained economic growth commonly called the "<a href="/wiki/Italian_economic_miracle" title="Italian economic miracle">Economic Miracle</a>". In 1957, Italy was a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC), which became the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU) in 1993. </p>
      <p>From the late 1960s until the early 1980s, the country experienced the <a href="/wiki/Years_of_Lead_(Italy)" title="Years of Lead (Italy)">Years of Lead</a>, a period characterised by economic crisis (especially after the <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">1973 oil crisis</a>), widespread social conflicts and terrorist massacres carried out by opposing extremist groups, with the alleged involvement of US and Soviet intelligence.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Docs_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Docs-139">[139]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> The Years of Lead culminated in the assassination of the Christian Democrat leader <a href="/wiki/Aldo_Moro" title="Aldo Moro">Aldo Moro</a> in 1978 and the <a href="/wiki/Bologna_massacre" title="Bologna massacre">Bologna railway station massacre</a> in 1980, where 85 people died. </p>
      <p>In the 1980s, for the first time since 1945, two governments were led by non-Christian-Democrat premiers: one republican (<a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Spadolini" title="Giovanni Spadolini">Giovanni Spadolini</a>) and one socialist (<a href="/wiki/Bettino_Craxi" title="Bettino Craxi">Bettino Craxi</a>); the Christian Democrats remained, however, the main government party. During Craxi's government, the economy recovered and Italy became the world's fifth-largest industrial nation after it gained the entry into the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven" title="Group of Seven">Group of Seven</a> in the 1970s. However, as a result of his spending policies, the Italian national debt skyrocketed during the Craxi era, soon passing 100% of the country's GDP. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Strage_di_bologna_funerali_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Strage_di_bologna_funerali_1.jpg/220px-Strage_di_bologna_funerali_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="142" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Strage_di_bologna_funerali_1.jpg/330px-Strage_di_bologna_funerali_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/85/Strage_di_bologna_funerali_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="259"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Strage_di_bologna_funerali_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Funerals of the victims of the <a href="/wiki/Bologna_massacre" title="Bologna massacre">Bologna bombing</a> of 2 August 1980, the deadliest attack ever perpetrated in Italy during the <a href="/wiki/Years_of_Lead_(Italy)" title="Years of Lead (Italy)">Years of Lead</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy faced several terror attacks between 1992 and 1993 perpetrated by the <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_Mafia" title="Sicilian Mafia">Sicilian Mafia</a> as a consequence of several life sentences pronounced during the "<a href="/wiki/Maxi_Trial" title="Maxi Trial">Maxi Trial</a>", and of the new anti-mafia measures launched by the government. In 1992, two major dynamite attacks killed the judges <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Falcone" title="Giovanni Falcone">Giovanni Falcone</a> (23 May in the <a href="/wiki/Capaci_bombing" title="Capaci bombing">Capaci bombing</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Paolo_Borsellino" title="Paolo Borsellino">Paolo Borsellino</a> (19 July in the <a href="/wiki/Via_D%27Amelio_bombing" title="Via D'Amelio bombing">Via D'Amelio bombing</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> One year later (May–July 1993), tourist spots were attacked, such as the <a href="/wiki/Via_dei_Georgofili_bombing" title="Via dei Georgofili bombing">Via dei Georgofili</a> in Florence, <a href="/wiki/Via_Palestro_massacre" title="Via Palestro massacre">Via Palestro</a> in Milan, and the Piazza <a href="/wiki/San_Giovanni_in_Laterano" class="mw-redirect" title="San Giovanni in Laterano">San Giovanni in Laterano</a> and Via San Teodoro in Rome, leaving 10 dead and 93 injured and causing severe damage to cultural heritage such as the <a href="/wiki/Uffizi_Gallery" class="mw-redirect" title="Uffizi Gallery">Uffizi Gallery</a>. The Catholic Church openly condemned the Mafia, and two churches were bombed and an anti-Mafia priest shot dead in Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-Dickie2007p416_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dickie2007p416-142">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> Also in the early 1990s, Italy faced significant challenges, as voters – disenchanted with political paralysis, massive public debt and the extensive corruption system (known as <i><a href="/wiki/Tangentopoli" class="mw-redirect" title="Tangentopoli">Tangentopoli</a></i>) uncovered by the <a href="/wiki/Mani_pulite" title="Mani pulite">Clean Hands</a> (<i>Mani Pulite</i>) investigation – demanded radical reforms. The scandals involved all major parties, but especially those in the government coalition: the Christian Democrats, who ruled for almost 50 years, underwent a severe crisis and eventually disbanded, splitting up into several factions.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> The Communists reorganised as a <a href="/wiki/Social-democratic" class="mw-redirect" title="Social-democratic">social-democratic</a> force. During the 1990s and the 2000s, <a href="/wiki/Centre-right_coalition" title="Centre-right coalition">centre-right</a> (dominated by media magnate <a href="/wiki/Silvio_Berlusconi" title="Silvio Berlusconi">Silvio Berlusconi</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Centre-left_coalition" title="Centre-left coalition">centre-left</a> coalitions (led by university professor <a href="/wiki/Romano_Prodi" title="Romano Prodi">Romano Prodi</a>) alternately governed the country. </p>
      <p>Amidst the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a>, Berlusconi <a href="/wiki/Resignation_of_Silvio_Berlusconi" class="mw-redirect" title="Resignation of Silvio Berlusconi">resigned</a> in 2011, and his conservative government was replaced by the technocratic cabinet of <a href="/wiki/Mario_Monti" title="Mario Monti">Mario Monti</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Italian_general_election,_2013" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian general election, 2013">2013 general election</a>, the Vice-Secretary of the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Italy)" title="Democratic Party (Italy)">Democratic Party</a> <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Letta" title="Enrico Letta">Enrico Letta</a> formed a <a href="/wiki/Letta_Cabinet" title="Letta Cabinet">new government</a> at the head of a right-left <a href="/wiki/Grand_coalition_(Italy)" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand coalition (Italy)">Grand coalition</a>. In 2014, challenged by the new <a href="/wiki/List_of_Secretaries_of_the_Democratic_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Secretaries of the Democratic Party">Secretary</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Partito_Democratico" class="mw-redirect" title="Partito Democratico">PD</a> <a href="/wiki/Matteo_Renzi" title="Matteo Renzi">Matteo Renzi</a>, Letta resigned and was replaced by Renzi. The new government started important constitutional reforms such as the abolition of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Senate" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Senate">Senate</a> and a new electoral law. On 4 December the constitutional reform was rejected in a <a href="/wiki/Italian_constitutional_referendum,_2016" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian constitutional referendum, 2016">referendum</a> and Renzi resigned; the Foreign Affairs Minister <a href="/wiki/Paolo_Gentiloni" title="Paolo Gentiloni">Paolo Gentiloni</a> was appointed new Prime Minister.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the <a href="/wiki/European_migrant_crisis" title="European migrant crisis">European migrant crisis</a> of the 2010s, Italy was the entry point and leading destination for most asylum seekers entering the EU. From 2013 to 2018, the country took in over 700,000 migrants and refugees,<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> mainly from sub-Saharan Africa,<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> which caused great strain on the public purse and a surge in the support for far-right or eurosceptic political parties.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Italian_general_election,_2018" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian general election, 2018">2018 general election</a> was characterized by a strong showing of the <a href="/wiki/Five_Star_Movement" title="Five Star Movement">Five Star Movement</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Lega_Nord" title="Lega Nord">League</a> and the university professor <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Conte" title="Giuseppe Conte">Giuseppe Conte</a> became the Prime Minister at the head of a <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Change" class="mw-redirect" title="Government of Change">populist coalition</a> between these two parties.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> However, after only fourteen months the League withdrew its support to Conte, who formed a new unprecedented government coalition between the Five Star Movement and the centre-left.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2020_coronavirus_task_force.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/2020_coronavirus_task_force.jpg/220px-2020_coronavirus_task_force.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/2020_coronavirus_task_force.jpg/330px-2020_coronavirus_task_force.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/2020_coronavirus_task_force.jpg/440px-2020_coronavirus_task_force.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1700" data-file-height="1133"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2020_coronavirus_task_force.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Italian government task force to face the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Italy" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Italy">COVID-19 emergency</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2020, Italy was severely hit by the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Italy" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Italy">COVID-19 pandemic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> From March to May, Conte's government imposed a <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_lockdown_in_Italy" title="COVID-19 lockdown in Italy">national lockdown</a> as a measure to limit the spread of the disease,<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> while further restrictions were introduced during the following winter.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> The measures, despite being widely approved by the public opinion,<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> were also described as the largest suppression of <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_right" title="Constitutional right">constitutional rights</a> in the history of the republic.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> With more than 115,000 confirmed victims, Italy was one of the countries with the highest total number of deaths in the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">worldwide coronavirus pandemic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> The pandemic caused also a <a href="/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic" title="Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic">severe economic disruption</a>, in which Italy resulted as one of the most affected countries.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In February 2021, after a <a href="/wiki/2021_Italian_government_crisis" title="2021 Italian government crisis">government crisis</a> within his majority, Conte was forced to resign and <a href="/wiki/Mario_Draghi" title="Mario Draghi">Mario Draghi</a>, former president of the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a>, formed a <a href="/wiki/Draghi_Cabinet" title="Draghi Cabinet">national unity government</a> supported by almost all the main parties,<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> pledging to oversee implementation of economic stimulus to face the crisis caused by the pandemic.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Italy" title="Geography of Italy">Geography of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg/220px-Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="271" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg/330px-Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg/440px-Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1759" data-file-height="2167"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Italy_topographic_map-blank.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Topographic map of Italy
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy is located in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">Southern Europe</a> (it is also considered a part of <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">western Europe</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-DGACM_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DGACM-19">[19]</a></sup> between latitudes <a href="/wiki/35th_parallel_north" title="35th parallel north">35°</a> and <a href="/wiki/47th_parallel_north" title="47th parallel north">47° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/6th_meridian_east" title="6th meridian east">6°</a> and <a href="/wiki/19th_meridian_east" title="19th meridian east">19° E</a>. To the north, Italy borders <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a> and is roughly delimited by the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alpine watershed</a>, enclosing the <a href="/wiki/Po_Valley" title="Po Valley">Po Valley</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Venetian_Plain" title="Venetian Plain">Venetian Plain</a>. To the south, it consists of the entirety of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">Italian Peninsula</a> and the two <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean islands">Mediterranean islands</a> of <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">Sicily</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sardinia" title="Sardinia">Sardinia</a> (the two <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_islands#By_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean islands">biggest islands</a> of the Mediterranean), in addition to many smaller islands. The sovereign states of <a href="/wiki/San_Marino" title="San Marino">San Marino</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a> are <a href="/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave" title="Enclave and exclave">enclaves</a> within Italy,<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Campione_d%27Italia" title="Campione d'Italia">Campione d'Italia</a> is an Italian <a href="/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave" title="Enclave and exclave">exclave</a> in Switzerland.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The country's total area is 301,230 square kilometres (116,306&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), of which 294,020&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (113,522&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) is land and 7,210&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (2,784&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) is water.<sup id="cite_ref-Area_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Area-169">[169]</a></sup> Including the islands, Italy has a coastline and border of 7,600 kilometres (4,722 miles) on the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Sea" title="Ionian Sea">Ionian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tyrrhenian_Sea" title="Tyrrhenian Sea">Tyrrhenian</a> seas (740&nbsp;km (460&nbsp;mi)), and borders shared with France (488&nbsp;km (303&nbsp;mi)), Austria (430&nbsp;km (267&nbsp;mi)), Slovenia (232&nbsp;km (144&nbsp;mi)) and Switzerland (740&nbsp;km (460&nbsp;mi)). San Marino (39&nbsp;km (24&nbsp;mi)) and Vatican City (3.2&nbsp;km (2.0&nbsp;mi)), both enclaves, account for the remainder.<sup id="cite_ref-Area_169-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Area-169">[169]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:229px;max-width:229px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
