           <a href="/wiki/File:MontBlancFromENE.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/MontBlancFromENE.jpg/225px-MontBlancFromENE.jpg" decoding="async" width="225" height="169" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/MontBlancFromENE.jpg/338px-MontBlancFromENE.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/MontBlancFromENE.jpg/450px-MontBlancFromENE.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3738" data-file-height="2804"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Mont_Blanc" title="Mont Blanc">Mont Blanc</a> (Monte Bianco) in <a href="/wiki/Aosta_Valley" title="Aosta Valley">Aosta Valley</a>, the highest point in the European Union
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Valmenocchia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Valmenocchia.jpg/225px-Valmenocchia.jpg" decoding="async" width="225" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Valmenocchia.jpg/338px-Valmenocchia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Valmenocchia.jpg/450px-Valmenocchia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4752" data-file-height="3168"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Appennine" class="mw-redirect" title="Appennine">Appennine</a> landscape in <a href="/wiki/Marche" title="Marche">Marche</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Over 35% of the Italian territory is mountainous.<sup id="cite_ref-eug92_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eug92-170">[170]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Apennine_Mountains" title="Apennine Mountains">Apennine Mountains</a> form the peninsula's backbone, and the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a> form most of its northern boundary, where Italy's highest point is located on <a href="/wiki/Mont_Blanc" title="Mont Blanc">Mont Blanc</a> (Monte Bianco) (4,810&nbsp;m or 15,780&nbsp;ft).<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[note 1]</a></sup> Other worldwide-known mountains in Italy include the <a href="/wiki/Matterhorn" title="Matterhorn">Matterhorn</a> (Monte Cervino), <a href="/wiki/Monte_Rosa" title="Monte Rosa">Monte Rosa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gran_Paradiso" title="Gran Paradiso">Gran Paradiso</a> in the West Alps, and <a href="/wiki/Bernina_Range" title="Bernina Range">Bernina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stelvio_Pass" title="Stelvio Pass">Stelvio</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dolomites" title="Dolomites">Dolomites</a> along the eastern side. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Po_river" class="mw-redirect" title="Po river">Po</a>, Italy's longest river (652 kilometres or 405 miles), flows from the Alps on the western border with France and crosses the <a href="/wiki/Padan_plain" class="mw-redirect" title="Padan plain">Padan plain</a> on its way to the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic Sea</a>. The Po Valley is the largest plain in Italy, with 46,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (18,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), and it represents over 70% of the total plain area in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-eug92_170-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eug92-170">[170]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Many elements of the Italian territory are of volcanic origin. Most of the small islands and archipelagos in the south, like <a href="/wiki/Capraia" title="Capraia">Capraia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ponza" title="Ponza">Ponza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ischia" title="Ischia">Ischia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eolie" class="mw-redirect" title="Eolie">Eolie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ustica" title="Ustica">Ustica</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pantelleria" title="Pantelleria">Pantelleria</a> are <a href="/wiki/Volcanic_island" class="mw-redirect" title="Volcanic island">volcanic islands</a>. There are also active volcanoes: <a href="/wiki/Mount_Etna" title="Mount Etna">Mount Etna</a> in Sicily (the largest active volcano in Europe), <a href="/wiki/Vulcano" title="Vulcano">Vulcano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stromboli" title="Stromboli">Stromboli</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vesuvius" class="mw-redirect" title="Vesuvius">Vesuvius</a> (the only active volcano on mainland Europe). </p>
      <p>The five largest lakes are, in order of diminishing size:<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[171]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lake_Garda" title="Lake Garda">Garda</a> (367.94&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> or 142&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), <a href="/wiki/Lake_Maggiore" title="Lake Maggiore">Maggiore</a> (212.51&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> or 82&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi, whose minor northern part is Switzerland), <a href="/wiki/Lake_Como" title="Lake Como">Como</a> (145.9&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> or 56&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), <a href="/wiki/Trasimeno_Lake" class="mw-redirect" title="Trasimeno Lake">Trasimeno</a> (124.29&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> or 48&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Bolsena" title="Lake Bolsena">Bolsena</a> (113.55&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> or 44&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi). </p>
      <p>Although the country includes the Italian peninsula, adjacent islands, and most of the southern Alpine basin, some of Italy's territory extends beyond the Alpine basin and some islands are located outside the <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">Eurasian</a> continental shelf. These territories are the <i>comuni</i> of: <a href="/wiki/Livigno" title="Livigno">Livigno</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sexten" title="Sexten">Sexten</a>, <a href="/wiki/Innichen" title="Innichen">Innichen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toblach" title="Toblach">Toblach</a> (in part), <a href="/wiki/Chiusaforte" title="Chiusaforte">Chiusaforte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tarvisio" title="Tarvisio">Tarvisio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Graun_im_Vinschgau" title="Graun im Vinschgau">Graun im Vinschgau</a> (in part), which are all part of the <a href="/wiki/Danube#Drainage_basin" title="Danube">Danube's drainage basin</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/Lago_di_Lei" title="Lago di Lei">Val di Lei</a> constitutes part of the <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">Rhine</a>'s basin and the islands of <a href="/wiki/Lampedusa" title="Lampedusa">Lampedusa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lampione" title="Lampione">Lampione</a> are on the African <a href="/wiki/Continental_shelf" title="Continental shelf">continental shelf</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Waters">Waters</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_Italy" title="List of rivers of Italy">List of rivers of Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_of_Italy" title="List of lakes of Italy">List of lakes of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:229px;max-width:229px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Vernazza_and_the_sea,_Cinque_Terre,_Italy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Vernazza_and_the_sea%2C_Cinque_Terre%2C_Italy.jpg/225px-Vernazza_and_the_sea%2C_Cinque_Terre%2C_Italy.jpg" decoding="async" width="225" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Vernazza_and_the_sea%2C_Cinque_Terre%2C_Italy.jpg/338px-Vernazza_and_the_sea%2C_Cinque_Terre%2C_Italy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Vernazza_and_the_sea%2C_Cinque_Terre%2C_Italy.jpg/450px-Vernazza_and_the_sea%2C_Cinque_Terre%2C_Italy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <i><a href="/wiki/Cinque_Terre" title="Cinque Terre">Cinque Terre</a></i> on the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Riviera" title="Italian Riviera">Italian Riviera</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Decollo_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Decollo_-_panoramio.jpg/225px-Decollo_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="225" height="148" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Decollo_-_panoramio.jpg/338px-Decollo_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Decollo_-_panoramio.jpg/450px-Decollo_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4179" data-file-height="2751"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Flamingos in the delta of the <a href="/wiki/Po_(river)" title="Po (river)">Po river</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Four different seas surround the Italian Peninsula in the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> from three sides: the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic Sea</a> in the east,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECushman-RoisinGačićPoulain20011–2_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECushman-RoisinGačićPoulain20011–2-173">[172]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Sea" title="Ionian Sea">Ionian Sea</a> in the south,<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[173]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Ligurian_Sea" title="Ligurian Sea">Ligurian Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tyrrhenian_Sea" title="Tyrrhenian Sea">Tyrrhenian Sea</a> in the west.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[174]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Including islands, Italy has a coastline of 7,900&nbsp;km.<sup id="cite_ref-Mit06441_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mit06441-176">[175]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SantateresaRipascimenti_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SantateresaRipascimenti-178">[177]</a></sup> Italian coasts include the <a href="/wiki/Amalfi_Coast" title="Amalfi Coast">Amalfi Coast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cilentan_Coast" title="Cilentan Coast">Cilentan Coast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coast_of_the_Gods" title="Coast of the Gods">Coast of the Gods</a>, <a href="/wiki/Costa_Verde_(Sardinia)" title="Costa Verde (Sardinia)">Costa Verde</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riviera_delle_Palme_(Marche)" title="Riviera delle Palme (Marche)">Riviera delle Palme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riviera_del_Brenta" title="Riviera del Brenta">Riviera del Brenta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Costa_Smeralda" title="Costa Smeralda">Costa Smeralda</a> and <a href="/wiki/Trabocchi_Coast" title="Trabocchi Coast">Trabocchi Coast</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Riviera" title="Italian Riviera">Italian Riviera</a> includes nearly all of the coastline of Liguria, extending from the border with France near <a href="/wiki/Ventimiglia,_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Ventimiglia, Italy">Ventimiglia</a> eastwards to Capo Corvo, which marks the eastern end of the Gulf of <a href="/wiki/La_Spezia" title="La Spezia">La Spezia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[178]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[179]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Apennines run along the entire length of the peninsula, dividing the waters into two opposite sides. On the other hand, the rivers are numerous due to the relative abundance of rains and to the presence of the Alpine chain in northern Italy with snowfields and glaciers. The fundamental watershed follows the ridge of the Alps and the Apennines and delimits five main slopes, corresponding to the seas into which the rivers flow: the Adriatic, Ionic, Tyrrhenian, Ligurian and Mediterranean sides.<sup id="cite_ref-Londrillo_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Londrillo-181">[180]</a></sup> Taking into consideration their origin, the Italian rivers can be divided into two main groups: the Alpine-Po rivers and the Apennine-island rivers.<sup id="cite_ref-Londrillo_181-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Londrillo-181">[180]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Most of the <a href="/wiki/Rivers_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Rivers of Italy">rivers of Italy</a> drain either into the Adriatic Sea, such as the <a href="/wiki/Po_(river)" title="Po (river)">Po</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piave_(river)" title="Piave (river)">Piave</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adige" title="Adige">Adige</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brenta_(river)" title="Brenta (river)">Brenta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tagliamento" title="Tagliamento">Tagliamento</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Reno_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Reno River">Reno</a>, or into the Tyrrhenian, like the <a href="/wiki/Arno" title="Arno">Arno</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tiber" title="Tiber">Tiber</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volturno" title="Volturno">Volturno</a>. The waters from some border municipalities (<a href="/wiki/Livigno" title="Livigno">Livigno</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lombardy" title="Lombardy">Lombardy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Innichen" title="Innichen">Innichen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sexten" title="Sexten">Sexten</a> in <a href="/wiki/Trentino-Alto_Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol" title="Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol">Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol</a>) drain into the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> through the basin of the <a href="/wiki/Drava" title="Drava">Drava</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Tributary" title="Tributary">tributary</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a>, and the waters from the <a href="/wiki/Lago_di_Lei" title="Lago di Lei">Lago di Lei</a> in Lombardy drain into the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> through the basin of the <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">Rhine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[181]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Delfini_tra_panarea_e_stromboli_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Delfini_tra_panarea_e_stromboli_2.jpg/220px-Delfini_tra_panarea_e_stromboli_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Delfini_tra_panarea_e_stromboli_2.jpg/330px-Delfini_tra_panarea_e_stromboli_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Delfini_tra_panarea_e_stromboli_2.jpg/440px-Delfini_tra_panarea_e_stromboli_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2256" data-file-height="1504"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Delfini_tra_panarea_e_stromboli_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Dolphins in the <a href="/wiki/Tyrrhenian_Sea" title="Tyrrhenian Sea">Tyrrhenian Sea</a> off the <a href="/wiki/Aeolian_Islands" title="Aeolian Islands">Aeolian Islands</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The longest Italian river is Po, which flows either 652&nbsp;km (405&nbsp;mi) or 682&nbsp;km (424&nbsp;mi) (considering the length of the right bank tributary <a href="/wiki/Maira_(river)" title="Maira (river)">Maira</a>) and whose headwaters are a spring seeping from a stony hillside at Pian del Re, a flat place at the head of the <a href="/wiki/Val_Po" class="mw-redirect" title="Val Po">Val Po</a> under the northwest face of <a href="/wiki/Monviso" class="mw-redirect" title="Monviso">Monviso</a>. The vast valley around the Po is called <a href="/wiki/Po_Valley" title="Po Valley">Po Valley</a> (Italian: <i>Pianura Padana</i> or <i>Val Padana</i>) the main industrial area of the country; in 2002, more than 16 million people lived there, at the time nearly ⅓ of the population of Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-NG2002_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NG2002-183">[182]</a></sup> The second longest Italian river is Adige, which originates near <a href="/wiki/Lake_Resia" class="mw-redirect" title="Lake Resia">Lake Resia</a> and flows into the Adriatic Sea, after having made a north–south route, near <a href="/wiki/Chioggia" title="Chioggia">Chioggia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[183]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the north of the country are a number of large subalpine moraine-dammed lakes, commonly referred to as the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Lakes" title="Italian Lakes">Italian Lakes</a>. There are more than 1000 lakes in Italy,<sup id="cite_ref-Londrillo26_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Londrillo26-185">[184]</a></sup> the largest of which is <a href="/wiki/Lake_Garda" title="Lake Garda">Garda</a> (370&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> or 143&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi). Other well-known subalpine lakes are <a href="/wiki/Lake_Maggiore" title="Lake Maggiore">Lake Maggiore</a> (212.5&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> or 82&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), whose most northerly section is part of Switzerland, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Como" title="Lake Como">Como</a> (146&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> or 56&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_by_depth" title="List of lakes by depth">deepest lakes</a> in Europe, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Orta" title="Lake Orta">Orta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Lugano" title="Lake Lugano">Lugano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Iseo" title="Lake Iseo">Iseo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Idro" title="Lake Idro">Idro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[185]</a></sup> Other notable lakes in the Italian peninsula are <a href="/wiki/Trasimeno" class="mw-redirect" title="Trasimeno">Trasimeno</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Bolsena" title="Lake Bolsena">Bolsena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Bracciano" title="Lake Bracciano">Bracciano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Vico" title="Lake Vico">Vico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lago_di_Varano" title="Lago di Varano">Varano</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Lesina" title="Lake Lesina">Lesina</a> in <a href="/wiki/Gargano" title="Gargano">Gargano</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Omodeo" title="Lake Omodeo">Omodeo</a> in Sardinia.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[186]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Along the Italian coasts there are lagoons, including the <a href="/wiki/Lagoon_of_Venice" class="mw-redirect" title="Lagoon of Venice">Venice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grado_Lagoon" class="mw-redirect" title="Grado Lagoon">Grado Lagoon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marano_Lagoon" title="Marano Lagoon">Marano</a> lagoons in northern Adriatic, and the <a href="/wiki/Orbetello" title="Orbetello">Orbetello</a> lagoon on the Tuscan coast. The swamps and ponds that in the past covered vast flat areas of Italy, have largely been dried up in recent centuries;<sup id="cite_ref-Londrillo26_185-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Londrillo26-185">[184]</a></sup> the few remaining wetlands, such as the <a href="/wiki/Comacchio" title="Comacchio">Comacchio</a> Valleys in Emilia-Romagna or the <a href="/wiki/Stagno_di_Cagliari" title="Stagno di Cagliari">Stagno di Cagliari</a> in Sardinia, are protected natural environments.<sup id="cite_ref-Londrillo26_185-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Londrillo26-185">[184]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Volcanology">Volcanology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Volcanology_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Volcanology of Italy">Volcanology of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:229px;max-width:229px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Mt_Etna_and_Catania1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Mt_Etna_and_Catania1.jpg/225px-Mt_Etna_and_Catania1.jpg" decoding="async" width="225" height="92" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Mt_Etna_and_Catania1.jpg/338px-Mt_Etna_and_Catania1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Mt_Etna_and_Catania1.jpg/450px-Mt_Etna_and_Catania1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="1225"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Mount_Etna" title="Mount Etna">Mount Etna</a>, one of the world's most active volcanoes
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Vesuvio_landscape.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Vesuvio_landscape.jpg/225px-Vesuvio_landscape.jpg" decoding="async" width="225" height="50" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Vesuvio_landscape.jpg/338px-Vesuvio_landscape.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Vesuvio_landscape.jpg/450px-Vesuvio_landscape.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2043" data-file-height="454"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Mount_Vesuvius" title="Mount Vesuvius">Mount Vesuvius</a>, one of the world's most densely-populated volcanoes
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The country is situated at the meeting point of the Eurasian Plate and the African Plate, leading to considerable <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_Italy" title="List of earthquakes in Italy">seismic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volcanism_in_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Volcanism in Italy">volcanic activity</a>. There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_Italy" title="List of volcanoes in Italy">14 volcanoes in Italy</a>, four of which are active: <a href="/wiki/Mount_Etna" title="Mount Etna">Etna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stromboli" title="Stromboli">Stromboli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vulcano" title="Vulcano">Vulcano</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vesuvius" class="mw-redirect" title="Vesuvius">Vesuvius</a>. The last is the only active volcano in mainland Europe and is most famous for the destruction of <a href="/wiki/Pompeii" title="Pompeii">Pompeii</a> and <a href="/wiki/Herculanum" class="mw-redirect" title="Herculanum">Herculanum</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Eruption_of_Mount_Vesuvius_in_79" class="mw-redirect" title="Eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79">eruption in 79 AD</a>. Several islands and hills have been created by volcanic activity, and there is still a large active <a href="/wiki/Caldera" title="Caldera">caldera</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Campi_Flegrei" class="mw-redirect" title="Campi Flegrei">Campi Flegrei</a> north-west of Naples. </p>
      <p>The high volcanic and magmatic neogenic activity is subdivided into provinces: </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>Magmatic Tuscan (<a href="/wiki/Monti_Cimini" title="Monti Cimini">Monti Cimini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tolfa" title="Tolfa">Tolfa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amiata" class="mw-redirect" title="Amiata">Amiata</a>);<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Scro_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scro-189">[188]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>Magmatic Latium (<a href="/wiki/Monti_Volsini" title="Monti Volsini">Monti Volsini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vico_nel_Lazio" title="Vico nel Lazio">Vico nel Lazio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colli_Albani" class="mw-redirect" title="Colli Albani">Colli Albani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roccamonfina" title="Roccamonfina">Roccamonfina</a>);<sup id="cite_ref-Scro_189-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scro-189">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-alexstrekeisen_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alexstrekeisen-190">[189]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>Ultra-alkaline Umbrian Latium District (<a href="/wiki/San_Venanzo" title="San Venanzo">San Venanzo</a>, Cupaello and <a href="/wiki/Polino" title="Polino">Polino</a>);<sup id="cite_ref-Scro_189-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scro-189">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-alexstrekeisen_190-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alexstrekeisen-190">[189]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>Volcanic bell (Vesuvius, <a href="/wiki/Campi_Flegrei" class="mw-redirect" title="Campi Flegrei">Campi Flegrei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ischia" title="Ischia">Ischia</a>);<sup id="cite_ref-Scro_189-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scro-189">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-alexstrekeisen_190-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alexstrekeisen-190">[189]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>Windy arch and Tyrrhenian basin (<a href="/wiki/Aeolian_Islands" title="Aeolian Islands">Aeolian Islands</a> and Tyrrhenian <a href="/wiki/Seamounts" class="mw-redirect" title="Seamounts">seamounts</a>);<sup id="cite_ref-Scro_189-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scro-189">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-alexstrekeisen_190-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alexstrekeisen-190">[189]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>African-Adriatic Avampa (<a href="/wiki/Channel_of_Sicily" class="mw-redirect" title="Channel of Sicily">Channel of Sicily</a>, <a href="/wiki/Graham_Island_(Mediterranean_Sea)" title="Graham Island (Mediterranean Sea)">Graham Island</a>, Etna and <a href="/wiki/Mount_Vulture" class="mw-redirect" title="Mount Vulture">Mount Vulture</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Scro_189-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scro-189">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-alexstrekeisen_190-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alexstrekeisen-190">[189]</a></sup></li>
      </ul> 
      <p>Italy was the first country to exploit geothermal energy to produce electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-UNMIG_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNMIG-191">[190]</a></sup> The high geothermal gradient that forms part of the peninsula makes potentially exploitable also other provinces: research carried out in the 1960s and 1970s identifies potential geothermal fields in Lazio and Tuscany, as well as in most volcanic islands.<sup id="cite_ref-UNMIG_191-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNMIG-191">[190]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Italy" title="List of national parks of Italy">List of national parks of Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_regional_parks_of_Italy" title="List of regional parks of Italy">List of regional parks of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Italy_natural_parks.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Italy_natural_parks.png/170px-Italy_natural_parks.png" decoding="async" width="170" height="208" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Italy_natural_parks.png/255px-Italy_natural_parks.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a1/Italy_natural_parks.png 2x" data-file-width="270" data-file-height="330"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Italy_natural_parks.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>National and regional parks in Italy
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After its quick industrial growth, Italy took a long time to confront its environmental problems. After several improvements, it now ranks 84th in the world for ecological sustainability.<sup id="cite_ref-dev.prenhall_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dev.prenhall-192">[191]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">National parks</a> cover about 5% of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[192]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the last decade, Italy has become one of the world's leading producers of <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Italy" title="Renewable energy in Italy">renewable energy</a>, ranking as the world's fourth largest holder of installed <a href="/wiki/Solar_energy" title="Solar energy">solar energy</a> capacity<sup id="cite_ref-REN21_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-REN21-194">[193]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BaroPhoto2010_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BaroPhoto2010-195">[194]</a></sup> and the sixth largest holder of <a href="/wiki/Wind_power" title="Wind power">wind power</a> capacity in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-wwea_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wwea-196">[195]</a></sup> Renewable energies now make up about 12% of the total primary and final energy consumption in Italy, with a future target share set at 17% for the year 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[196]</a></sup> However, air pollution remains a severe problem, especially in the industrialised north, reaching the tenth highest level worldwide of industrial carbon dioxide emissions in the 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-Encyclopedia_of_the_Nations_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopedia_of_the_Nations-198">[197]</a></sup> Italy is the twelfth largest <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> producer.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[199]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Extensive traffic and congestion in the largest metropolitan areas continue to cause severe environmental and health issues, even if smog levels have decreased dramatically since the 1970s and 1980s, and the presence of smog is becoming an increasingly rarer phenomenon and levels of <a href="/wiki/Sulphur_dioxide" class="mw-redirect" title="Sulphur dioxide">sulphur dioxide</a> are decreasing.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[200]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bergtocht_van_Gimillan_(1805m.)_naar_Colle_Tsa_S%C3%A8tse_in_Cogne_Valley_(Itali%C3%AB)._Zicht_op_de_omringende_alpentoppen_van_Gran_Paradiso_06.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bergtocht_van_Gimillan_%281805m.%29_naar_Colle_Tsa_S%C3%A8tse_in_Cogne_Valley_%28Itali%C3%AB%29._Zicht_op_de_omringende_alpentoppen_van_Gran_Paradiso_06.jpg/240px-Bergtocht_van_Gimillan_%281805m.%29_naar_Colle_Tsa_S%C3%A8tse_in_Cogne_Valley_%28Itali%C3%AB%29._Zicht_op_de_omringende_alpentoppen_van_Gran_Paradiso_06.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="125" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bergtocht_van_Gimillan_%281805m.%29_naar_Colle_Tsa_S%C3%A8tse_in_Cogne_Valley_%28Itali%C3%AB%29._Zicht_op_de_omringende_alpentoppen_van_Gran_Paradiso_06.jpg/360px-Bergtocht_van_Gimillan_%281805m.%29_naar_Colle_Tsa_S%C3%A8tse_in_Cogne_Valley_%28Itali%C3%AB%29._Zicht_op_de_omringende_alpentoppen_van_Gran_Paradiso_06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bergtocht_van_Gimillan_%281805m.%29_naar_Colle_Tsa_S%C3%A8tse_in_Cogne_Valley_%28Itali%C3%AB%29._Zicht_op_de_omringende_alpentoppen_van_Gran_Paradiso_06.jpg/480px-Bergtocht_van_Gimillan_%281805m.%29_naar_Colle_Tsa_S%C3%A8tse_in_Cogne_Valley_%28Itali%C3%AB%29._Zicht_op_de_omringende_alpentoppen_van_Gran_Paradiso_06.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="2701"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bergtocht_van_Gimillan_(1805m.)_naar_Colle_Tsa_S%C3%A8tse_in_Cogne_Valley_(Itali%C3%AB)._Zicht_op_de_omringende_alpentoppen_van_Gran_Paradiso_06.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Gran_Paradiso_National_Park" title="Gran Paradiso National Park">Gran Paradiso</a>, established in 1922, is the oldest Italian national park.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Many watercourses and coastal stretches have also been contaminated by industrial and agricultural activity, while because of rising water levels, <a href="/wiki/Venice" title="Venice">Venice</a> has been regularly flooded throughout recent years. Waste from industrial activity is not always disposed of by legal means and has led to permanent health effects on inhabitants of affected areas, as in the case of the <a href="/wiki/Seveso_disaster" title="Seveso disaster">Seveso disaster</a>. The country has also operated several nuclear reactors between 1963 and 1990 but, after the <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl_disaster" title="Chernobyl disaster">Chernobyl disaster</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Italian_nuclear_power_referendum,_1987" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian nuclear power referendum, 1987">referendum on the issue</a> the nuclear programme was terminated, a decision that was overturned by the government in 2008, planning to build up to four nuclear power plants with French technology. This was in turn struck down by a referendum following the <a href="/wiki/Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster">Fukushima nuclear accident</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[201]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Deforestation, illegal building developments and poor land-management policies have led to significant erosion all over Italy's mountainous regions, leading to major ecological disasters like the 1963 <a href="/wiki/Vajont_Dam" title="Vajont Dam">Vajont Dam</a> flood, the 1998 <a href="/wiki/Sarno" title="Sarno">Sarno</a><sup id="cite_ref-Sicily_mudslide_leaves_scores_dead_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sicily_mudslide_leaves_scores_dead-203">[202]</a></sup> and 2009 <a href="/wiki/2009_Messina_floods_and_mudslides" title="2009 Messina floods and mudslides">Messina</a> <a href="/wiki/Mudslide" class="mw-redirect" title="Mudslide">mudslides</a>. The country had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 3.65/10, ranking it 142nd globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-204">[203]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Italy" title="Fauna of Italy">Fauna of Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Flora_of_Italy" title="Flora of Italy">Flora of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Wolf_at_Castello_Belfort.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Wolf_at_Castello_Belfort.jpg/220px-Wolf_at_Castello_Belfort.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Wolf_at_Castello_Belfort.jpg/330px-Wolf_at_Castello_Belfort.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Wolf_at_Castello_Belfort.jpg/440px-Wolf_at_Castello_Belfort.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4272" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Wolf_at_Castello_Belfort.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Italian_wolf" title="Italian wolf">Italian wolf</a>, which inhabits the Apennines and Western Alps, features prominently in Latin and Italian cultures, such as in the legend of the <a href="/wiki/Founding_of_Rome" title="Founding of Rome">founding of Rome</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[204]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy has the highest level of <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">faunal</a> <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a> in Europe, with over 57,000 species recorded, representing more than a third of all European fauna.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[205]</a></sup> Italy's varied geological structure contributes to its high climate and habitat diversity. The Italian peninsula is in the centre of the Mediterranean Sea, forming a corridor between central Europe and North Africa, and has 8,000&nbsp;km (5,000&nbsp;mi) of coastline. Italy also receives species from the Balkans, Eurasia, the Middle East. Italy's varied geological structure, including the Alps and the Apennines, Central Italian woodlands, and Southern Italian Garigue and Maquis shrubland, also contributes to high climate and habitat diversity. </p>
      <p>Italian fauna includes 4,777 <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemic</a> animal species, which include the <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_long-eared_bat" title="Sardinian long-eared bat">Sardinian long-eared bat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Corsican_red_deer" title="Corsican red deer">Sardinian red deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spectacled_salamander" title="Spectacled salamander">spectacled salamander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brown_cave_salamander" title="Brown cave salamander">brown cave salamander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_newt" title="Italian newt">Italian newt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_stream_frog" title="Italian stream frog">Italian frog</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apennine_yellow-bellied_toad" title="Apennine yellow-bellied toad">Apennine yellow-bellied toad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aeolian_wall_lizard" title="Aeolian wall lizard">Aeolian wall lizard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_wall_lizard" title="Sicilian wall lizard">Sicilian wall lizard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Aesculapian_snake" title="Italian Aesculapian snake">Italian Aesculapian snake</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_pond_turtle" title="Sicilian pond turtle">Sicilian pond turtle</a>. There are 102 <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Italy" title="List of mammals of Italy">mammals species</a> (most notably the <a href="/wiki/Italian_wolf" title="Italian wolf">Italian wolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marsican_brown_bear" title="Marsican brown bear">Marsican brown bear</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pyrenean_chamois" title="Pyrenean chamois">Pyrenean chamois</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alpine_ibex" title="Alpine ibex">Alpine ibex</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crested_porcupine" title="Crested porcupine">crested porcupine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_monk_seal" title="Mediterranean monk seal">Mediterranean monk seal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alpine_marmot" title="Alpine marmot">Alpine marmot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Etruscan_shrew" title="Etruscan shrew">Etruscan shrew</a>, and <a href="/wiki/European_snow_vole" title="European snow vole">European snow vole</a>), 516 <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Italy" title="List of birds of Italy">bird species</a> and 56,213 invertebrate species. </p>
      <p>The flora of Italy was traditionally estimated to comprise about 5,500 <a href="/wiki/Vascular_plant" title="Vascular plant">vascular plant</a> species.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[206]</a></sup> However, as of 2005<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Italy&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 6,759 species are recorded in the <i>Data bank of Italian vascular flora</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[207]</a></sup> Italy is a signatory to the <a href="/wiki/Berne_Convention_on_the_Conservation_of_European_Wildlife_and_Natural_Habitats" title="Berne Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats">Berne Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Habitats_Directive" title="Habitats Directive">Habitats Directive</a> both affording protection to Italian fauna and flora. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Italy" title="Climate of Italy">Climate of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_Italy" title="List of rivers of Italy">List of rivers of Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_of_Italy" title="List of lakes of Italy">List of lakes of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_ITA_present.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Koppen-Geiger_Map_ITA_present.svg/290px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_ITA_present.svg.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="181" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Koppen-Geiger_Map_ITA_present.svg/435px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_ITA_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Koppen-Geiger_Map_ITA_present.svg/580px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_ITA_present.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1364" data-file-height="850"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_ITA_present.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen-Geiger climate classification</a> map of Italy<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[208]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Because of the great longitudinal extension of the peninsula and the mostly mountainous internal conformation, the climate of Italy is highly diverse. In most of the inland northern and central regions, the climate ranges from <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical" class="mw-redirect" title="Humid subtropical">humid subtropical</a> to <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental" class="mw-redirect" title="Humid continental">humid continental</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic</a>. In particular, the climate of the <a href="/wiki/Po_valley" class="mw-redirect" title="Po valley">Po valley</a> geographical region is mostly continental, with harsh winters and hot summers.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[210]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The coastal areas of <a href="/wiki/Liguria" title="Liguria">Liguria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tuscany" title="Tuscany">Tuscany</a> and most of the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">South</a> generally fit the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> stereotype (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> Csa). Conditions on peninsular coastal areas can be very different from the interior's higher ground and valleys, particularly during the winter months when the higher altitudes tend to be cold, wet, and often snowy. The coastal regions have mild winters and warm and generally dry summers, although lowland valleys can be quite hot in summer. Average winter temperatures vary from 0&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">°C</a> (32&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">°F</a>) on the Alps to 12&nbsp;°C (54&nbsp;°F) in Sicily, so average summer temperatures range from 20&nbsp;°C (68&nbsp;°F) to over 25&nbsp;°C (77&nbsp;°F). Winters can vary widely across the country with lingering cold, foggy and snowy periods in the north and milder, sunnier conditions in the south. Summers can be hot and humid across the country, particularly in the south while northern and central areas can experience occasional strong thunderstorms from spring to autumn.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[211]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Italy" title="Politics of Italy">Politics of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy has been a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> since 2 June 1946, when the monarchy was abolished by a <a href="/wiki/Italian_constitutional_referendum,_1946" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian constitutional referendum, 1946">constitutional referendum</a>. The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Italy" title="President of Italy">President of Italy</a> (<i>Presidente della Repubblica</i>), currently <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Mattarella" title="Sergio Mattarella">Sergio Mattarella</a> since 2015, is Italy's <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>. The President is elected for a single seven years mandate by the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliament of Italy">Parliament of Italy</a> and some regional voters in <a href="/wiki/Joint_session" title="Joint session">joint session</a>. Italy has a written democratic <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy" title="Constitution of Italy">constitution</a>, resulting from the work of a <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_Italy" title="Constituent Assembly of Italy">Constituent Assembly</a> formed by the representatives of all the <a href="/wiki/Anti-fascist" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-fascist">anti-fascist</a> forces that contributed to the defeat of Nazi and Fascist forces during the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Civil_War" title="Italian Civil War">Civil War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[212]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:294px;max-width:294px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:145px;max-width:145px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Presidente_Mattarella.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Presidente_Mattarella.jpg/143px-Presidente_Mattarella.jpg" decoding="async" width="143" height="187" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Presidente_Mattarella.jpg/215px-Presidente_Mattarella.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Presidente_Mattarella.jpg/286px-Presidente_Mattarella.jpg 2x" data-file-width="490" data-file-height="640"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Mattarella" title="Sergio Mattarella">Sergio Mattarella</a>
           <br><small><a href="/wiki/President_of_Italy" title="President of Italy">President of Italy</a><br>since 2015</small>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:145px;max-width:145px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Mario_Draghi_2021_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Mario_Draghi_2021_cropped.jpg/143px-Mario_Draghi_2021_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="143" height="187" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Mario_Draghi_2021_cropped.jpg/215px-Mario_Draghi_2021_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Mario_Draghi_2021_cropped.jpg/286px-Mario_Draghi_2021_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1275" data-file-height="1663"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <a href="/wiki/Mario_Draghi" title="Mario Draghi">Mario Draghi</a>
           <br><small><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Italy" title="Prime Minister of Italy">Prime Minister of Italy</a><br>since 2021</small>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Italy" title="Government of Italy">Government of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy has a parliamentary government based on a mixed <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional</a> and majoritarian voting system. The parliament is perfectly <a href="/wiki/Bicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Bicameral">bicameral</a>: the two houses, the <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Chamber of Deputies of Italy">Chamber of Deputies</a> that meets in <a href="/wiki/Palazzo_Montecitorio" title="Palazzo Montecitorio">Palazzo Montecitorio</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Senate of Italy">Senate of the Republic</a> that meets in <a href="/wiki/Palazzo_Madama" title="Palazzo Madama">Palazzo Madama</a>, have the same powers. The Prime Minister, officially <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Council_of_Ministers_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="President of the Council of Ministers of Italy">President of the Council of Ministers</a> (<i>Presidente del Consiglio dei Ministri</i>), is Italy's <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>. The Prime Minister and the cabinet are appointed by the President of the Republic of Italy and must pass a vote of confidence in Parliament to come into office. To remain the Prime Minister has to pass also eventual further votes of confidence or no confidence in Parliament. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg/220px-Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg/330px-Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg/440px-Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="990" data-file-height="658"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Giuramento_Mattarella_Montecitorio.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Italy)" title="Chamber of Deputies (Italy)">Chamber of Deputies</a> is the lower house of Italy.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The prime minister is the President of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Council of Ministers of Italy">Council of Ministers</a>&nbsp;– which holds effective executive power&nbsp;– and he must receive a vote of approval from it to execute most political activities. The office is similar to those in most other <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary systems</a>, but the leader of the Italian government is not authorised to request the dissolution of the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliament of Italy">Parliament of Italy</a>. </p>
      <p>Another difference with similar offices is that the overall political responsibility for intelligence is vested in the President of the Council of Ministers. By virtue of that, the Prime Minister has exclusive power to: co-ordinate intelligence policies, determining the financial resources and strengthening national cyber security; apply and protect State secrets; authorise agents to carry out operations, in Italy or abroad, in violation of the law.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[213]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A peculiarity of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Parliament" title="Italian Parliament">Italian Parliament</a> is the representation given to <a href="/wiki/Italian_nationality_law" title="Italian nationality law">Italian citizens</a> permanently living abroad: 12 Deputies and 6 Senators elected in four distinct <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Italy#Overseas_constituency" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliament of Italy">overseas constituencies</a>. In addition, the Italian Senate is characterised also by a small number of <a href="/wiki/Senator_for_life" title="Senator for life">senators for life</a>, appointed by the President "for outstanding patriotic merits in the social, scientific, artistic or literary field". Former Presidents of the Republic are <i>ex officio</i> life senators. </p>
      <p>Italy's three major political parties are the <a href="/wiki/Five_Star_Movement" title="Five Star Movement">Five Star Movement</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Italy)" title="Democratic Party (Italy)">Democratic Party</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Lega_Nord" title="Lega Nord">Lega</a>. During the 2018 general election these three parties and their coalitions won 614 out of 630 seats available in the Chamber of Deputies and 309 out of 315 in the Senate.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[214]</a></sup> Berlusconi's <a href="/wiki/Forza_Italia_(2013)" title="Forza Italia (2013)">Forza Italia</a> which formed a centre-right coalition with <a href="/wiki/Matteo_Salvini" title="Matteo Salvini">Matteo Salvini</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Northern_League_(Italy)" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern League (Italy)">Northern League</a> and Giorgia Meloni's <a href="/wiki/Brothers_of_Italy" title="Brothers of Italy">Brothers of Italy</a> won most of the seats without getting the majority in parliament. The rest of the seats were taken by <a href="/wiki/Five_Star_Movement" title="Five Star Movement">Five Star Movement</a>, Matteo Renzi's <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Italy)" title="Democratic Party (Italy)">Democratic Party</a> along with Achammer and Panizza's <a href="/wiki/South_Tyrolean_People%27s_Party" title="South Tyrolean People's Party">South Tyrolean People's Party</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/Trentino_Tyrolean_Autonomist_Party" title="Trentino Tyrolean Autonomist Party">Trentino Tyrolean Autonomist Party</a> in a centre-left coalition and the independent <a href="/wiki/Free_and_Equal_(Italy)" title="Free and Equal (Italy)">Free and Equal</a> party. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_criminal_justice">Law and criminal justice</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Italy" title="Law of Italy">Law of Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Italy" title="Judiciary of Italy">Judiciary of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Courthouse_facade,_Rome,_Italy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Courthouse_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg/220px-Courthouse_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="115" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Courthouse_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg/330px-Courthouse_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Courthouse_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg/440px-Courthouse_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4350" data-file-height="2276"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Courthouse_facade,_Rome,_Italy.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Cassation_(Italy)" title="Supreme Court of Cassation (Italy)">Supreme Court of Cassation</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Italian judicial system is based on <a href="/wiki/Roman_law" title="Roman law">Roman law</a> modified by the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_code" class="mw-redirect" title="Napoleonic code">Napoleonic code</a> and later statutes. The <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Cassation_(Italy)" class="mw-redirect" title="Court of Cassation (Italy)">Supreme Court of Cassation</a> is the highest court in Italy for both criminal and civil appeal cases. The <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Italy" title="Constitutional Court of Italy">Constitutional Court of Italy</a> (<i>Corte Costituzionale</i>) rules on the conformity of laws with the constitution and is a post–World War II innovation. Since their appearance in the middle of the 19th century, <a href="/wiki/Organized_crime_in_Italy" title="Organized crime in Italy">Italian organised crime</a> and criminal organisations have infiltrated the social and economic life of many regions in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">Southern Italy</a>, the most notorious of which being the <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_Mafia" title="Sicilian Mafia">Sicilian Mafia</a>, which would later expand into some foreign countries including the United States. Mafia receipts may reach 9%<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[215]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup> of Italy's GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-218">[217]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A 2009 report identified 610 <a href="/wiki/Comune" title="Comune"><i lang="it" title="Italian-language text">comuni</i></a> which have a strong Mafia presence, where 13 million Italians live and 14.6% of the Italian GDP is produced.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[218]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[219]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Calabria" title="Calabria">Calabrian</a> <a href="/wiki/%27Ndrangheta" title="'Ndrangheta">'Ndrangheta</a>, nowadays probably the most powerful crime syndicate of Italy, accounts alone for 3% of the country's GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[220]</a></sup> However, at 0.013 per 1,000 people, Italy has only the 47th highest murder rate<sup id="cite_ref-NationMaster.com_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NationMaster.com-222">[221]</a></sup> compared to 61 countries and the 43rd highest number of rapes per 1,000 people compared to 64 countries in the world. These are relatively low figures among developed countries. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement">Law enforcement</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Italy" title="Law enforcement in Italy">Law enforcement in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Alfa-Romeo159-Carabinieri-di-Roma.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Alfa-Romeo159-Carabinieri-di-Roma.JPG/220px-Alfa-Romeo159-Carabinieri-di-Roma.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Alfa-Romeo159-Carabinieri-di-Roma.JPG/330px-Alfa-Romeo159-Carabinieri-di-Roma.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Alfa-Romeo159-Carabinieri-di-Roma.JPG/440px-Alfa-Romeo159-Carabinieri-di-Roma.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Alfa-Romeo159-Carabinieri-di-Roma.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>An <a href="/wiki/Alfa_Romeo_159" title="Alfa Romeo 159">Alfa Romeo 159</a> vehicle of the <a href="/wiki/Carabinieri" title="Carabinieri">Carabinieri</a> corps
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Italian law enforcement system is complex, with multiple police forces.<sup id="cite_ref-Walters_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walters-223">[222]</a></sup> The national policing agencies are the <a href="/wiki/Polizia_di_Stato" title="Polizia di Stato">Polizia di Stato</a> (State Police), the <a href="/wiki/Arma_dei_Carabinieri" class="mw-redirect" title="Arma dei Carabinieri">Arma dei Carabinieri</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Guardia_di_Finanza" title="Guardia di Finanza">Guardia di Finanza</a> (Financial Guard), and the Polizia Penitenziaria (Prison Police),<sup id="cite_ref-BuonannoMastrobuoni_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BuonannoMastrobuoni-224">[223]</a></sup> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Guardia_Costiera" class="mw-redirect" title="Guardia Costiera">Guardia Costiera</a> (<a href="/wiki/Water_police" title="Water police">coast guard police</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Walters_223-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walters-223">[222]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <i>Polizia di Stato</i> are a civil police supervised by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Italy)" title="Ministry of the Interior (Italy)">Interior Ministry</a>, while the <i>Carabinieri</i> is a <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie" title="Gendarmerie">gendarmerie</a> supervised by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Italy)" title="Ministry of Defence (Italy)">Defense Ministry</a>; both share duties in law enforcement and the maintenance of public order.<sup id="cite_ref-BuonannoMastrobuoni_224-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BuonannoMastrobuoni-224">[223]</a></sup> Within the Carabinieri is a unit devoted to combating <a href="/wiki/Environmental_crime" title="Environmental crime">environmental crime</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Walters_223-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walters-223">[222]</a></sup> The <i>Guardia di Finanza</i> is responsible for combating <a href="/wiki/Financial_crime" title="Financial crime">financial crime</a> and <a href="/wiki/White-collar_crime" title="White-collar crime">white-collar crime</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-BuonannoMastrobuoni_224-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BuonannoMastrobuoni-224">[223]</a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Customs" title="Customs">customs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Walters_223-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walters-223">[222]</a></sup> The <i>Polizia Penitenziaria</i> are responsible for guarding the prison system.<sup id="cite_ref-BuonannoMastrobuoni_224-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BuonannoMastrobuoni-224">[223]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Corpo_Forestale_dello_Stato" class="mw-redirect" title="Corpo Forestale dello Stato">Corpo Forestale dello Stato</a> (State Forestry Corps) formerly existed as a separate national <a href="/wiki/Park_ranger" title="Park ranger">park ranger</a> agency,<sup id="cite_ref-Walters_223-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walters-223">[222]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BuonannoMastrobuoni_224-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BuonannoMastrobuoni-224">[223]</a></sup> but was merged into the Carabinieri in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[224]</a></sup> Although policing in Italy is primarily provided on a national basis,<sup id="cite_ref-BuonannoMastrobuoni_224-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BuonannoMastrobuoni-224">[223]</a></sup> there also exists <i>Polizia Provinciale</i> (<a href="/wiki/Provincial_police" title="Provincial police">provincial police</a>) and <i>Polizia Municipale</i> (<a href="/wiki/Municipal_police_(Italy)" title="Municipal police (Italy)">municipal police</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Walters_223-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walters-223">[222]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Italy" title="Foreign relations of Italy">Foreign relations of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:G7_Taormina_family_photo_2017-05-26.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/G7_Taormina_family_photo_2017-05-26.jpg/220px-G7_Taormina_family_photo_2017-05-26.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/G7_Taormina_family_photo_2017-05-26.jpg/330px-G7_Taormina_family_photo_2017-05-26.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/G7_Taormina_family_photo_2017-05-26.jpg/440px-G7_Taormina_family_photo_2017-05-26.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:G7_Taormina_family_photo_2017-05-26.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Group photo of the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven" title="Group of Seven">G7</a> leaders at the <a href="/wiki/43rd_G7_summit" title="43rd G7 summit">43rd G7 summit</a> in <a href="/wiki/Taormina" title="Taormina">Taormina</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC), now the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU), and of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>. Italy was admitted to the United Nations in 1955, and it is a member and a strong supporter of a wide number of international organisations, such as the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD), the <a href="/wiki/General_Agreement_on_Tariffs_and_Trade" title="General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade">General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade</a>/<a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (GATT/WTO), the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a> (OSCE), the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Central_European_Initiative" title="Central European Initiative">Central European Initiative</a>. Its recent or upcoming turns in the rotating presidency of international organisations include the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a> in 2018, the <a href="/wiki/G7" class="mw-redirect" title="G7">G7</a> in 2017 and the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_the_Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Presidency of the Council of the European Union">EU Council</a> from July to December 2014. Italy is also a recurrent <a href="/wiki/List_of_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="List of members of the United Nations Security Council">non-permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="UN Security Council">UN Security Council</a>, the most recently in 2017. </p>
      <p>Italy strongly supports multilateral international politics, endorsing the United Nations and its <a href="/wiki/International_security" title="International security">international security</a> activities. As of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Italy&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Italy was deploying 5,296 troops abroad, engaged in 33 UN and NATO missions in 25 countries of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[225]</a></sup> Italy deployed troops in support of UN peacekeeping missions in <a href="/wiki/UNITAF" class="mw-redirect" title="UNITAF">Somalia</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Operation_in_Mozambique" title="United Nations Operation in Mozambique">Mozambique</a>, and <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Integrated_Mission_in_East_Timor" title="United Nations Integrated Mission in East Timor">East Timor</a> and provides support for NATO and UN operations in <a href="/wiki/IFOR" class="mw-redirect" title="IFOR">Bosnia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Force" title="Kosovo Force">Kosovo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Sunrise_(Albania)" class="mw-redirect" title="Operation Sunrise (Albania)">Albania</a>. Italy deployed over 2,000 troops in <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> in support of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Enduring_Freedom" title="Operation Enduring Freedom">Operation Enduring Freedom</a> (OEF) from February 2003. </p>
      <p>Italy supported international efforts to reconstruct and stabilise <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, but it had withdrawn its <a href="/wiki/Multi-National_Force_%E2%80%93_Iraq#2006_withdrawals" title="Multi-National Force – Iraq">military contingent</a> of some 3,200 troops by 2006, maintaining only humanitarian operators and other civilian personnel. In August 2006 Italy deployed about 2,450 troops in Lebanon for the United Nations' <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> mission <a href="/wiki/UNIFIL" class="mw-redirect" title="UNIFIL">UNIFIL</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NewsMax_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewsMax-227">[226]</a></sup> Italy is one of the largest financiers of the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority" title="Palestinian National Authority">Palestinian National Authority</a>, contributing €60 million in 2013 alone.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[227]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:342px;max-width:342px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:169px;max-width:169px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Cavour_(550).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cavour_%28550%29.jpg/167px-Cavour_%28550%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="167" height="111" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cavour_%28550%29.jpg/251px-Cavour_%28550%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cavour_%28550%29.jpg/334px-Cavour_%28550%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2176"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:169px;max-width:169px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ejercicio_Dissimilar_Air_Combat_Training_-_DACT_2017_-_Base_A%C3%A9rea_de_Gando_(32765109225).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ejercicio_Dissimilar_Air_Combat_Training_-_DACT_2017_-_Base_A%C3%A9rea_de_Gando_%2832765109225%29.jpg/167px-Ejercicio_Dissimilar_Air_Combat_Training_-_DACT_2017_-_Base_A%C3%A9rea_de_Gando_%2832765109225%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="167" height="111" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ejercicio_Dissimilar_Air_Combat_Training_-_DACT_2017_-_Base_A%C3%A9rea_de_Gando_%2832765109225%29.jpg/251px-Ejercicio_Dissimilar_Air_Combat_Training_-_DACT_2017_-_Base_A%C3%A9rea_de_Gando_%2832765109225%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ejercicio_Dissimilar_Air_Combat_Training_-_DACT_2017_-_Base_A%C3%A9rea_de_Gando_%2832765109225%29.jpg/334px-Ejercicio_Dissimilar_Air_Combat_Training_-_DACT_2017_-_Base_A%C3%A9rea_de_Gando_%2832765109225%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1067"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:169px;max-width:169px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Alpinis_on_exercise;_Italian_Army.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Alpinis_on_exercise%3B_Italian_Army.jpg/167px-Alpinis_on_exercise%3B_Italian_Army.jpg" decoding="async" width="167" height="105" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Alpinis_on_exercise%3B_Italian_Army.jpg/251px-Alpinis_on_exercise%3B_Italian_Army.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Alpinis_on_exercise%3B_Italian_Army.jpg/334px-Alpinis_on_exercise%3B_Italian_Army.jpg 2x" data-file-width="350" data-file-height="220"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:169px;max-width:169px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Blindo_centauro_deserto.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Blindo_centauro_deserto.jpg/167px-Blindo_centauro_deserto.jpg" decoding="async" width="167" height="111" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Blindo_centauro_deserto.jpg/251px-Blindo_centauro_deserto.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Blindo_centauro_deserto.jpg/334px-Blindo_centauro_deserto.jpg 2x" data-file-width="693" data-file-height="462"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          Examples of Italy's military. Clockwise from top left: aircraft carrier <a href="/wiki/Italian_aircraft_carrier_Cavour_(550)" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian aircraft carrier Cavour (550)"><i>MM Cavour</i></a>; two <a href="/wiki/Eurofighter_Typhoon" title="Eurofighter Typhoon">Eurofighter Typhoons</a> operated by the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Air_Force" title="Italian Air Force">Italian Air Force</a>; tank destroyer <a href="/wiki/B1_Centauro" title="B1 Centauro">B1 Centauro</a>; and <i><a href="/wiki/Alpini" title="Alpini">Alpini</a></i> from the <a href="/wiki/Alpine_Brigade_Taurinense" class="mw-redirect" title="Alpine Brigade Taurinense">Taurinense Brigade</a>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Italian_Armed_Forces" title="Italian Armed Forces">Italian Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Army" title="Italian Army">Italian Army</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Navy" title="Italian Navy">Navy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Air_Force" title="Italian Air Force">Air Force</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carabinieri" title="Carabinieri">Carabinieri</a> collectively form the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Armed_Forces" title="Italian Armed Forces">Italian Armed Forces</a>, under the command of the Supreme Defence Council, presided over by the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Italy" title="President of Italy">President of Italy</a>. Since 2005, military service is voluntary.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[228]</a></sup> In 2010, the Italian military had 293,202 personnel on active duty,<sup id="cite_ref-IISS_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IISS-230">[229]</a></sup> of which 114,778 are Carabinieri.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup> Total Italian military spending in 2010 ranked <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">tenth</a> in the world, standing at $35.8&nbsp;billion, equal to 1.7% of national GDP. As part of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_sharing" title="Nuclear sharing">NATO's nuclear sharing strategy</a> Italy also hosts 90 United States <a href="/wiki/B61_nuclear_bomb" title="B61 nuclear bomb">B61 nuclear bombs</a>, located in the <a href="/wiki/Ghedi_Air_Base" title="Ghedi Air Base">Ghedi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aviano_Air_Base" title="Aviano Air Base">Aviano</a> air bases.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[231]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Italian Army is the national ground defence force, numbering 109,703 in 2008. Its best-known combat vehicles are the <a href="/wiki/Dardo_IFV" title="Dardo IFV">Dardo</a> <a href="/wiki/Infantry_fighting_vehicle" title="Infantry fighting vehicle">infantry fighting vehicle</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Centauro" class="mw-redirect" title="Centauro">Centauro</a> <a href="/wiki/Tank_destroyer" title="Tank destroyer">tank destroyer</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ariete" title="Ariete">Ariete</a> <a href="/wiki/Tank" title="Tank">tank</a>, and among its aircraft the <a href="/wiki/Agusta_A129_Mangusta" title="Agusta A129 Mangusta">Mangusta</a> <a href="/wiki/Attack_helicopter" title="Attack helicopter">attack helicopter</a>, in the last years deployed in EU, NATO and UN missions. It also has at its disposal many <a href="/wiki/Leopard_1" title="Leopard 1">Leopard 1</a> and <a href="/wiki/M113_armored_personnel_carrier" title="M113 armored personnel carrier">M113</a> armoured vehicles. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Navy" title="Italian Navy">Italian Navy</a> in 2008 had 35,200 active personnel with 85 commissioned ships and 123 aircraft.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[232]</a></sup> It is a <a href="/wiki/Blue-water_navy" title="Blue-water navy">blue-water navy</a>. In modern times the Italian Navy, being a member of the EU and NATO, has taken part in many coalition peacekeeping operations around the world. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Air_Force" title="Italian Air Force">Italian Air Force</a> in 2008 had a strength of 43,882 and operated 585 aircraft, including 219 combat jets and 114 helicopters. A transport capability is guaranteed by a fleet of 27 <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_Martin_C-130J_Super_Hercules" title="Lockheed Martin C-130J Super Hercules">C-130Js</a> and <a href="/wiki/C-27J_Spartan" class="mw-redirect" title="C-27J Spartan">C-27J Spartan</a>. </p>
      <p>An autonomous corps of the military, the Carabinieri are the <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie" title="Gendarmerie">gendarmerie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Military_police" title="Military police">military police</a> of Italy, policing the military and civilian population alongside <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Italy" title="Law enforcement in Italy">Italy's other police forces</a>. While the different branches of the Carabinieri report to separate ministries for each of their individual functions, the corps reports to the Ministry of Internal Affairs when maintaining public order and security.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[233]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Constituent_entities"><span class="anchor" id="Administrative_divisions"></span> Constituent entities</span></h3> 
      <div class="floatright">
