       <a href="/wiki/File:Italian_provinces_no_regions.svg" class="image" title="Administrative regions of Italy"><img alt="Administrative regions of Italy" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Italian_provinces_no_regions.svg/450px-Italian_provinces_no_regions.svg.png" decoding="async" width="450" height="563" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Italian_provinces_no_regions.svg/675px-Italian_provinces_no_regions.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Italian_provinces_no_regions.svg/900px-Italian_provinces_no_regions.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1500"></a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Italy" title="Regions of Italy">Regions of Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Italy" title="Provinces of Italy">Provinces of Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_cities_of_Italy" title="Metropolitan cities of Italy">Metropolitan cities of Italy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Municipalities of Italy">Municipalities of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy is constituted by 20 regions (<i>regioni</i>)—five of these regions having a <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_regions_with_special_statute" class="mw-redirect" title="Autonomous regions with special statute">special autonomous status</a> that enables them to enact legislation on additional matters, 107 provinces (<i>province</i>) or metropolitan cities (<i>città metropolitane</i>), and 7,960 municipalities (<i>comuni</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[234]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:45%; float:left;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th>Region</th> 
         <th>Capital</th>

         <th>Population (January 2019)</th> 
         <th>Nominal GDP EURO billions (2016)<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[235]</a></sup></th> 
         <th>Nominal GDP EURO per capita(2016) <sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[236]</a></sup> </th>
        </tr>

      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Italy" title="Economy of Italy">Economy of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_Italian_companies" title="List of largest Italian companies">List of largest Italian companies</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Full_Milan_skyline_from_Duomo_roof.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Full_Milan_skyline_from_Duomo_roof.jpg/220px-Full_Milan_skyline_from_Duomo_roof.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="119" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Full_Milan_skyline_from_Duomo_roof.jpg/330px-Full_Milan_skyline_from_Duomo_roof.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Full_Milan_skyline_from_Duomo_roof.jpg/440px-Full_Milan_skyline_from_Duomo_roof.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6048" data-file-height="3264"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Full_Milan_skyline_from_Duomo_roof.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">Milan</a> is a global financial centre and a <a href="/wiki/Fashion_capital" title="Fashion capital">fashion capital</a> of the world.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy has a major advanced<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[237]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Capitalist" class="mw-redirect" title="Capitalist">capitalist</a> <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a>, ranking as the third-largest in the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">eighth-largest</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[238]</a></sup> A founding member of the <a href="/wiki/G7" class="mw-redirect" title="G7">G7</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> and the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>, it is regarded as one of the world's most industrialised nations and a leading country in <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">world trade and exports</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[241]</a></sup> It is a highly <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a>, with the world's 8th highest <a href="/wiki/Quality_of_life" title="Quality of life">quality of life</a> in 2005<sup id="cite_ref-economist.com_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist.com-33">[33]</a></sup> and the 26th <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>. The country is well known for its creative and innovative business,<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[242]</a></sup> a large and competitive agricultural sector<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup> (with the world's largest wine production),<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[244]</a></sup> and for its influential and high-quality automobile, machinery, food, design and fashion industry.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[245]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[246]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[247]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:193px;max-width:193px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:127px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ferrari_488_Pista_2_Genf_2018.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Ferrari_488_Pista_2_Genf_2018.jpg/191px-Ferrari_488_Pista_2_Genf_2018.jpg" decoding="async" width="191" height="128" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Ferrari_488_Pista_2_Genf_2018.jpg/287px-Ferrari_488_Pista_2_Genf_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Ferrari_488_Pista_2_Genf_2018.jpg/382px-Ferrari_488_Pista_2_Genf_2018.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4964" data-file-height="3318"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:195px;max-width:195px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:127px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:2014-03-04_Geneva_Motor_Show_1377.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/2014-03-04_Geneva_Motor_Show_1377.JPG/193px-2014-03-04_Geneva_Motor_Show_1377.JPG" decoding="async" width="193" height="128" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/2014-03-04_Geneva_Motor_Show_1377.JPG/290px-2014-03-04_Geneva_Motor_Show_1377.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/2014-03-04_Geneva_Motor_Show_1377.JPG/386px-2014-03-04_Geneva_Motor_Show_1377.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          A <a href="/wiki/Ferrari" title="Ferrari">Ferrari</a> <a href="/wiki/Ferrari_488_Pista" class="mw-redirect" title="Ferrari 488 Pista">488 Pista</a> <small>(left)</small> and a <a href="/wiki/Lamborghini" title="Lamborghini">Lamborghini</a> <a href="/wiki/Lamborghini_Hurac%C3%A1n" title="Lamborghini Huracán">Hurácan</a> <small>(right)</small>. Italy maintains a large <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Italy" title="Automotive industry in Italy">automotive industry</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[248]</a></sup> and is the world's seventh largest exporter of goods.<sup id="cite_ref-OECDtrade_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDtrade-250">[249]</a></sup>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy is the world's sixth largest <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">manufacturing</a> country,<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[250]</a></sup> characterised by a smaller number of global multinational corporations than other economies of comparable size and many dynamic <a href="/wiki/Small_and_medium-sized_enterprises" title="Small and medium-sized enterprises">small and medium-sized enterprises</a>, notoriously clustered in several <a href="/wiki/Industrial_district" title="Industrial district">industrial districts</a>, which are the backbone of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian industry">Italian industry</a>. This has produced a manufacturing sector often focused on the export of <a href="/wiki/Niche_market" title="Niche market">niche market</a> and luxury products, that if on one side is less capable to compete on the quantity, on the other side is more capable of facing the competition from China and other emerging Asian economies based on lower labour costs, with higher quality products.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[251]</a></sup> Italy was the world's 7th largest exporter in 2016. Its closest trade ties are with the other countries of the European Union, with whom it conducts about 59% of its total trade. Its largest EU trade partners, in order of market share, are Germany (12.9%), France (11.4%), and Spain (7.4%).<sup id="cite_ref-cia.gov_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-253">[252]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Eurozone.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/220px-Eurozone.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="223" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/330px-Eurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Eurozone.svg/440px-Eurozone.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="450" data-file-height="456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Eurozone.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Italy is part of a monetary union, the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> (dark blue) and of the <a href="/wiki/Internal_Market_(European_Union)" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal Market (European Union)">EU single market</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Italy" title="Automotive industry in Italy">automotive industry</a> is a significant part of the Italian manufacturing sector, with over 144,000 firms and almost 485,000 employed people in 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[253]</a></sup> and a contribution of 8.5% to Italian <a href="/wiki/GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="GDP">GDP</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-acea.thisconnect.com_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-acea.thisconnect.com-255">[254]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fiat_Chrysler_Automobiles" title="Fiat Chrysler Automobiles">Fiat Chrysler Automobiles</a> or FCA is currently the world's <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry#Top_vehicle_manufacturing_groups_by_volume" title="Automotive industry">seventh-largest auto maker</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[255]</a></sup> The country boasts a wide range of acclaimed products, from very compact city cars to luxury supercars such as <a href="/wiki/Maserati" title="Maserati">Maserati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lamborghini" title="Lamborghini">Lamborghini</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ferrari" title="Ferrari">Ferrari</a>, which was rated the world's most powerful brand by Brand Finance.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[256]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy is part of the European single market which represents more than 500 million consumers. Several domestic commercial policies are determined by agreements among European Union (EU) members and by EU legislation. Italy introduced the common European currency, the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">Euro</a> in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-euroc_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euroc-258">[257]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[258]</a></sup> It is a member of the Eurozone which represents around 330 million citizens. Its monetary policy is set by the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a>. </p>
      <p>Italy has been hit hard by the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%9308" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial crisis of 2007–08">Financial crisis of 2007–08</a>, that exacerbated the country's structural problems.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[259]</a></sup> Effectively, after a strong GDP growth of 5–6% per year from the 1950s to the early 1970s,<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[260]</a></sup> and a progressive slowdown in the 1980-90s, the country virtually stagnated in the 2000s.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[261]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[262]</a></sup> The political efforts to revive growth with massive government spending eventually produced a severe rise in <a href="/wiki/Public_debt" class="mw-redirect" title="Public debt">public debt</a>, that stood at over 131.8% of GDP in 2017,<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[263]</a></sup> ranking second in the EU only after the Greek one.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[264]</a></sup> For all that, the largest chunk of <a href="/wiki/Italian_government_debt" title="Italian government debt">Italian public debt</a> is owned by national subjects, a major difference between Italy and Greece,<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[265]</a></sup> and the level of <a href="/wiki/Household_debt" title="Household debt">household debt</a> is much lower than the OECD average.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A gaping <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Italy#North–South_divide" title="Economy of Italy">North–South divide</a> is a major factor of socio-economic weakness.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[267]</a></sup> It can be noted by the huge difference in statistical income between the northern and southern regions and municipalities.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[268]</a></sup> The richest province, <a href="/wiki/South_Tyrol" title="South Tyrol">Alto Adige-South Tyrol</a>, earns 152% of the national GDP per capita, while the poorest region, Calabria, 61%.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[269]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Unemployment" title="Unemployment">unemployment</a> rate (11.1%) stands slightly above the Eurozone average,<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[270]</a></sup> but the disaggregated figure is 6.6% in the North and 19.2% in the South.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[271]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Youth_unemployment_in_Italy" title="Youth unemployment in Italy">youth unemployment rate</a> (31.7% in March 2018) is extremely high compared to EU standards.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy has a strong <a href="/wiki/Cooperative" title="Cooperative">cooperative</a> sector, with the largest share of the population (4.5%) employed by a cooperative in the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[273]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Italy" title="Agriculture in Italy">Agriculture in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Val_D_Orcia_Sunrise_(151505625).jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Val_D_Orcia_Sunrise_%28151505625%29.jpeg/200px-Val_D_Orcia_Sunrise_%28151505625%29.jpeg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Val_D_Orcia_Sunrise_%28151505625%29.jpeg/300px-Val_D_Orcia_Sunrise_%28151505625%29.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Val_D_Orcia_Sunrise_%28151505625%29.jpeg/400px-Val_D_Orcia_Sunrise_%28151505625%29.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="1798" data-file-height="1200"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Vineyards_in_Piemonte,_Italy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Vineyards_in_Piemonte%2C_Italy.jpg/200px-Vineyards_in_Piemonte%2C_Italy.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Vineyards_in_Piemonte%2C_Italy.jpg/300px-Vineyards_in_Piemonte%2C_Italy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Vineyards_in_Piemonte%2C_Italy.jpg/400px-Vineyards_in_Piemonte%2C_Italy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2304"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <a href="/wiki/Val_d%27Orcia" title="Val d'Orcia">Val d'Orcia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tuscany" title="Tuscany">Tuscany</a> (left) and vineyards in <a href="/wiki/Vineyard_Landscape_of_Piedmont:_Langhe-Roero_and_Monferrato" title="Vineyard Landscape of Piedmont: Langhe-Roero and Monferrato">Langhe and Montferrat, Piedmont</a> (right). Italy is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_wine-producing_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="List of wine-producing countries">world's largest wine producer</a>.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the last national agricultural census, there were 1.6 million farms in 2010 (−32.4% since 2000) covering 12.7 million hectares (63% of which are located in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">Southern Italy</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-agrocensus_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agrocensus-275">[274]</a></sup> The vast majority (99%) are family-operated and small, averaging only 8 hectares in size.<sup id="cite_ref-agrocensus_275-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agrocensus-275">[274]</a></sup> Of the total surface area in agricultural use (forestry excluded), <a href="/wiki/Grain" title="Grain">grain</a> fields take up 31%, <a href="/wiki/Olive_tree" class="mw-redirect" title="Olive tree">olive tree</a> orchards 8.2%, <a href="/wiki/Vineyard" title="Vineyard">vineyards</a> 5.4%, <a href="/wiki/Citrus" title="Citrus">citrus</a> orchards 3.8%, <a href="/wiki/Sugar_beet" title="Sugar beet">sugar beets</a> 1.7%, and <a href="/wiki/Horticulture" title="Horticulture">horticulture</a> 2.4%. The remainder is primarily dedicated to pastures (25.9%) and feed grains (11.6%).<sup id="cite_ref-agrocensus_275-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agrocensus-275">[274]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_wine-producing_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="List of wine-producing countries">world's largest wine producer</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-OIVstats_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OIVstats-276">[275]</a></sup> and one of the leading in <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a>, fruits (<a href="/wiki/Apple" title="Apple">apples</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olive" title="Olive">olives</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grape" title="Grape">grapes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orange_(fruit)" title="Orange (fruit)">oranges</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lemon" title="Lemon">lemons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pear" title="Pear">pears</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apricot" title="Apricot">apricots</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hazelnut" title="Hazelnut">hazelnuts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peach" title="Peach">peaches</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cherry" title="Cherry">cherries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Plum" title="Plum">plums</a>, <a href="/wiki/Strawberry" title="Strawberry">strawberries</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kiwifruit" title="Kiwifruit">kiwifruits</a>), and vegetables (especially <a href="/wiki/Artichoke" title="Artichoke">artichokes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tomato" title="Tomato">tomatoes</a>). The most famous <a href="/wiki/Italian_wine" title="Italian wine">Italian wines</a> are probably the <a href="/wiki/Tuscany_(wine)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tuscany (wine)">Tuscan</a> <a href="/wiki/Chianti" title="Chianti">Chianti</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Piedmont_(wine)" class="mw-redirect" title="Piedmont (wine)">Piedmontese</a> <a href="/wiki/Barolo" title="Barolo">Barolo</a>. Other famous wines are <a href="/wiki/Barbaresco" title="Barbaresco">Barbaresco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barbera_d%27Asti" title="Barbera d'Asti">Barbera d'Asti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brunello_di_Montalcino" title="Brunello di Montalcino">Brunello di Montalcino</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frascati_DOC" title="Frascati DOC">Frascati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Montepulciano_d%27Abruzzo" title="Montepulciano d'Abruzzo">Montepulciano d'Abruzzo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Morellino_di_Scansano" title="Morellino di Scansano">Morellino di Scansano</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sparkling_wine" title="Sparkling wine">sparkling wines</a> <a href="/wiki/Franciacorta_DOCG" title="Franciacorta DOCG">Franciacorta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prosecco" title="Prosecco">Prosecco</a>. </p>
      <p>Quality goods in which Italy specialises, particularly the already mentioned wines and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_DOP_cheeses" title="List of Italian DOP cheeses">regional cheeses</a>, are often protected under the quality assurance labels <a href="/wiki/Denominazione_di_origine_controllata" title="Denominazione di origine controllata">DOC/DOP</a>. This <a href="/wiki/Geographical_indications_and_traditional_specialities_in_the_European_Union" title="Geographical indications and traditional specialities in the European Union">geographical indication certificate</a>, which is attributed by the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, is considered important in order to avoid confusion with low-quality mass-produced <a href="/wiki/Ersatz_good" title="Ersatz good">ersatz products</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Italy" title="Transport in Italy">Transport in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Railway_stations_in_Italy" title="Railway stations in Italy">Railway stations in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Elettrotreno_ETR.400.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Elettrotreno_ETR.400.jpg/220px-Elettrotreno_ETR.400.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Elettrotreno_ETR.400.jpg/330px-Elettrotreno_ETR.400.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Elettrotreno_ETR.400.jpg/440px-Elettrotreno_ETR.400.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4500" data-file-height="3102"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Elettrotreno_ETR.400.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ferrovie_dello_Stato_Italiane" title="Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane">FS</a>' <a href="/wiki/Frecciarossa_1000" title="Frecciarossa 1000">Frecciarossa 1000</a> high speed train, with a maximum speed of 400&nbsp;km/h (249&nbsp;mph),<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[276]</a></sup> is the fastest train in Europe.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:EI-EJI_FCO_(24869064081).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/EI-EJI_FCO_%2824869064081%29.jpg/220px-EI-EJI_FCO_%2824869064081%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/EI-EJI_FCO_%2824869064081%29.jpg/330px-EI-EJI_FCO_%2824869064081%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/EI-EJI_FCO_%2824869064081%29.jpg/440px-EI-EJI_FCO_%2824869064081%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:EI-EJI_FCO_(24869064081).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Alitalia" title="Alitalia">Alitalia</a> Airbus A330 at <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci%E2%80%93Fiumicino_Airport" title="Leonardo da Vinci–Fiumicino Airport">Leonardo da Vinci–Fiumicino Airport</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2004 the transport sector in Italy generated a turnover of about 119.4&nbsp;billion euros, employing 935,700 persons in 153,700 enterprises. Regarding the national road network, in 2002 there were 668,721&nbsp;km (415,524&nbsp;mi) of serviceable roads in Italy, including 6,487&nbsp;km (4,031&nbsp;mi) of motorways, state-owned but privately operated by <a href="/wiki/Atlantia_(company)" title="Atlantia (company)">Atlantia</a>. In 2005, about 34,667,000 <a href="/wiki/Automobile" class="mw-redirect" title="Automobile">passenger cars</a> (590 cars per 1,000 people) and 4,015,000 goods vehicles circulated on the national road network.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Commission_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Commission-278">[277]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Italy" title="Rail transport in Italy">national railway network</a>, state-owned and operated by <a href="/wiki/Ferrovie_dello_Stato" class="mw-redirect" title="Ferrovie dello Stato">Rete Ferroviaria Italiana</a> (FSI), in 2008 totalled 16,529&nbsp;km (10,271&nbsp;mi) of which 11,727&nbsp;km (7,287&nbsp;mi) is electrified, and on which 4,802 locomotives and railcars run. The main public operator of high-speed trains is <a href="/wiki/Trenitalia" title="Trenitalia">Trenitalia</a>, part of FSI. Higher-speed trains are divided into three categories: <a href="/wiki/Frecciarossa" title="Frecciarossa">Frecciarossa</a> (English: <span lang="en">red arrow</span>) trains operate at a maximum speed of 300&nbsp;km/h on dedicated high-speed tracks; <a href="/wiki/Frecciargento" title="Frecciargento">Frecciargento</a> (English: <span lang="en">silver arrow</span>) trains operate at a maximum speed of 250&nbsp;km/h on both high-speed and mainline tracks; and <a href="/wiki/Frecciabianca" title="Frecciabianca">Frecciabianca</a> (English: <span lang="en">white arrow</span>) trains operate on high-speed regional lines at a maximum speed of 200&nbsp;km/h. Italy has 11 rail border crossings over the Alpine mountains with its neighbouring countries. </p>
      <p>Italy is one of the countries with the most vehicles per capita, with 690 per 1000 people in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-Wards11_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wards11-279">[278]</a></sup> The national inland <a href="/wiki/Waterways" class="mw-redirect" title="Waterways">waterways</a> network comprised 2,400&nbsp;km (1,491&nbsp;mi) of navigable rivers and channels for various types of commercial traffic in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-cia1_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia1-280">[279]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy's largest airline is <a href="/wiki/Alitalia" title="Alitalia">Alitalia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[280]</a></sup> which serves 97 destinations (as of October 2019) and also operates a regional subsidiary under the <a href="/wiki/Alitalia_CityLiner" title="Alitalia CityLiner">Alitalia CityLiner</a> brand. The country also has <a href="/wiki/Regional_airline" title="Regional airline">regional airlines</a> (such as <a href="/wiki/Air_Dolomiti" title="Air Dolomiti">Air Dolomiti</a>), low-cost carriers, and Charter and leisure carriers (including <a href="/wiki/Neos_(airline)" title="Neos (airline)">Neos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blue_Panorama_Airlines" title="Blue Panorama Airlines">Blue Panorama Airlines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Poste_Air_Cargo" title="Poste Air Cargo">Poste Air Cargo</a>. Major Italian cargo operators are <a href="/wiki/Alitalia" title="Alitalia">Alitalia</a> Cargo and <a href="/wiki/Cargolux_Italia" title="Cargolux Italia">Cargolux Italia</a>. </p>
      <p>Italy is the fifth in Europe by number of passengers by air transport, with about 148 million passengers or about 10% of the European total in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup> In 2012 there were 130 airports in Italy, including the two <a href="/wiki/Airline_hub" title="Airline hub">hubs</a> of <a href="/wiki/Malpensa_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Malpensa International Airport">Malpensa International</a> in Milan and <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Leonardo da Vinci International Airport">Leonardo da Vinci International</a> in Rome. In 2004 there were 43 major seaports, including the seaport of <a href="/wiki/Genoa" title="Genoa">Genoa</a>, the country's largest and second largest in the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. In 2005 Italy maintained a civilian air fleet of about 389,000 units and a merchant fleet of 581 ships.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Commission_278-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Commission-278">[277]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Porto_nuovo_di_Trieste_1.4.2012.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Porto_nuovo_di_Trieste_1.4.2012.jpg/350px-Porto_nuovo_di_Trieste_1.4.2012.jpg" decoding="async" width="350" height="102" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Porto_nuovo_di_Trieste_1.4.2012.jpg/525px-Porto_nuovo_di_Trieste_1.4.2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Porto_nuovo_di_Trieste_1.4.2012.jpg/700px-Porto_nuovo_di_Trieste_1.4.2012.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2540" data-file-height="743"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Porto_nuovo_di_Trieste_1.4.2012.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">Trieste</a>, the main port of the northern Adriatic and starting point of the <a href="/wiki/Transalpine_Pipeline" title="Transalpine Pipeline">Transalpine Pipeline</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy does not invest enough to maintain <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Italy" title="Water supply and sanitation in Italy">its drinking water supply</a>. The Galli Law, passed in 1993, aimed at raising the level of investment and to improve service quality by consolidating service providers, making them more efficient and increasing the level of cost recovery through tariff revenues. Despite these reforms, investment levels have declined and remain far from sufficient.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[282]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[284]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy has been the final destination of the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">Silk Road</a> for many centuries. In particular, the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a> intensified sea trade with <a href="/wiki/East_Africa" title="East Africa">East Africa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> from the 19th century. Since the end of the Cold War and increasing European integration, the trade relations, which were often interrupted in the 20th century, have intensified again and the northern Italian ports such as the deep-water port of <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">Trieste</a> in the northernmost part of the Mediterranean with its extensive rail connections to <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> are once again the destination of government subsidies and significant foreign investment.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[285]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[286]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[287]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[288]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[289]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[290]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Italy" title="Energy in Italy">Energy in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_Eni_building,_Quartiere_XXXII_Europa,_Roma,_Lazio,_Italy_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/The_Eni_building%2C_Quartiere_XXXII_Europa%2C_Roma%2C_Lazio%2C_Italy_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-The_Eni_building%2C_Quartiere_XXXII_Europa%2C_Roma%2C_Lazio%2C_Italy_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/The_Eni_building%2C_Quartiere_XXXII_Europa%2C_Roma%2C_Lazio%2C_Italy_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-The_Eni_building%2C_Quartiere_XXXII_Europa%2C_Roma%2C_Lazio%2C_Italy_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/The_Eni_building%2C_Quartiere_XXXII_Europa%2C_Roma%2C_Lazio%2C_Italy_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-The_Eni_building%2C_Quartiere_XXXII_Europa%2C_Roma%2C_Lazio%2C_Italy_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2836" data-file-height="1889"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_Eni_building,_Quartiere_XXXII_Europa,_Roma,_Lazio,_Italy_-_panoramio.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Eni" title="Eni">ENI</a> is one of the world's largest industrial companies and among the oil and gas "<a href="/wiki/Supermajors" class="mw-redirect" title="Supermajors">Supermajors</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-Eni_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eni-292">[291]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[292]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Eni" title="Eni">Eni</a>, with operations in 79 countries, is one of the seven "<a href="/wiki/Supermajor" class="mw-redirect" title="Supermajor">Supermajor</a>" oil companies in the world, and one of the world's largest industrial companies.<sup id="cite_ref-Eni_292-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eni-292">[291]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Val%27d_Agri_oil_field" title="Val'd Agri oil field">Val d'Agri</a> area, <a href="/wiki/Basilicata" title="Basilicata">Basilicata</a>, hosts the largest <a href="/wiki/Onshore_(hydrocarbons)" title="Onshore (hydrocarbons)">onshore</a> <a href="/wiki/Hydrocarbon_field" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydrocarbon field">hydrocarbon field</a> in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[293]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Moderate natural gas reserves, mainly in the <a href="/wiki/Po_Valley" title="Po Valley">Po Valley</a> and offshore <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic Sea</a>, have been discovered in recent years and constitute the country's most important mineral resource. </p>
      <p>Italy is one of the world's leading producers of <a href="/wiki/Pumice" title="Pumice">pumice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pozzolana" title="Pozzolana">pozzolana</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Feldspar" title="Feldspar">feldspar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nat_resources_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nat_resources-295">[294]</a></sup> Another notable mineral resource is <a href="/wiki/Marble" title="Marble">marble</a>, especially the world-famous white <a href="/wiki/Carrara_marble" title="Carrara marble">Carrara marble</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Massa_and_Carrara" title="Province of Massa and Carrara">Massa and Carrara</a> quarries in <a href="/wiki/Tuscany" title="Tuscany">Tuscany</a>. Italy needs to import about 80% of its energy requirements.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[295]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[296]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[297]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pannelli_solari_Unicoop_Tirreno.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Pannelli_solari_Unicoop_Tirreno.JPG/210px-Pannelli_solari_Unicoop_Tirreno.JPG" decoding="async" width="210" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Pannelli_solari_Unicoop_Tirreno.JPG/315px-Pannelli_solari_Unicoop_Tirreno.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Pannelli_solari_Unicoop_Tirreno.JPG/420px-Pannelli_solari_Unicoop_Tirreno.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pannelli_solari_Unicoop_Tirreno.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Solar panels in <a href="/wiki/Piombino" title="Piombino">Piombino</a>. Italy is one of the world's largest producers of renewable energy.<sup id="cite_ref-legambiente2015_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-legambiente2015-299">[298]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the last decade, Italy has become one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_electricity_production_from_renewable_sources" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by electricity production from renewable sources">largest producers of renewable energy</a>, ranking as the second largest producer in the European Union and the ninth in the world. Wind power, hydroelectricity, and geothermal power are also important sources of electricity in the country. Renewable sources account for the 27.5% of all electricity produced in Italy, with hydro alone reaching 12.6%, followed by solar at 5.7%, wind at 4.1%, bioenergy at 3.5%, and geothermal at 1.6%.<sup id="cite_ref-gse_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gse-300">[299]</a></sup> The rest of the national demand is covered by fossil fuels (38.2% natural gas, 13% coal, 8.4% oil) and by imports.<sup id="cite_ref-gse_300-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gse-300">[299]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Solar_power_in_Italy" title="Solar power in Italy">Solar energy</a> production alone accounted for almost 9% of the total electric production in the country in 2014, making Italy the country with the highest contribution from solar energy in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-legambiente2015_299-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-legambiente2015-299">[298]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Montalto_di_Castro_Photovoltaic_Power_Station" title="Montalto di Castro Photovoltaic Power Station">Montalto di Castro Photovoltaic Power Station</a>, completed in 2010, is the largest photovoltaic power station in Italy with 85 MW. Other examples of large PV plants in Italy are San Bellino (70.6 MW), Cellino san Marco (42.7 MW) and Sant’ Alberto (34.6 MW).<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[300]</a></sup> Italy was also the first country to exploit geothermal energy to produce electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-UNMIG_191-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNMIG-191">[190]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy has managed four nuclear reactors until the 1980s. However, <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Italy" title="Nuclear power in Italy">nuclear power in Italy</a> has been abandoned following a <a href="/wiki/Italian_referendums,_1987" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian referendums, 1987">1987 referendum</a> (in the wake of the 1986 <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl_disaster" title="Chernobyl disaster">Chernobyl disaster</a> in Soviet Ukraine). The national power company <a href="/wiki/Enel" title="Enel">Enel</a> operates several nuclear reactors in Spain, Slovakia and France,<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[301]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nuclear_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nuclear-303">[302]</a></sup> managing it to access nuclear power and direct involvement in design, construction, and operation of the plants without placing reactors on Italian territory.<sup id="cite_ref-nuclear_303-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nuclear-303">[302]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Italy" title="Science and technology in Italy">Science and technology in Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of Italian inventions and discoveries">List of Italian inventions and discoveries</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg/240px-Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="240" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg/360px-Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg/480px-Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1010" data-file-height="1010"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Collage_scienziati_italiani.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Clockwise from top: <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Volta" title="Alessandro Volta">Alessandro Volta</a>, inventor of the <a href="/wiki/Electric_battery" title="Electric battery">electric battery</a> and discoverer of <a href="/wiki/Methane" title="Methane">methane</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-wmnqsy_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wmnqsy-304">[303]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Galilei" title="Galileo Galilei">Galileo Galilei</a>, recognised as the Father of modern science, physics and observational astronomy;<sup id="cite_ref-Einstein_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Einstein-305">[304]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Guglielmo_Marconi" title="Guglielmo Marconi">Guglielmo Marconi</a>, inventor of the long-distance radio transmission;<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[305]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Fermi" title="Enrico Fermi">Enrico Fermi</a>, creator of the first <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactor</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Pile-1" title="Chicago Pile-1">Chicago Pile-1</a><sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Through the centuries, Italy has fostered the scientific community that produced many major discoveries in physics and the other sciences. During the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> Italian polymaths such as <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a> (1452–1519), <a href="/wiki/Michelangelo" title="Michelangelo">Michelangelo</a> (1475–1564) and <a href="/wiki/Leon_Battista_Alberti" title="Leon Battista Alberti">Leon Battista Alberti</a> (1404–1472) made important contributions to a variety of fields, including biology, architecture, and engineering. <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Galilei" title="Galileo Galilei">Galileo Galilei</a> (1564–1642), a physicist, mathematician and astronomer, played a major role in the <a href="/wiki/Scientific_Revolution" title="Scientific Revolution">Scientific Revolution</a>. His achievements include key improvements to the <a href="/wiki/Telescope" title="Telescope">telescope</a> and consequent astronomical observations, and ultimately the triumph of <a href="/wiki/Nicolaus_Copernicus" title="Nicolaus Copernicus">Copernicanism</a> over the <a href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_model" class="mw-redirect" title="Ptolemaic model">Ptolemaic model</a>. </p>
      <p>Other astronomers suchs as <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Domenico_Cassini" title="Giovanni Domenico Cassini">Giovanni Domenico Cassini</a> (1625–1712) and <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Schiaparelli" title="Giovanni Schiaparelli">Giovanni Schiaparelli</a> (1835–1910) made many important discoveries about the <a href="/wiki/Solar_System" title="Solar System">Solar System</a>. In mathematics, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Louis_Lagrange" class="mw-redirect" title="Joseph Louis Lagrange">Joseph Louis Lagrange</a> (born Giuseppe Lodovico Lagrangia, 1736–1813) was active before leaving Italy. <a href="/wiki/Fibonacci" title="Fibonacci">Fibonacci</a> (c. 1170 – c. 1250), and <a href="/wiki/Gerolamo_Cardano" title="Gerolamo Cardano">Gerolamo Cardano</a> (1501–1576) made fundamental advances in mathematics. <a href="/wiki/Luca_Pacioli" title="Luca Pacioli">Luca Pacioli</a> established <a href="/wiki/Accounting" title="Accounting">accounting</a> to the world. Physicist <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Fermi" title="Enrico Fermi">Enrico Fermi</a> (1901–1954), a Nobel prize laureate, led the team in Chicago that developed the <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Pile-1" title="Chicago Pile-1">first nuclear reactor</a> and is also noted for his many other contributions to physics, including the co-development of the <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">quantum theory</a> and was one of the key figures in the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapon</a>. He, <a href="/wiki/Emilio_G._Segr%C3%A8" class="mw-redirect" title="Emilio G. Segrè">Emilio G. Segrè</a> (1905–1989) who discovered the elements <a href="/wiki/Technetium" title="Technetium">technetium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Astatine" title="Astatine">astatine</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Antiproton" title="Antiproton">antiproton</a>), <a href="/wiki/Bruno_Rossi" title="Bruno Rossi">Bruno Rossi</a> (1905–1993) a pioneer in Cosmic Rays and X-ray astronomy) and a number of Italian physicists were forced to leave Italy in the 1930s by <a href="/wiki/Italian_Racial_Laws" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Racial Laws">Fascist laws against Jews</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[307]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other prominent physicists include: <a href="/wiki/Amedeo_Avogadro" title="Amedeo Avogadro">Amedeo Avogadro</a> (most noted for his contributions to <a href="/wiki/Molecular_theory" class="mw-redirect" title="Molecular theory">molecular theory</a>, in particular the <a href="/wiki/Avogadro%27s_law" title="Avogadro's law">Avogadro's law</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Avogadro_constant" title="Avogadro constant">Avogadro constant</a>), <a href="/wiki/Evangelista_Torricelli" title="Evangelista Torricelli">Evangelista Torricelli</a> (inventor of <a href="/wiki/Barometer" title="Barometer">barometer</a>), <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Volta" title="Alessandro Volta">Alessandro Volta</a> (inventor of <a href="/wiki/Electric_battery" title="Electric battery">electric battery</a>), <a href="/wiki/Guglielmo_Marconi" title="Guglielmo Marconi">Guglielmo Marconi</a> (inventor of <a href="/wiki/Radio" title="Radio">radio</a>), <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Ferraris" title="Galileo Ferraris">Galileo Ferraris</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Pacinotti" title="Antonio Pacinotti">Antonio Pacinotti</a>, pioneers of the induction motor, <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Cruto" title="Alessandro Cruto">Alessandro Cruto</a>, pioneer of light bulb and <a href="/wiki/Innocenzo_Manzetti" title="Innocenzo Manzetti">Innocenzo Manzetti</a>, eclectic pioneer of auto and robotics, <a href="/wiki/Ettore_Majorana" title="Ettore Majorana">Ettore Majorana</a> (who discovered the <a href="/wiki/Majorana_fermion" title="Majorana fermion">Majorana fermions</a>), <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Rubbia" title="Carlo Rubbia">Carlo Rubbia</a> (1984 Nobel Prize in Physics for work leading to the discovery of the <a href="/wiki/W_and_Z_particles" class="mw-redirect" title="W and Z particles">W and Z particles</a> at <a href="/wiki/CERN" title="CERN">CERN</a>). <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Meucci" title="Antonio Meucci">Antonio Meucci</a> is known for developing a voice-communication device which is often credited as the first <a href="/wiki/Telephone" title="Telephone">telephone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[308]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[309]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pier_Giorgio_Perotto" title="Pier Giorgio Perotto">Pier Giorgio Perotto</a> in 1964 designed one of the first desktop <a href="/wiki/Programmable_calculator" title="Programmable calculator">programmable calculators</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Programma_101" title="Programma 101">Programma 101</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[310]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[311]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[312]</a></sup> In biology, <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Redi" title="Francesco Redi">Francesco Redi</a> has been the first to challenge the theory of spontaneous generation by demonstrating that maggots come from eggs of flies and he described 180 parasites in details and <a href="/wiki/Marcello_Malpighi" title="Marcello Malpighi">Marcello Malpighi</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Microscopic_anatomy" class="mw-redirect" title="Microscopic anatomy">microscopic anatomy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lazzaro_Spallanzani" title="Lazzaro Spallanzani">Lazzaro Spallanzani</a> conducted important research in bodily functions, animal reproduction, and cellular theory, <a href="/wiki/Camillo_Golgi" title="Camillo Golgi">Camillo Golgi</a>, whose many achievements include the discovery of the <a href="/wiki/Golgi_complex" class="mw-redirect" title="Golgi complex">Golgi complex</a>, paved the way to the acceptance of the <a href="/wiki/Neuron_doctrine" title="Neuron doctrine">Neuron doctrine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rita_Levi-Montalcini" title="Rita Levi-Montalcini">Rita Levi-Montalcini</a> discovered the <a href="/wiki/Nerve_growth_factor" title="Nerve growth factor">nerve growth factor</a> (awarded 1986 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine). In chemistry, <a href="/wiki/Giulio_Natta" title="Giulio Natta">Giulio Natta</a> received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1963 for his work on high <a href="/wiki/Polymers" class="mw-redirect" title="Polymers">polymers</a>. <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Occhialini" title="Giuseppe Occhialini">Giuseppe Occhialini</a> received the <a href="/wiki/Wolf_Prize_in_Physics" title="Wolf Prize in Physics">Wolf Prize in Physics</a> for the discovery of the <a href="/wiki/Pion" title="Pion">pion</a> or pi-<a href="/wiki/Meson" title="Meson">meson</a> decay in 1947. <a href="/wiki/Ennio_de_Giorgi" title="Ennio de Giorgi">Ennio de Giorgi</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Wolf_Prize_in_Mathematics" title="Wolf Prize in Mathematics">Wolf Prize in Mathematics</a> recipient in 1990, solved <a href="/wiki/Bernstein%27s_problem" title="Bernstein's problem">Bernstein's problem</a> about <a href="/wiki/Minimal_surface" title="Minimal surface">minimal surfaces</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hilbert%27s_nineteenth_problem" title="Hilbert's nineteenth problem">19th Hilbert problem</a> on the regularity of solutions of <a href="/wiki/Elliptic_partial_differential_equations" class="mw-redirect" title="Elliptic partial differential equations">Elliptic partial differential equations</a>. </p>
      <p>There are numerous technology parks in Italy such as the Science and Technology Parks Kilometro Rosso (Bergamo), the <a href="/wiki/AREA_Science_Park" title="AREA Science Park">AREA Science Park</a> (Trieste), The VEGA-Venice Gateway for Science and Technology (Venezia), the Toscana Life Sciences (Siena), the Technology Park of Lodi Cluster (Lodi), and the Technology Park of Navacchio (Pisa).<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[313]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/ELETTRA" title="ELETTRA">ELETTRA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurac_Research" title="Eurac Research">Eurac Research</a>, <a href="/wiki/ESA_Centre_for_Earth_Observation" title="ESA Centre for Earth Observation">ESA Centre for Earth Observation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Scientific_Interchange" title="Institute for Scientific Interchange">Institute for Scientific Interchange</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Centre_for_Genetic_Engineering_and_Biotechnology" title="International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology">International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Centre_for_Maritime_Research_and_Experimentation" title="Centre for Maritime Research and Experimentation">Centre for Maritime Research and Experimentation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/International_Centre_for_Theoretical_Physics" title="International Centre for Theoretical Physics">International Centre for Theoretical Physics</a> conduct basic research. <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">Trieste</a> has the highest percentage of researchers in Europe in relation to the population.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[314]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Italy" title="Tourism in Italy">Tourism in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Positano_-_Fornillo_Beach.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Positano_-_Fornillo_Beach.jpg/220px-Positano_-_Fornillo_Beach.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Positano_-_Fornillo_Beach.jpg/330px-Positano_-_Fornillo_Beach.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Positano_-_Fornillo_Beach.jpg/440px-Positano_-_Fornillo_Beach.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3783" data-file-height="2533"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Positano_-_Fornillo_Beach.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Amalfi_Coast" title="Amalfi Coast">Amalfi Coast</a> is one of Italy's major tourist destinations.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[315]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy is the fifth most visited country in the world, with a total of 52.3 million international arrivals in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2016_Edition_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2016_Edition-317">[316]</a></sup> The total contribution of travel &amp; tourism to GDP (including wider effects from investment, the supply chain and induced income impacts) was EUR162.7bn in 2014 (10.1% of GDP) and generated 1,082,000 jobs directly in 2014 (4.8% of total employment).<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[317]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy is well known for its cultural and environmental tourist routes and is home to 55 <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-convention_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-convention-319">[318]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a> is the 3rd most visited city in Europe and the 12th in the world, with 9.4 million arrivals in 2017 while <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">Milan</a> is the 27th worldwide with 6.8 million tourists.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[319]</a></sup> In addition, <a href="/wiki/Venice" title="Venice">Venice</a> and <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">Florence</a> are also among the world's top 100 destinations. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Italy" title="Demographics of Italy">Demographics of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Italians" title="Italians">Italians</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_population_density_in_Italy_(2011_census)_alt_colours.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Map_of_population_density_in_Italy_%282011_census%29_alt_colours.jpg/220px-Map_of_population_density_in_Italy_%282011_census%29_alt_colours.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="254" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Map_of_population_density_in_Italy_%282011_census%29_alt_colours.jpg/330px-Map_of_population_density_in_Italy_%282011_census%29_alt_colours.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Map_of_population_density_in_Italy_%282011_census%29_alt_colours.jpg/440px-Map_of_population_density_in_Italy_%282011_census%29_alt_colours.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="2313"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_population_density_in_Italy_(2011_census)_alt_colours.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of Italy's population density as of the 2011 census
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>At the beginning of 2020, Italy had 60,317,116 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-istat.it_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-istat.it-4">[4]</a></sup> The resulting population density, at 202 inhabitants per square kilometre (520/sq&nbsp;mi), is higher than that of most Western European countries. However, the distribution of the population is widely uneven. The most densely populated areas are the Po Valley (that accounts for almost a half of the national population) and the metropolitan areas of Rome and Naples, while vast regions such as the Alps and Apennines highlands, the plateaus of Basilicata and the island of Sardinia, as well as much of Sicily, are very sparsely populated. </p>
      <p>The population of Italy almost doubled during the 20th century, but the pattern of growth was extremely uneven because of large-scale internal migration from the rural South to the industrial cities of the North, a phenomenon which happened as a consequence of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_economic_miracle" title="Italian economic miracle">Italian economic miracle</a> of the 1950–1960s. High fertility and birth rates persisted until the 1970s, after which they started to decline. The population rapidly <a href="/wiki/Population_ageing" title="Population ageing">aged</a>; by 2010, one in five Italians was over 65 years old, and the country currently has the fifth oldest population in the world, with a <a href="/wiki/Median_age" class="mw-redirect" title="Median age">median age</a> of 46.5 years.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[320]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[321]</a></sup> However, in recent years Italy has experienced significant growth in birth rates.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[322]</a></sup> The total fertility rate has also climbed from an all-time low of 1.18 children per woman in 1995 to 1.41 in 2008,<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[323]</a></sup> albeit still below the <a href="/wiki/Replacement_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Replacement rate">replacement rate</a> of 2.1 and considerably below the high of 5.06 children born per woman in 1883.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[324]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> is expected to reach 1.6–1.8 in 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[325]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>From the late 19th century until the 1960s Italy was a country of mass <a href="/wiki/Emigration" title="Emigration">emigration</a>. Between 1898 and 1914, the peak years of <a href="/wiki/Italian_diaspora" title="Italian diaspora">Italian diaspora</a>, approximately 750,000 Italians emigrated each year.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[326]</a></sup> The diaspora concerned more than 25 million Italians and it is considered the biggest mass migration of contemporary times.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[327]</a></sup> As a result, today more than 4.1 million Italian citizens are living abroad,<sup id="cite_ref-aire_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aire-329">[328]</a></sup> while at least 60 million people of full or part Italian ancestry live outside of Italy, most notably in <a href="/wiki/Italians_in_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="Italians in Argentina">Argentina</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[329]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Italian_Brazilians" title="Italian Brazilians">Brazil</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[330]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Italian_Uruguayans" title="Italian Uruguayans">Uruguay</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[331]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Italians_in_Venezuela" class="mw-redirect" title="Italians in Venezuela">Venezuela</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[332]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Italians_in_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="Italians in the United States">United States</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[333]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Italians_in_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Italians in Canada">Canada</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[334]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Italian_Australians" title="Italian Australians">Australia</a><sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[335]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Italians_in_France" title="Italians in France">France</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[336]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><br> </p>

         <td><b><a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_City_of_Cagliari" title="Metropolitan City of Cagliari">Cagliari</a></b> </td> 
         <td align="center"><a href="/wiki/Sardinia" title="Sardinia">Sardinia</a> </td> 
         <td align="right">1,248 </td> 
         <td align="right">431,038 </td> 
         <td align="right">488,954 </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">Immigration</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Italy" title="Immigration to Italy">Immigration to Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:COB_data_Italy.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/COB_data_Italy.PNG/350px-COB_data_Italy.PNG" decoding="async" width="350" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/COB_data_Italy.PNG/525px-COB_data_Italy.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/COB_data_Italy.PNG/700px-COB_data_Italy.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1357" data-file-height="628"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:COB_data_Italy.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Italy is home to a large population of migrants from Eastern Europe and North Africa.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2016, Italy had about 5.05 million foreign residents,<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[339]</a></sup> making up 8.3% of the total population. The figures include more than half a million children born in Italy to foreign nationals&nbsp;(second generation immigrants) but exclude foreign nationals who have subsequently acquired Italian citizenship;<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[340]</a></sup> in 2016, about 201,000 people became Italian citizens,<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[341]</a></sup> compared to 130,000 in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[342]</a></sup> The official figures also exclude <a href="/wiki/Illegal_immigration" title="Illegal immigration">illegal immigrants</a>, who estimated to number at least 670,000 as of 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[343]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Starting from the early 1980s, until then a linguistically and culturally homogeneous society, Italy begun to attract substantial flows of foreign immigrants.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[344]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Berlin_Wall" title="Fall of the Berlin Wall">fall of the Berlin Wall</a> and, more recently, the <a href="/wiki/2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2004 enlargement of the European Union">2004</a> and <a href="/wiki/2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2004 enlargement of the European Union">2007</a> enlargements of the European Union, large waves of migration originated from the former socialist countries of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> (especially <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>). An equally important source of immigration is neighbouring North Africa (in particular, <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, Egypt and <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>), with soaring arrivals as a consequence of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a>. Furthermore, in recent years, growing migration fluxes from Asia-Pacific (notably <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[345]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>) and Latin America have been recorded. </p>
      <p>Currently, about one million <a href="/wiki/Romanian_diaspora" title="Romanian diaspora">Romanian</a> citizens (around 10% of them being ethnic <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Romani people</a><sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[346]</a></sup>) are officially registered as living in Italy, representing thus the most important individual country of origin, followed by <a href="/wiki/Albanians" title="Albanians">Albanians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moroccans" title="Moroccans">Moroccans</a> with about 500,000 people each. The number of unregistered Romanians is difficult to estimate, but the Balkan Investigative Reporting Network suggested in 2007 that there might have been half a million or more.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[347]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[note 2]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of 2010, the foreign born population of Italy was from the following regions: Europe (54%), Africa (22%), Asia (16%), the Americas (8%) and Oceania (0.06%). The distribution of immigrants is largely uneven in Italy: 87% live in the northern and central parts of the country (the most economically developed areas), while only 13% live in the southern half. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Italy" title="Languages of Italy">Languages of Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Italy#Historical_language_minorities" title="Languages of Italy">Italy's recognised minority languages</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian language</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Regional_Italian" title="Regional Italian">Regional Italian</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Linguistic_map_of_the_Italian_language.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Linguistic_map_of_the_Italian_language.svg/350px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Italian_language.svg.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="180" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Linguistic_map_of_the_Italian_language.svg/525px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Italian_language.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Linguistic_map_of_the_Italian_language.svg/700px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Italian_language.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="263"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Linguistic_map_of_the_Italian_language.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Geographic distribution of the Italian language in the world: 
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#0c5eb1; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Official language status
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#9fceff; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Former official language status
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#00ff00; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Presence of Italian-speaking communities
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy's official language is <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>, as stated by the framework law no. 482/1999<sup id="cite_ref-lang_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lang-351">[349]</a></sup> and Trentino Alto-Adige's special Statute,<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[350]</a></sup> which is adopted with a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_law" title="Constitutional law">constitutional law</a>. Around the world there are an estimated 64 million native Italian speakers<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[351]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-europa2006_354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-europa2006-354">[352]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[353]</a></sup> and another 21 million who use it as a second language.<sup id="cite_ref-Italian_language_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Italian_language-356">[354]</a></sup> Italian is often natively spoken in a <a href="/wiki/Regional_Italian" title="Regional Italian">regional variety</a>, not to be confused with Italy's regional and minority languages;<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[355]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[356]</a></sup> however, the establishment of a national education system led to a decrease in variation in the languages spoken across the country during the 20th century. Standardisation was further expanded in the 1950s and 1960s due to economic growth and the rise of <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Italy">mass media</a> and television (the state broadcaster <a href="/wiki/RAI" title="RAI">RAI</a> helped set a standard Italian). </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg/150px-Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg.png" decoding="async" width="150" height="191" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg/225px-Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg/300px-Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="4022" data-file-height="5122"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Minoranze_linguistiche_it.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The ethno-linguistic minorities officially recognised by Italy<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[357]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Twelve "historical <a href="/wiki/Minority_language" title="Minority language">minority languages</a>" (<i>minoranze linguistiche storiche</i>) are formally recognised: <a href="/wiki/Arberesh_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arberesh language">Albanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">Catalan</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">Slovene</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>, <a href="/wiki/Franco-Proven%C3%A7al_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Franco-Provençal language">Franco-Provençal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Friulian" class="mw-redirect" title="Friulian">Friulian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ladin_language" title="Ladin language">Ladin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Occitan" class="mw-redirect" title="Occitan">Occitan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">Sardinian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-lang_351-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lang-351">[349]</a></sup> Four of these also enjoy a co-official status in their respective region: French in the <a href="/wiki/Aosta_Valley" title="Aosta Valley">Aosta Valley</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[358]</a></sup> German in <a href="/wiki/South_Tyrol" title="South Tyrol">South Tyrol</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ladin_language" title="Ladin language">Ladin</a> as well in some parts of the same province and in parts of the neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Trentino" title="Trentino">Trentino</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[359]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">Slovene</a> in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Trieste" title="Province of Trieste">Trieste</a>, <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Gorizia" title="Province of Gorizia">Gorizia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Udine" title="Province of Udine">Udine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[360]</a></sup> A number of other Ethnologue, ISO and UNESCO languages are not recognised by Italian law. Like France, Italy has signed the <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a>, but has not ratified it.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[361]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Because of recent immigration, Italy has sizeable populations whose native language is not Italian, nor a regional language. According to the <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Statistics_(Italy)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Institute of Statistics (Italy)">Italian National Institute of Statistics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romanian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Romanian people">Romanian</a> is the most common mother tongue among foreign residents in Italy: almost 800,000 people speak Romanian as their first language (21.9% of the foreign residents aged 6 and over).
