Other prevalent mother tongues are <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a> (spoken by over 475,000 people; 13.1% of foreign residents), <a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian</a> (380,000 people) and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> (255,000 people).<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[362]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Italy" title="Religion in Italy">Religion in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:342px;max-width:342px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:169px;max-width:169px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Florence_Duomo_from_Michelangelo_hill.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Florence_Duomo_from_Michelangelo_hill.jpg/167px-Florence_Duomo_from_Michelangelo_hill.jpg" decoding="async" width="167" height="121" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Florence_Duomo_from_Michelangelo_hill.jpg/251px-Florence_Duomo_from_Michelangelo_hill.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Florence_Duomo_from_Michelangelo_hill.jpg/334px-Florence_Duomo_from_Michelangelo_hill.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3308" data-file-height="2399"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:169px;max-width:169px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica_facade,_Rome,_Italy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg/167px-Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg" decoding="async" width="167" height="111" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg/251px-Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg/334px-Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica_facade%2C_Rome%2C_Italy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4470" data-file-height="2975"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:169px;max-width:169px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Basilica_Venecia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Basilica_Venecia.jpg/167px-Basilica_Venecia.jpg" decoding="async" width="167" height="119" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Basilica_Venecia.jpg/251px-Basilica_Venecia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Basilica_Venecia.jpg/334px-Basilica_Venecia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2676" data-file-height="1907"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:169px;max-width:169px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Milano,_Duomo,_2016-06_CN-03.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Milano%2C_Duomo%2C_2016-06_CN-03.jpg/167px-Milano%2C_Duomo%2C_2016-06_CN-03.jpg" decoding="async" width="167" height="127" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Milano%2C_Duomo%2C_2016-06_CN-03.jpg/251px-Milano%2C_Duomo%2C_2016-06_CN-03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Milano%2C_Duomo%2C_2016-06_CN-03.jpg/334px-Milano%2C_Duomo%2C_2016-06_CN-03.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3365" data-file-height="2564"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          Italy is home to many of the world's largest, oldest and opulent churches. Clockwise from left: <a href="/wiki/Florence_Cathedral" title="Florence Cathedral">Florence Cathedral</a>, which has the biggest brick dome in the world;<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[363]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[364]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica" title="St. Peter's Basilica">St. Peter's Basilica</a>, the largest church of <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[365]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Milan_Cathedral" title="Milan Cathedral">Milan Cathedral</a>, the largest Italian church and the third largest in the world; and <a href="/wiki/St_Mark%27s_Basilica" title="St Mark's Basilica">St Mark's Basilica</a>, one of the best known examples of Italo-<a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a><sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[366]</a></sup>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2017, the proportion of Italians who identified themselves as <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism">Roman Catholic Christians</a> was 74.4%.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[367]</a></sup> Since 1985, Roman Catholicism is no longer officially the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[368]</a></sup> Italy has the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">fifth world's largest Roman Catholic population</a>, and the largest Catholic nation in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[369]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">episcopal jurisdiction of Rome</a>, contains the central government of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>. It is recognised by other subjects of international law as a <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereign</a> entity, headed by the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a>, who is also the <a href="/wiki/Bishop_of_Rome" class="mw-redirect" title="Bishop of Rome">Bishop of Rome</a>, with which <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Diplomatic relations">diplomatic relations</a> can be maintained.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[370]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[371]</a></sup> Often incorrectly referred to as "the Vatican", the Holy See is not the same entity as the <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a> State,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text should explian the difference (July 2020)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> which came into existence only in 1929. </p>
      <p>In 2011, minority Christian faiths in Italy included an estimated 1.5 million Orthodox Christians, or 2.5% of the population;<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[372]</a></sup> 500,000 <a href="/wiki/Pentecostals" class="mw-redirect" title="Pentecostals">Pentecostals</a> and <a href="/wiki/Evangelicals" class="mw-redirect" title="Evangelicals">Evangelicals</a> (of whom 400,000 are members of the <a href="/wiki/Assemblies_of_God" title="Assemblies of God">Assemblies of God</a>), 251,192 <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[373]</a></sup> 30,000 Waldensians,<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[374]</a></sup> 25,000 <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventists" class="mw-redirect" title="Seventh-day Adventists">Seventh-day Adventists</a>, 26,925 <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">Latter-day Saints</a>, 15,000 Baptists (plus some 5,000 Free Baptists), 7,000 <a href="/wiki/Lutherans" class="mw-redirect" title="Lutherans">Lutherans</a>, 4,000 <a href="/wiki/Methodists" class="mw-redirect" title="Methodists">Methodists</a> (<a href="/wiki/Union_of_Methodist_and_Waldensian_Churches" title="Union of Methodist and Waldensian Churches">affiliated with the Waldensian Church</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[375]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>One of the longest-established minority religious faiths in Italy is <a href="/wiki/Italian_Jews" title="Italian Jews">Judaism</a>, Jews having been present in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Ancient Rome</a> since before the birth of Christ. Italy has for centuries welcomed Jews expelled from other countries, notably Spain. However, about 20% of Italian Jews were killed during the <a href="/wiki/Holocaust" class="mw-redirect" title="Holocaust">Holocaust</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-isbn0553343025_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-isbn0553343025-378">[376]</a></sup> This, together with the emigration which preceded and followed World War II, has left only around 28,400 Jews in Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[377]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="barbox tleft" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;"> 
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:#ddd">
           <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5">Religion in Italy in 2017<sup id="cite_ref-2016Montaigne-IFOP_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2016Montaigne-IFOP-380">[378]</a></sup></th>
          </tr> 
          <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;"> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Italy" title="Catholic Church in Italy">Roman Catholicism</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:gold; width:78%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">78%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">No Religion</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:blue; width:15%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">15%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Other Religions</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:Green; width:5%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">5%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Other Christian</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:purple; width:2%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Soaring immigration in the last two decades has been accompanied by an increase in non-Christian faiths. There are more than 800,000 followers of faiths originating in the Indian subcontinent with some 70,000 <a href="/wiki/Sikhs" title="Sikhs">Sikhs</a> with 22 <a href="/wiki/Gurdwaras" class="mw-redirect" title="Gurdwaras">gurdwaras</a> across the country.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[379]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="Who are the other 730,000 followers of Indian faiths? (March 2020)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The Italian state, as a measure to protect religious freedom, devolves shares of income tax to recognised religious communities, under a regime known as <a href="/wiki/Eight_per_thousand" title="Eight per thousand">Eight per thousand</a>. Donations are allowed to Christian, Jewish, Buddhist and Hindu communities; however, Islam remains excluded, since no Muslim communities have yet signed a concordat with the Italian state.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[380]</a></sup> Taxpayers who do not wish to fund a religion contribute their share to the state welfare system.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[381]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Italy" title="Education in Italy">Education in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Archiginnasio_ora_blu_Bologna.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Archiginnasio_ora_blu_Bologna.jpg/220px-Archiginnasio_ora_blu_Bologna.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Archiginnasio_ora_blu_Bologna.jpg/330px-Archiginnasio_ora_blu_Bologna.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Archiginnasio_ora_blu_Bologna.jpg/440px-Archiginnasio_ora_blu_Bologna.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7240" data-file-height="4784"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Archiginnasio_ora_blu_Bologna.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bologna_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Bologna University">Bologna University</a>, established in AD 1088, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_universities_in_continuous_operation" title="List of oldest universities in continuous operation">world's oldest academic institution</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Education in Italy is free and mandatory from ages six to sixteen,<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[382]</a></sup> and consists of five stages: kindergarten (<i>scuola dell'infanzia</i>), primary school (<i>scuola primaria</i>), <a href="/wiki/Lower_secondary_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Lower secondary school">lower secondary school</a> (<i>scuola secondaria di primo grado</i>, <a href="/wiki/Upper_secondary_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Upper secondary school">upper secondary school</a> (<i>scuola secondaria di secondo grado</i>) and university (<i>università</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[383]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Primary education lasts eight years. Students are given a basic education in Italian, English, mathematics, natural sciences, history, geography, social studies, physical education and visual and musical arts. Secondary education lasts for five years and includes three traditional types of schools focused on different academic levels: the <i><a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Italy#liceo" title="Secondary education in Italy">liceo</a></i> prepares students for university studies with a classical or scientific curriculum, while the <i><a href="/wiki/Istituto_tecnico" class="mw-redirect" title="Istituto tecnico">istituto tecnico</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Istituto_professionale" class="mw-redirect" title="Istituto professionale">Istituto professionale</a></i> prepare pupils for vocational education. In 2018, the Italian secondary education was evaluated as below the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> average.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[384]</a></sup> A wide gap exists between <a href="/wiki/Northern_Italy" title="Northern Italy">northern</a> schools, which perform better than average, and schools in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">South</a>, that had much poorer results.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[385]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Tertiary education in Italy is divided between <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Italy" title="List of universities in Italy">public universities</a>, private universities and the prestigious and selective <a href="/wiki/Superior_Graduate_Schools_in_Italy" title="Superior Graduate Schools in Italy">superior graduate schools</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Scuola_Normale_Superiore_di_Pisa" title="Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa">Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa</a>. 33 Italian universities were ranked among the world's top 500 in 2019, the third-largest number in Europe after the United Kingdom and Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[386]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bologna_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Bologna University">Bologna University</a>, founded in 1088, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_universities_in_continuous_operation" title="List of oldest universities in continuous operation">oldest university in continuous operation</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[387]</a></sup> as well as one of the leading academic institutions in Italy and Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[388]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bocconi_University" title="Bocconi University">Bocconi University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Universit%C3%A0_Cattolica_del_Sacro_Cuore" title="Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore">Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Libera_Universit%C3%A0_Internazionale_degli_Studi_Sociali_Guido_Carli" title="Libera Università Internazionale degli Studi Sociali Guido Carli">LUISS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polytechnic_University_of_Turin" title="Polytechnic University of Turin">Polytechnic University of Turin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polytechnic_University_of_Milan" title="Polytechnic University of Milan">Polytechnic University of Milan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sapienza_University_of_Rome" title="Sapienza University of Rome">Sapienza University of Rome</a>, and <a href="/wiki/University_of_Milan" title="University of Milan">University of Milan</a> are also ranked among the best in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[389]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Italy" title="Healthcare in Italy">Healthcare in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Oil-1383546_1920.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Oil-1383546_1920.jpg/220px-Oil-1383546_1920.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Oil-1383546_1920.jpg/330px-Oil-1383546_1920.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Oil-1383546_1920.jpg/440px-Oil-1383546_1920.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1281"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Oil-1383546_1920.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">Olive oil</a> and vegetables are central to the Mediterranean diet.<sup id="cite_ref-:110_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:110-392">[390]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Italian state runs a universal public healthcare system since 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-dev.prenhall_a_393-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dev.prenhall_a-393">[391]</a></sup> However, healthcare is provided to all citizens and residents by a mixed public-private system. The public part is the <i>Servizio Sanitario Nazionale</i>, which is organised under the Ministry of Health and administered on a devolved regional basis. Healthcare spending in Italy accounted for 9.2% of the national GDP in 2012, very close the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> countries' average of 9.3%.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD-394">[392]</a></sup> Italy in 2000 ranked as having the world's 2nd best healthcare system,<sup id="cite_ref-dev.prenhall_a_393-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dev.prenhall_a-393">[391]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-photius.com_395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-photius.com-395">[393]</a></sup> and the world's <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization_ranking_of_health_systems_in_2000" title="World Health Organization ranking of health systems in 2000">2nd best healthcare performance</a>. </p>
      <p>Life expectancy in Italy is 80 for males and 85 for females, placing the country <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">5th in the world for life expectancy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[394]</a></sup> In comparison to other Western countries, Italy has a relatively low rate of adult obesity (below 10%<sup id="cite_ref-IOTF2008_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IOTF2008-397">[395]</a></sup>), as there are several health benefits of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_diet" title="Mediterranean diet">Mediterranean diet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dinu2017_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dinu2017-398">[396]</a></sup> The proportion of daily smokers was 22% in 2012, down from 24.4% in 2000 but still slightly above the OECD average.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD_394-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD-394">[392]</a></sup> Smoking in public places including bars, restaurants, night clubs and offices has been restricted to specially ventilated rooms since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[397]</a></sup> In 2013, <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> added the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_diet" title="Mediterranean diet">Mediterranean diet</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Representative_List_of_the_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_of_Humanity" class="mw-redirect" title="Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity">Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity</a> of Italy (promoter), <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[398]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[399]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="North-South_gap">North-South gap</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Southern_question" class="mw-redirect" title="Southern question">Southern question</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In the decades following the <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Unification of italy">unification of Italy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/North_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="North Italy">northern regions of the country</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lombardy" title="Lombardy">Lombardy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piedmont" title="Piedmont">Piedmont</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liguria" title="Liguria">Liguria</a> in particular, began a process of industrialization and economic development while the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">southern regions</a> remained behind. Due to the growing economic and social gap, the <a href="/wiki/Southern_question" class="mw-redirect" title="Southern question">southern question</a> is beginning to be talked about<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[400]</a></sup> The imbalance between North and South, which widened steadily in the first post-unification century, was reduced in the <a href="/wiki/Sixties" class="mw-redirect" title="Sixties">sixties</a> and <a href="/wiki/Seventies" class="mw-redirect" title="Seventies">seventies</a> also through the construction of public works, the implementation of agrarian and scholastic reforms,<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[401]</a></sup> the expansion of industrialization and the improved living conditions of the <a href="/wiki/Population_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Population of Italy">population</a>. This convergence process was interrupted, however, in the <a href="/wiki/1980s" title="1980s">1980s</a>. To date, the per capita <a href="/wiki/GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="GDP">GDP</a> of the South is just 58% of that of the <a href="/wiki/North_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="North Italy">Center-North</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[402]</a></sup> while the unemployment rate is more than double (6.7% in the North against 14.9% in the South).<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[403]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A study by Censis attributes to the pervasive presence of <a href="/wiki/Italian_Criminal_Law_System" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Criminal Law System">criminal organizations</a> an important role in the delay of Southern Italy, they estimate an annual loss of wealth of 2.5% in the South in the period 1981–2003 due to the presence of such organizations and evaluating that without of these, the per capita GDP of the South would have reached that of the North.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[404]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Italy" title="Culture of Italy">Culture of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venice_Carnival_(2010).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Venice_Carnival_%282010%29.jpg/220px-Venice_Carnival_%282010%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Venice_Carnival_%282010%29.jpg/330px-Venice_Carnival_%282010%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Venice_Carnival_%282010%29.jpg/440px-Venice_Carnival_%282010%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venice_Carnival_(2010).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Carnival_of_Venice" title="Carnival of Venice">Carnival of Venice</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy is considered one of the birthplaces of <a href="/wiki/Western_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Western civilization">western civilization</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Power_(international_relations)#Power_as_status" title="Power (international relations)">cultural superpower</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[405]</a></sup> Divided by politics and geography for centuries until its eventual unification in 1861, Italy's culture has been shaped by a multitude of regional customs and local centres of power and <a href="/wiki/Patronage" title="Patronage">patronage</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[406]</a></sup> Italy has had a central role in Western culture for centuries and is still recognised for its cultural traditions and artists. During the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, a number of magnificent <a href="/wiki/Court_(royal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Court (royal)">courts</a> competed for attracting the best architects, artists and scholars, thus producing a great legacy of monuments, paintings, music and literature. Despite the political and social isolation of these courts, Italy's contribution to the cultural and historical heritage of Europe and the world remain immense.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[407]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy has rich collections of art, culture and literature from many periods. The country has had a broad cultural influence worldwide, also because numerous Italians emigrated to other places during the <a href="/wiki/Italian_diaspora" title="Italian diaspora">Italian diaspora</a>. Furthermore, Italy has, overall, an estimated 100,000 monuments of any sort (museums, palaces, buildings, statues, churches, art galleries, villas, fountains, historic houses and archaeological remains),<sup id="cite_ref-Eyewitness_Travel_2005,_pg._19_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eyewitness_Travel_2005,_pg._19-410">[408]</a></sup> and according to some estimates the nation is home to half the world's great art treasures.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[409]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Italy" title="Architecture of Italy">Architecture of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg/220px-Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg/330px-Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg/440px-Canal_Grande_Chiesa_della_Salute_e_Dogana_dal_ponte_dell_Accademia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7307" data-file-height="4912"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The city of <a href="/wiki/Venice" title="Venice">Venice</a>, built on 117 islands
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Pisa_Duomo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Pisa_Duomo.jpg/220px-Pisa_Duomo.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="117" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Pisa_Duomo.jpg/330px-Pisa_Duomo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Pisa_Duomo.jpg/440px-Pisa_Duomo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3140" data-file-height="1672"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Duomo_di_Pisa" class="mw-redirect" title="Duomo di Pisa">Duomo</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Leaning_Tower_of_Pisa" title="Leaning Tower of Pisa">Leaning Tower of Pisa</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy is known for its considerable architectural achievements,<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[410]</a></sup> such as the construction of arches, domes and similar structures during <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">ancient Rome</a>, the founding of the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_architecture" title="Renaissance architecture">Renaissance architectural movement</a> in the late-14th to 16th centuries, and being the homeland of <a href="/wiki/Palladianism" class="mw-redirect" title="Palladianism">Palladianism</a>, a style of construction which inspired movements such as that of <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">Neoclassical architecture</a>, and influenced the designs which noblemen built their country houses all over the world, notably in the UK, Australia and the US during the late 17th to early 20th centuries. </p>
      <p>Along with pre-historic architecture, the first people in Italy to truly begin a sequence of designs were the Greeks and the Etruscans, progressing to classical Roman,<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[411]</a></sup> then to the revival of the classical Roman era during the Renaissance and evolving into the Baroque era. The Christian concept of a Basilica, a style of church architecture that came to dominate the early Middle Ages, was invented in Rome. They were known for being long, rectangular buildings, which were built in an almost ancient Roman style, often rich in mosaics and decorations. The early Christians' art and architecture was also widely inspired by that of the pagan Romans; statues, mosaics and paintings decorated all their churches.<sup id="cite_ref-byzan_414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-byzan-414">[412]</a></sup> The first significant buildings in the medieval Romanesque style were churches built in Italy during the 800's. Byzantine architecture was also widely diffused in Italy. The Byzantines kept Roman principles of architecture and art alive, and the most famous structure from this period is the <a href="/wiki/St_Mark%27s_Basilica" title="St Mark's Basilica">Basilica of St. Mark</a> in Venice. </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Castel_del_Monte,_Andria.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Castel_del_Monte%2C_Andria.jpg/220px-Castel_del_Monte%2C_Andria.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Castel_del_Monte%2C_Andria.jpg/330px-Castel_del_Monte%2C_Andria.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Castel_del_Monte%2C_Andria.jpg/440px-Castel_del_Monte%2C_Andria.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4875" data-file-height="3250"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Castel_del_Monte,_Apulia" title="Castel del Monte, Apulia">Castel del Monte, Apulia</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Reggia_di_Caserta,_prospettiva_dalla_fontana_di_Venere_e_Adone_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Reggia_di_Caserta%2C_prospettiva_dalla_fontana_di_Venere_e_Adone_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Reggia_di_Caserta%2C_prospettiva_dalla_fontana_di_Venere_e_Adone_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Reggia_di_Caserta%2C_prospettiva_dalla_fontana_di_Venere_e_Adone_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-Reggia_di_Caserta%2C_prospettiva_dalla_fontana_di_Venere_e_Adone_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Reggia_di_Caserta%2C_prospettiva_dalla_fontana_di_Venere_e_Adone_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-Reggia_di_Caserta%2C_prospettiva_dalla_fontana_di_Venere_e_Adone_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4752" data-file-height="3168"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Caserta" title="Royal Palace of Caserta">Royal Palace of Caserta</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Romanesque movement, which went from approximately 800 AD to 1100 AD, was one of the most fruitful and creative periods in Italian architecture, when several masterpieces, such as the Leaning Tower of Pisa in the <a href="/wiki/Piazza_dei_Miracoli" title="Piazza dei Miracoli">Piazza dei Miracoli</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_Sant%27Ambrogio" title="Basilica of Sant'Ambrogio">Basilica of Sant'Ambrogio</a> in Milan were built. It was known for its usage of the Roman arches, stained glass windows, and also its curved columns which commonly featured in cloisters. The main innovation of Italian Romanesque architecture was the vault, which had never been seen before in the history of Western architecture.<sup id="cite_ref-romanesque_415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-romanesque-415">[413]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The greatest flowering of Italian architecture took place during the Renaissance. <a href="/wiki/Filippo_Brunelleschi" title="Filippo Brunelleschi">Filippo Brunelleschi</a> made great contributions to architectural design with his dome for the Cathedral of Florence, a feat of engineering that had not been accomplished since antiquity.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[414]</a></sup> A popular achievement of Italian Renaissance architecture was St. Peter's Basilica, originally designed by <a href="/wiki/Donato_Bramante" title="Donato Bramante">Donato Bramante</a> in the early 16th century. Also, Andrea Palladio influenced architects throughout western Europe with the villas and palaces he designed in the middle and late 16th century; the city of <a href="/wiki/Vicenza" title="Vicenza">Vicenza</a>, with its twenty-three buildings designed by Palladio, and twenty-four <a href="/wiki/Palladian_Villas_of_the_Veneto" class="mw-redirect" title="Palladian Villas of the Veneto">Palladian Villas of the Veneto</a> are listed by UNESCO as part of a World Heritage Site named <a href="/wiki/City_of_Vicenza_and_the_Palladian_Villas_of_the_Veneto" title="City of Vicenza and the Palladian Villas of the Veneto">City of Vicenza and the Palladian Villas of the Veneto</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[415]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Baroque period produced several outstanding Italian architects in the 17th century, especially known for their churches. The most original work of all late Baroque and Rococo architecture is the <a href="/wiki/Palazzina_di_caccia_di_Stupinigi" class="mw-redirect" title="Palazzina di caccia di Stupinigi">Palazzina di caccia di Stupinigi</a>, dating back to the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[416]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Luigi_Vanvitelli" title="Luigi Vanvitelli">Luigi Vanvitelli</a> began in 1752 the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Caserta" title="Royal Palace of Caserta">Royal Palace of Caserta</a>. In this large complex, the grandiose Baroque style interiors and gardens are opposed to a more sober building envelope.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[417]</a></sup> In the late 18th and early 19th centuries Italy was affected by the Neoclassical architectural movement. Everything from villas, palaces, gardens, interiors and art began to be based on Roman and Greek themes.<sup id="cite_ref-Neoclassic_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Neoclassic-420">[418]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the Fascist period, the so-called "<a href="/wiki/Novecento_movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Novecento movement">Novecento movement</a>" flourished, based on the rediscovery of imperial Rome, with figures such as <a href="/wiki/Gio_Ponti" title="Gio Ponti">Gio Ponti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Muzio" title="Giovanni Muzio">Giovanni Muzio</a>. <a href="/wiki/Marcello_Piacentini" title="Marcello Piacentini">Marcello Piacentini</a>, responsible for the urban transformations of several cities in Italy and remembered for the disputed <a href="/wiki/Via_della_Conciliazione" title="Via della Conciliazione">Via della Conciliazione</a> in Rome, devised a form of simplified Neoclassicism.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[419]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_art">Visual art</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Art_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Art of Italy">Art of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Leonardo_da_Vinci_(1452-1519)_-_The_Last_Supper_(1495-1498).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg/310px-Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg/465px-Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg/620px-Leonardo_da_Vinci_%281452-1519%29_-_The_Last_Supper_%281495-1498%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5076" data-file-height="2645"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Leonardo_da_Vinci_(1452-1519)_-_The_Last_Supper_(1495-1498).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Last_Supper_(Leonardo_da_Vinci)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Last Supper (Leonardo da Vinci)">The Last Supper</a></i> (1494–1499), <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a>, Church of <a href="/wiki/Santa_Maria_delle_Grazie_(Milan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Santa Maria delle Grazie (Milan)">Santa Maria delle Grazie</a>, Milan
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The history of Italian visual arts is significant to the history of <a href="/wiki/Western_painting" title="Western painting">Western painting</a>. <a href="/wiki/Roman_art" title="Roman art">Roman art</a> was influenced by Greece and can in part be taken as a descendant of ancient Greek painting. Roman painting does have its own unique characteristics. The only surviving Roman paintings are wall paintings, many from villas in <a href="/wiki/Campania" title="Campania">Campania</a>, in Southern Italy. Such paintings can be grouped into four main "styles" or periods<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[420]</a></sup> and may contain the first examples of <a href="/wiki/Trompe-l%27%C5%93il" title="Trompe-l'œil">trompe-l'œil</a>, pseudo-perspective, and pure landscape.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[421]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Panel painting becomes more common during the <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_art" title="Romanesque art">Romanesque</a> period, under the heavy influence of Byzantine icons. Towards the middle of the 13th century, <a href="/wiki/Medieval_art" title="Medieval art">Medieval art</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gothic_painting" class="mw-redirect" title="Gothic painting">Gothic painting</a> became more realistic, with the beginnings of interest in the depiction of volume and perspective in Italy with <a href="/wiki/Cimabue" title="Cimabue">Cimabue</a> and then his pupil <a href="/wiki/Giotto" title="Giotto">Giotto</a>. From Giotto onwards, the treatment of composition by the best painters also became much more free and innovative. The two are considered to be the two great medieval masters of painting in western culture. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg/200px-Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="320" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg/300px-Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg/400px-Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2388" data-file-height="3824"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Michelangelo%27s_David_2015.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Michelangelo" title="Michelangelo">Michelangelo</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/David_(Michelangelo)" title="David (Michelangelo)">David</a></i> (1501–1504), <a href="/wiki/Galleria_dell%27Accademia" title="Galleria dell'Accademia">Galleria dell'Accademia</a>, Florence
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Renaissance" title="Italian Renaissance">Italian Renaissance</a> is said by many to be the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_(metaphor)" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Age (metaphor)">golden age</a> of painting; roughly spanning the 14th through the mid-17th centuries with a significant influence also out of the borders of modern Italy. In Italy artists like <a href="/wiki/Paolo_Uccello" title="Paolo Uccello">Paolo Uccello</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fra_Angelico" title="Fra Angelico">Fra Angelico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Masaccio" title="Masaccio">Masaccio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piero_della_Francesca" title="Piero della Francesca">Piero della Francesca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Mantegna" title="Andrea Mantegna">Andrea Mantegna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Filippo_Lippi" title="Filippo Lippi">Filippo Lippi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Giorgione" title="Giorgione">Giorgione</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tintoretto" title="Tintoretto">Tintoretto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sandro_Botticelli" title="Sandro Botticelli">Sandro Botticelli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michelangelo_Buonarroti" class="mw-redirect" title="Michelangelo Buonarroti">Michelangelo Buonarroti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Raphael" title="Raphael">Raphael</a>, <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Bellini" title="Giovanni Bellini">Giovanni Bellini</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Titian" title="Titian">Titian</a> took painting to a higher level through the use of <a href="/wiki/Perspective_(graphical)" title="Perspective (graphical)">perspective</a>, the study of <a href="/wiki/Human_anatomy" class="mw-redirect" title="Human anatomy">human anatomy</a> and proportion, and through their development of an unprecedented refinement in drawing and painting techniques. Michelangelo was an active sculptor from about 1500 to 1520, and his great masterpieces including his <i><a href="/wiki/David_(Michelangelo)" title="David (Michelangelo)">David</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Piet%C3%A0_(Michelangelo)" title="Pietà (Michelangelo)">Pietà</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Moses_(Michelangelo)" title="Moses (Michelangelo)">Moses</a></i>. Other prominent Renaissance sculptors include <a href="/wiki/Lorenzo_Ghiberti" title="Lorenzo Ghiberti">Lorenzo Ghiberti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luca_Della_Robbia" class="mw-redirect" title="Luca Della Robbia">Luca Della Robbia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donatello" title="Donatello">Donatello</a>, <a href="/wiki/Filippo_Brunelleschi" title="Filippo Brunelleschi">Filippo Brunelleschi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrea_del_Verrocchio" title="Andrea del Verrocchio">Andrea del Verrocchio</a>. </p>
      <p>In the 15th and 16th centuries, the <a href="/wiki/High_Renaissance" title="High Renaissance">High Renaissance</a> gave rise to a stylised art known as <a href="/wiki/Mannerism" title="Mannerism">Mannerism</a>. In place of the balanced compositions and rational approach to perspective that characterised art at the dawn of the 16th century, the Mannerists sought instability, artifice, and doubt. The unperturbed faces and gestures of <a href="/wiki/Piero_della_Francesca" title="Piero della Francesca">Piero della Francesca</a> and the calm Virgins of Raphael are replaced by the troubled expressions of <a href="/wiki/Pontormo" title="Pontormo">Pontormo</a> and the emotional intensity of <a href="/wiki/El_Greco" title="El Greco">El Greco</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sandro_Botticelli_-_La_nascita_di_Venere_-_Google_Art_Project_-_edited.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Sandro_Botticelli_-_La_nascita_di_Venere_-_Google_Art_Project_-_edited.jpg/310px-Sandro_Botticelli_-_La_nascita_di_Venere_-_Google_Art_Project_-_edited.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="195" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Sandro_Botticelli_-_La_nascita_di_Venere_-_Google_Art_Project_-_edited.jpg/465px-Sandro_Botticelli_-_La_nascita_di_Venere_-_Google_Art_Project_-_edited.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Sandro_Botticelli_-_La_nascita_di_Venere_-_Google_Art_Project_-_edited.jpg/620px-Sandro_Botticelli_-_La_nascita_di_Venere_-_Google_Art_Project_-_edited.jpg 2x" data-file-width="30000" data-file-height="18840"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sandro_Botticelli_-_La_nascita_di_Venere_-_Google_Art_Project_-_edited.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Birth_of_Venus" title="The Birth of Venus">The Birth of Venus</a></i> (1484–1486), <a href="/wiki/Sandro_Botticelli" title="Sandro Botticelli">Sandro Botticelli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uffizi" title="Uffizi">Uffizi</a> Gallery, Florence
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the 17th century, among the greatest painters of <a href="/wiki/Italian_Baroque" title="Italian Baroque">Italian Baroque</a> are <a href="/wiki/Caravaggio" title="Caravaggio">Caravaggio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Annibale_Carracci" title="Annibale Carracci">Annibale Carracci</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artemisia_Gentileschi" title="Artemisia Gentileschi">Artemisia Gentileschi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mattia_Preti" title="Mattia Preti">Mattia Preti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Saraceni" title="Carlo Saraceni">Carlo Saraceni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bartolomeo_Manfredi" title="Bartolomeo Manfredi">Bartolomeo Manfredi</a>. Subsequently, in the 18th century, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Rococo_art" title="Italian Rococo art">Italian Rococo</a> was mainly inspired by French Rococo, since France was the founding nation of that particular style, with artists such as <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Battista_Tiepolo" title="Giovanni Battista Tiepolo">Giovanni Battista Tiepolo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canaletto" title="Canaletto">Canaletto</a>. Italian Neoclassical sculpture focused, with <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Canova" title="Antonio Canova">Antonio Canova</a>'s nudes, on the idealist aspect of the movement. </p>
      <p>In the 19th century, major Italian <a href="/wiki/Romantic_painting" class="mw-redirect" title="Romantic painting">Romantic</a> painters were <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Hayez" title="Francesco Hayez">Francesco Hayez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Bezzuoli" title="Giuseppe Bezzuoli">Giuseppe Bezzuoli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Podesti" title="Francesco Podesti">Francesco Podesti</a>. <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">Impressionism</a> was brought from France to Italy by the <i><a href="/wiki/Macchiaioli" title="Macchiaioli">Macchiaioli</a></i>, led by <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Fattori" title="Giovanni Fattori">Giovanni Fattori</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Boldini" title="Giovanni Boldini">Giovanni Boldini</a>; <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">Realism</a> by <a href="/wiki/Gioacchino_Toma" title="Gioacchino Toma">Gioacchino Toma</a> and <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Pellizza_da_Volpedo" title="Giuseppe Pellizza da Volpedo">Giuseppe Pellizza da Volpedo</a>. In the 20th century, with <a href="/wiki/Futurism" title="Futurism">Futurism</a>, primarily through the works of <a href="/wiki/Umberto_Boccioni" title="Umberto Boccioni">Umberto Boccioni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Giacomo_Balla" title="Giacomo Balla">Giacomo Balla</a>, Italy rose again as a seminal country for artistic evolution in painting and sculpture. Futurism was succeeded by the metaphysical paintings of <a href="/wiki/Giorgio_de_Chirico" title="Giorgio de Chirico">Giorgio de Chirico</a>, who exerted a strong influence on the <a href="/wiki/Surrealists" class="mw-redirect" title="Surrealists">Surrealists</a> and generations of artists to follow like <a href="/wiki/Bruno_Caruso" title="Bruno Caruso">Bruno Caruso</a> and <a href="/wiki/Renato_Guttuso" title="Renato Guttuso">Renato Guttuso</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Literature_of_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Literature of Italy">Literature of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Formal Latin literature began in 240 BC, when the first stage play was performed in Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[422]</a></sup> Latin literature was, and still is, highly influential in the world, with numerous writers, poets, philosophers, and historians, such as <a href="/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder" title="Pliny the Elder">Pliny the Elder</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pliny_the_Younger" title="Pliny the Younger">Pliny the Younger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virgil" title="Virgil">Virgil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Horace" title="Horace">Horace</a>, <a href="/wiki/Propertius" title="Propertius">Propertius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ovid" title="Ovid">Ovid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Livy" title="Livy">Livy</a>. The Romans were also famous for their oral tradition, poetry, drama and epigrams.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[423]</a></sup> In early years of the 13th century, St. <a href="/wiki/Francis_of_Assisi" title="Francis of Assisi">Francis of Assisi</a> was considered the first Italian poet by literary critics, with his religious song <i><a href="/wiki/Canticle_of_the_Sun" title="Canticle of the Sun">Canticle of the Sun</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[424]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dante_Domenico_di_Michelino_Duomo_Florence.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Dante_Domenico_di_Michelino_Duomo_Florence.jpg/240px-Dante_Domenico_di_Michelino_Duomo_Florence.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="180" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Dante_Domenico_di_Michelino_Duomo_Florence.jpg/360px-Dante_Domenico_di_Michelino_Duomo_Florence.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Dante_Domenico_di_Michelino_Duomo_Florence.jpg/480px-Dante_Domenico_di_Michelino_Duomo_Florence.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1530" data-file-height="1150"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dante_Domenico_di_Michelino_Duomo_Florence.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Dante_Alighieri" title="Dante Alighieri">Dante</a> shown holding a copy of the <i><a href="/wiki/Divine_Comedy" title="Divine Comedy">Divine Comedy</a></i>, next to the entrance to <a href="/wiki/Inferno_(Dante)" title="Inferno (Dante)">Hell</a>, the mount of <a href="/wiki/Purgatorio_(Dante)" class="mw-redirect" title="Purgatorio (Dante)">Purgatory</a> and the city of Florence, with the spheres of <a href="/wiki/Paradiso_(Dante)" title="Paradiso (Dante)">Heaven</a> above, in <a href="/wiki/Domenico_di_Michelino" title="Domenico di Michelino">Michelino</a>'s fresco, 1465
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Another Italian voice originated in Sicily. At the court of Emperor Frederick II, who ruled the Sicilian kingdom during the first half of the 13th century, lyrics modelled on Provençal forms and themes were written in a refined version of the local vernacular. The most important of these poets was the notary <a href="/wiki/Giacomo_da_Lentini" title="Giacomo da Lentini">Giacomo da Lentini</a>, inventor of the <a href="/wiki/Sonnet" title="Sonnet">sonnet</a> form, though the most famous early sonneteer was <a href="/wiki/Petrarch" title="Petrarch">Petrarch</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[425]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Guido_Guinizelli" title="Guido Guinizelli">Guido Guinizelli</a> is considered the founder of the <i><a href="/wiki/Dolce_Stil_Novo" title="Dolce Stil Novo">Dolce Stil Novo</a></i>, a school that added a philosophical dimension to traditional love poetry. This new understanding of love, expressed in a smooth, pure style, influenced <a href="/wiki/Guido_Cavalcanti" title="Guido Cavalcanti">Guido Cavalcanti</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">Florentine</a> poet <a href="/wiki/Dante_Alighieri" title="Dante Alighieri">Dante Alighieri</a>, who established the basis of the modern <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian language</a>; his greatest work, the <i><a href="/wiki/Divine_Comedy" title="Divine Comedy">Divine Comedy</a></i>, is considered among the foremost literary statements produced in Europe during the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>; furthermore, the poet invented the difficult <i><a href="/wiki/Terza_rima" title="Terza rima">terza rima</a></i>. The two great writers of the 14th century, Petrarch and <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Boccaccio" title="Giovanni Boccaccio">Giovanni Boccaccio</a>, sought out and imitated the works of antiquity and cultivated their own artistic personalities. Petrarch achieved fame through his collection of poems, <i><a href="/wiki/Il_Canzoniere" title="Il Canzoniere">Il Canzoniere</a></i>. Petrarch's love poetry served as a model for centuries. Equally influential was Boccaccio's <i><a href="/wiki/The_Decameron" title="The Decameron">The Decameron</a></i>, one of the most popular collections of short stories ever written.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica-Shakespeare_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-Shakespeare-428">[426]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Portrait_of_Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli_by_Santi_di_Tito.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Portrait_of_Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli_by_Santi_di_Tito.jpg/170px-Portrait_of_Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli_by_Santi_di_Tito.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="219" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Portrait_of_Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli_by_Santi_di_Tito.jpg/255px-Portrait_of_Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli_by_Santi_di_Tito.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Portrait_of_Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli_by_Santi_di_Tito.jpg/340px-Portrait_of_Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli_by_Santi_di_Tito.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1244" data-file-height="1600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Portrait_of_Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli_by_Santi_di_Tito.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli" title="Niccolò Machiavelli">Niccolò Machiavelli</a>, founder of modern political science and ethics
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italian Renaissance authors produced a number of important works. <a href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli" title="Niccolò Machiavelli">Niccolò Machiavelli</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Prince" title="The Prince">The Prince</a></i> is one of the world's most famous essays on political science and modern philosophy, in which the "effectual truth" is taken to be more important than any abstract ideal. Another important work of the period, <a href="/wiki/Ludovico_Ariosto" title="Ludovico Ariosto">Ludovico Ariosto</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Orlando_Furioso" title="Orlando Furioso">Orlando Furioso</a></i>, continuation of <a href="/wiki/Matteo_Maria_Boiardo" title="Matteo Maria Boiardo">Matteo Maria Boiardo</a>'s unfinished romance <i><a href="/wiki/Orlando_Innamorato" title="Orlando Innamorato">Orlando Innamorato</a></i>, is perhaps the greatest chivalry poem ever written. <a href="/wiki/Baldassare_Castiglione" title="Baldassare Castiglione">Baldassare Castiglione</a>'s dialogue <i><a href="/wiki/The_Book_of_the_Courtier" title="The Book of the Courtier">The Book of the Courtier</a></i> describes the ideal of the perfect court gentleman and of spiritual beauty. The lyric poet <a href="/wiki/Torquato_Tasso" title="Torquato Tasso">Torquato Tasso</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Delivered" title="Jerusalem Delivered">Jerusalem Delivered</a></i> wrote a Christian epic, making use of the <i><a href="/wiki/Ottava_rima" title="Ottava rima">ottava rima</a></i>, with attention to the Aristotelian canons of unity. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Francesco_Straparola" title="Giovanni Francesco Straparola">Giovanni Francesco Straparola</a> and <a href="/wiki/Giambattista_Basile" title="Giambattista Basile">Giambattista Basile</a>, which have written <i><a href="/wiki/The_Facetious_Nights_of_Straparola" title="The Facetious Nights of Straparola">The Facetious Nights of Straparola</a></i> (1550–1555) and the <i><a href="/wiki/Pentamerone" title="Pentamerone">Pentamerone</a></i> (1634) respectively, printed some of the first known versions of fairy tales in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[427]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[428]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[429]</a></sup> In the early 17th century, some literary masterpieces were created, such as <a href="/wiki/Giambattista_Marino" title="Giambattista Marino">Giambattista Marino</a>'s long mythological poem, <i><a href="/wiki/Giambattista_Marino#L'Adone" title="Giambattista Marino">L'Adone</a></i>. The Baroque period also produced the clear scientific prose of <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Galilei" title="Galileo Galilei">Galileo</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Tommaso_Campanella" title="Tommaso Campanella">Tommaso Campanella</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_City_of_the_Sun" title="The City of the Sun">The City of the Sun</a></i>, a description of a perfect society ruled by a philosopher-priest. At the end of the 17th century, the <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_Arcadia" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy of Arcadia">Arcadians</a> began a movement to restore simplicity and classical restraint to poetry, as in <a href="/wiki/Metastasio" class="mw-redirect" title="Metastasio">Metastasio</a>'s heroic melodramas. In the 18th century, playwright <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Goldoni" title="Carlo Goldoni">Carlo Goldoni</a> created full written plays, many portraying the middle class of his day. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pinocchio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Pinocchio.jpg/150px-Pinocchio.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="207" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Pinocchio.jpg/225px-Pinocchio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Pinocchio.jpg/300px-Pinocchio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="705"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pinocchio.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Pinocchio" title="The Adventures of Pinocchio">Pinocchio</a></i> is the world's most translated non-religious book<sup id="cite_ref-Gasparini_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gasparini-432">[430]</a></sup> and a canonical piece of children's literature.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[431]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Romanticism coincided with some ideas of the <i><a href="/wiki/Risorgimento" class="mw-redirect" title="Risorgimento">Risorgimento</a></i>, the patriotic movement that brought Italy political unity and freedom from foreign domination. Italian writers embraced Romanticism in the early 19th century. The time of Italy's rebirth was heralded by the poets <a href="/wiki/Vittorio_Alfieri" title="Vittorio Alfieri">Vittorio Alfieri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ugo_Foscolo" title="Ugo Foscolo">Ugo Foscolo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Giacomo_Leopardi" title="Giacomo Leopardi">Giacomo Leopardi</a>. The works by <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Manzoni" title="Alessandro Manzoni">Alessandro Manzoni</a>, the leading Italian Romantic, are a symbol of the Italian unification for their patriotic message and because of his efforts in the development of the modern, unified Italian language; his novel <i><a href="/wiki/The_Betrothed_(Manzoni_novel)" title="The Betrothed (Manzoni novel)">The Betrothed</a></i> was the first Italian historical novel to glorify Christian values of justice and Providence, and it has been called the most famous and widely read novel in the Italian language.<sup id="cite_ref-Archibald_Colquhoun_1954_434-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Archibald_Colquhoun_1954-434">[432]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the late 19th century, a realistic literary movement called <i><a href="/wiki/Verismo_(literature)" title="Verismo (literature)">Verismo</a></i> played a major role in Italian literature; <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Verga" title="Giovanni Verga">Giovanni Verga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luigi_Capuana" title="Luigi Capuana">Luigi Capuana</a> were its main exponents. In the same period, <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Salgari" title="Emilio Salgari">Emilio Salgari</a>, writer of action-adventure <a href="/wiki/Swashbuckler" title="Swashbuckler">swashbucklers</a> and a pioneer of science fiction, published his <i><a href="/wiki/Sandokan" title="Sandokan">Sandokan</a></i> series.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[433]</a></sup> In 1883, <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Collodi" title="Carlo Collodi">Carlo Collodi</a> also published the novel <i><a href="/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Pinocchio" title="The Adventures of Pinocchio">The Adventures of Pinocchio</a></i>, the most celebrated children's classic by an Italian author and the most translated non-religious book in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Gasparini_432-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gasparini-432">[430]</a></sup> A movement called <a href="/wiki/Futurism" title="Futurism">Futurism</a> influenced Italian literature in the early 20th century. <a href="/wiki/Filippo_Tommaso_Marinetti" title="Filippo Tommaso Marinetti">Filippo Tommaso Marinetti</a> wrote <i><a href="/wiki/Manifesto_of_Futurism" title="Manifesto of Futurism">Manifesto of Futurism</a></i>, called for the use of language and metaphors that glorified the speed, dynamism, and violence of the machine age.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[434]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Modern literary figures and Nobel laureates are <a href="/wiki/Gabriele_D%27Annunzio" title="Gabriele D'Annunzio">Gabriele D'Annunzio</a> from 1889 to 1910, nationalist poet <a href="/wiki/Giosu%C3%A8_Carducci" title="Giosuè Carducci">Giosuè Carducci</a> in 1906, realist writer <a href="/wiki/Grazia_Deledda" title="Grazia Deledda">Grazia Deledda</a> in 1926, modern theatre author <a href="/wiki/Luigi_Pirandello" title="Luigi Pirandello">Luigi Pirandello</a> in 1936, short stories writer <a href="/wiki/Italo_Calvino" title="Italo Calvino">Italo Calvino</a> in 1960, poets <a href="/wiki/Salvatore_Quasimodo" title="Salvatore Quasimodo">Salvatore Quasimodo</a> in 1959 and <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Montale" title="Eugenio Montale">Eugenio Montale</a> in 1975, <a href="/wiki/Umberto_Eco" title="Umberto Eco">Umberto Eco</a> in 1980, and satirist and theatre author <a href="/wiki/Dario_Fo" title="Dario Fo">Dario Fo</a> in 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[435]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy">Philosophy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Italian_philosophy" title="Italian philosophy">Italian philosophy</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Over the ages, Italian philosophy and literature had a vast influence on <a href="/wiki/Western_philosophy" title="Western philosophy">Western philosophy</a>, beginning with the Greeks and Romans, and going onto <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_humanism" title="Renaissance humanism">Renaissance humanism</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a> and <a href="/wiki/Modern_philosophy" title="Modern philosophy">modern philosophy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Garin_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Garin-438">[436]</a></sup> Philosophy was brought to Italy by <a href="/wiki/Pythagoras" title="Pythagoras">Pythagoras</a>, founder of the Italian school of philosophy in <a href="/wiki/Crotone" title="Crotone">Crotone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[437]</a></sup> Major Italian philosophers of the <a href="/wiki/Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia">Greek period</a> include <a href="/wiki/Xenophanes" title="Xenophanes">Xenophanes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parmenides" title="Parmenides">Parmenides</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zeno_of_Elea" title="Zeno of Elea">Zeno</a>, <a href="/wiki/Empedocles" title="Empedocles">Empedocles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gorgias" title="Gorgias">Gorgias</a>. Roman philosophers include <a href="/wiki/Cicero" title="Cicero">Cicero</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lucretius" title="Lucretius">Lucretius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seneca_the_Younger" title="Seneca the Younger">Seneca the Younger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Musonius_Rufus" class="mw-redirect" title="Musonius Rufus">Musonius Rufus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Plutarch" title="Plutarch">Plutarch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epictetus" title="Epictetus">Epictetus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marcus_Aurelius" title="Marcus Aurelius">Marcus Aurelius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clement_of_Alexandria" title="Clement of Alexandria">Clement of Alexandria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sextus_Empiricus" title="Sextus Empiricus">Sextus Empiricus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_of_Aphrodisias" title="Alexander of Aphrodisias">Alexander of Aphrodisias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Plotinus" title="Plotinus">Plotinus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porphyry_(philosopher)" title="Porphyry (philosopher)">Porphyry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iamblichus_(philosopher)" class="mw-redirect" title="Iamblichus (philosopher)">Iamblichus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Augustine_of_Hippo" title="Augustine of Hippo">Augustine of Hippo</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Philoponus" title="John Philoponus">Philoponus of Alexandria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anicius_Manlius_Severinus_Boethius" class="mw-redirect" title="Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius">Boethius</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Garin_438-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Garin-438">[436]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Famous_Italian_philosophers.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Famous_Italian_philosophers.jpg/240px-Famous_Italian_philosophers.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="300" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Famous_Italian_philosophers.jpg/360px-Famous_Italian_philosophers.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Famous_Italian_philosophers.jpg/480px-Famous_Italian_philosophers.jpg 2x" data-file-width="820" data-file-height="1024"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Famous_Italian_philosophers.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Clockwise from top left: <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Aquinas" title="Thomas Aquinas">Thomas Aquinas</a>, proponent of natural theology and the Father of <i><a href="/wiki/Thomism" title="Thomism">Thomism</a></i>;<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[438]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Giordano_Bruno" title="Giordano Bruno">Giordano Bruno</a>, one of the major scientific figures of the Western world;<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[439]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cesare_Beccaria" title="Cesare Beccaria">Cesare Beccaria</a>, considered the Father of criminal justice and modern criminal law;<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_442-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-442">[440]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Maria_Montessori" title="Maria Montessori">Maria Montessori</a>, credited with the creation of the <i><a href="/wiki/Montessori_education" title="Montessori education">Montessori education</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Montessori_443-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Montessori-443">[441]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italian Medieval philosophy was mainly Christian, and included several important philosophers and theologians such as St <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Aquinas" title="Thomas Aquinas">Thomas Aquinas</a>, the foremost classical proponent of <a href="/wiki/Natural_theology" title="Natural theology">natural theology</a> and the father of <a href="/wiki/Thomism" title="Thomism">Thomism</a>, who reintroduced <a href="/wiki/Aristotelianism" title="Aristotelianism">Aristotelian philosophy</a> to Christianity.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[442]</a></sup> Notable Renaissance philosophers include: <a href="/wiki/Giordano_Bruno" title="Giordano Bruno">Giordano Bruno</a>, one of the major scientific figures of the western world; <a href="/wiki/Marsilio_Ficino" title="Marsilio Ficino">Marsilio Ficino</a>, one of the most influential humanist philosophers of the period; and <a href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli" title="Niccolò Machiavelli">Niccolò Machiavelli</a>, one of the main founders of modern <a href="/wiki/Political_science" title="Political science">political science</a>. Machiavelli's most famous work was <i><a href="/wiki/The_Prince" title="The Prince">The Prince</a></i>, whose contribution to the history of political thought is the fundamental break between political <a href="/wiki/Realism_(international_relations)" title="Realism (international relations)">realism</a> and political <a href="/wiki/Idealism" title="Idealism">idealism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[443]</a></sup> Italy was also affected by the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a>, a movement which was a consequence of the Renaissance.<sup id="cite_ref-history-world.org_446-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-history-world.org-446">[444]</a></sup> Cities with important universities such as Padua, Bologna and Naples remained great centres of scholarship and the intellect, with several philosophers such as <a href="/wiki/Giambattista_Vico" title="Giambattista Vico">Giambattista Vico</a> (who is widely regarded as being the founder of modern Italian philosophy)<sup id="cite_ref-maritain.nd.edu_447-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-maritain.nd.edu-447">[445]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Genovesi" title="Antonio Genovesi">Antonio Genovesi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-history-world.org_446-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-history-world.org-446">[444]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cesare_Beccaria" title="Cesare Beccaria">Cesare Beccaria</a> was also one of the greatest Italian Enlightenment writers and is now considered one of the fathers of <a href="/wiki/Classical_school_(criminology)" title="Classical school (criminology)">classical criminal theory</a> as well as modern <a href="/wiki/Penology" title="Penology">penology</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_442-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-442">[440]</a></sup> Beccaria is famous for his <i><a href="/wiki/On_Crimes_and_Punishments" title="On Crimes and Punishments">On Crimes and Punishments</a></i> (1764), a treatise that served as one of the earliest prominent condemnations of torture and the death penalty and thus a landmark work in anti-death penalty philosophy.<sup id="cite_ref-history-world.org_446-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-history-world.org-446">[444]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy also had a renowned philosophical movement in the 1800s, with <a href="/wiki/Idealism" title="Idealism">Idealism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sensism" class="mw-redirect" title="Sensism">Sensism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Empiricism" title="Empiricism">Empiricism</a>.
