The main Sensist Italian philosophers were <a href="/wiki/Melchiorre_Gioja" class="mw-redirect" title="Melchiorre Gioja">Melchiorre Gioja</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gian_Domenico_Romagnosi" title="Gian Domenico Romagnosi">Gian Domenico Romagnosi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-maritain.nd.edu_447-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-maritain.nd.edu-447">[445]</a></sup> Criticism of the Sensist movement came from other philosophers such as <a href="/wiki/Pasquale_Galluppi" title="Pasquale Galluppi">Pasquale Galluppi</a> (1770–1846), who affirmed that <i>a priori</i> relationships were synthetic.<sup id="cite_ref-maritain.nd.edu_447-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-maritain.nd.edu-447">[445]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Rosmini" title="Antonio Rosmini">Antonio Rosmini</a>, instead, was the founder of <a href="/wiki/Italian_Idealism" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian Idealism">Italian Idealism</a>. During the late 19th and 20th centuries, there were also several other movements which gained some form of popularity in Italy, such as <a href="/wiki/Ontologism" title="Ontologism">Ontologism</a> (whose main philosopher was <a href="/wiki/Vincenzo_Gioberti" title="Vincenzo Gioberti">Vincenzo Gioberti</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[446]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anarchism_in_Italy" title="Anarchism in Italy">anarchism</a>, communism, socialism, futurism, fascism and Christian democracy. <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Gentile" title="Giovanni Gentile">Giovanni Gentile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Benedetto_Croce" title="Benedetto Croce">Benedetto Croce</a> were two of the most significant 20th-century Idealist philosophers. Anarcho-communism first fully formed into its modern strain within the Italian section of the <a href="/wiki/First_International" class="mw-redirect" title="First International">First International</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Nunzio_Pernicone_pp._111-113_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nunzio_Pernicone_pp._111-113-449">[447]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Gramsci" title="Antonio Gramsci">Antonio Gramsci</a> remains an important philosopher within Marxist and communist theory, credited with creating the theory of <a href="/wiki/Cultural_hegemony" title="Cultural hegemony">cultural hegemony</a>. Italian philosophers were also influential in the development of the non-Marxist <a href="/wiki/Liberal_socialism" title="Liberal socialism">liberal socialism</a> philosophy, including <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Rosselli" title="Carlo Rosselli">Carlo Rosselli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norberto_Bobbio" title="Norberto Bobbio">Norberto Bobbio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piero_Gobetti" title="Piero Gobetti">Piero Gobetti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aldo_Capitini" title="Aldo Capitini">Aldo Capitini</a>. In the 1960s, many Italian left-wing activists adopted the <a href="/wiki/Anti-authoritarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-authoritarian">anti-authoritarian</a> pro-working class leftist theories that would become known as <a href="/wiki/Autonomism" title="Autonomism">autonomism</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Operaismo" class="mw-redirect" title="Operaismo">operaismo</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[448]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Early and important <a href="/wiki/Feminism_in_Italy" title="Feminism in Italy">Italian feminists</a> include <a href="/wiki/Sibilla_Aleramo" title="Sibilla Aleramo">Sibilla Aleramo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alaide_Gualberta_Beccari" title="Alaide Gualberta Beccari">Alaide Gualberta Beccari</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Anna_Maria_Mozzoni" title="Anna Maria Mozzoni">Anna Maria Mozzoni</a>, though proto-feminist philosophies had previously been touched upon by earlier Italian writers such as <a href="/wiki/Christine_de_Pizan" title="Christine de Pizan">Christine de Pizan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moderata_Fonte" title="Moderata Fonte">Moderata Fonte</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lucrezia_Marinella" title="Lucrezia Marinella">Lucrezia Marinella</a>. Italian physician and educator <a href="/wiki/Maria_Montessori" title="Maria Montessori">Maria Montessori</a> is credited with the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Montessori_education" title="Montessori education">philosophy of education that bears her name</a>, an educational philosophy now practiced throughout the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Montessori_443-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Montessori-443">[441]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Peano" title="Giuseppe Peano">Giuseppe Peano</a> was one of the founders of analytic philosophy and contemporary philosophy of mathematics. Recent analytic philosophers include <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Penco" title="Carlo Penco">Carlo Penco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gloria_Origgi" title="Gloria Origgi">Gloria Origgi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pieranna_Garavaso" title="Pieranna Garavaso">Pieranna Garavaso</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luciano_Floridi" title="Luciano Floridi">Luciano Floridi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Garin_438-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Garin-438">[436]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theatre">Theatre</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Commedia_dell%27arte" title="Commedia dell'arte">Commedia dell'arte</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_ancient_Rome" title="Theatre of ancient Rome">Theatre of ancient Rome</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Teatro_alla_Scala_interior_Milan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Teatro_alla_Scala_interior_Milan.jpg/310px-Teatro_alla_Scala_interior_Milan.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Teatro_alla_Scala_interior_Milan.jpg/465px-Teatro_alla_Scala_interior_Milan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Teatro_alla_Scala_interior_Milan.jpg/620px-Teatro_alla_Scala_interior_Milan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="10375" data-file-height="4388"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Teatro_alla_Scala_interior_Milan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/La_Scala" title="La Scala">La Scala</a> opera house
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italian theatre can be traced back to the Roman tradition. The <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_ancient_Rome" title="Theatre of ancient Rome">theatre of ancient Rome</a> was a thriving and diverse art form, ranging from festival performances of street theatre, nude dancing, and acrobatics, to the staging of <a href="/wiki/Plautus" title="Plautus">Plautus</a>'s broadly appealing situation comedies, to the high-style, verbally elaborate tragedies of <a href="/wiki/Seneca_the_Younger" title="Seneca the Younger">Seneca</a>. Although Rome had a native tradition of performance, the <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenization</a> of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_ancient_Rome" title="Culture of ancient Rome">Roman culture</a> in the 3rd century BCE had a profound and energising effect on Roman theatre and encouraged the development of Latin literature of the highest quality for the stage. As with many other literary genres, Roman dramatists was heavily influenced or tended to adapt from the Greek. For example, Seneca's <i><a href="/wiki/Phaedra_(Seneca)" title="Phaedra (Seneca)">Phaedra</a></i> was based on that of <a href="/wiki/Euripides" title="Euripides">Euripides</a>, and many of the comedies of <a href="/wiki/Plautus" title="Plautus">Plautus</a> were direct translations of works by <a href="/wiki/Menander" title="Menander">Menander</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[449]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Statue_in_legno_e_porcellana_coi_personaggi_della_commedia_dell%27arte,_01_pantalone_e_arlecchino.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Statue_in_legno_e_porcellana_coi_personaggi_della_commedia_dell%27arte%2C_01_pantalone_e_arlecchino.jpg/170px-Statue_in_legno_e_porcellana_coi_personaggi_della_commedia_dell%27arte%2C_01_pantalone_e_arlecchino.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="207" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Statue_in_legno_e_porcellana_coi_personaggi_della_commedia_dell%27arte%2C_01_pantalone_e_arlecchino.jpg/255px-Statue_in_legno_e_porcellana_coi_personaggi_della_commedia_dell%27arte%2C_01_pantalone_e_arlecchino.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Statue_in_legno_e_porcellana_coi_personaggi_della_commedia_dell%27arte%2C_01_pantalone_e_arlecchino.jpg/340px-Statue_in_legno_e_porcellana_coi_personaggi_della_commedia_dell%27arte%2C_01_pantalone_e_arlecchino.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1852" data-file-height="2256"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Statue_in_legno_e_porcellana_coi_personaggi_della_commedia_dell%27arte,_01_pantalone_e_arlecchino.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Statues of <a href="/wiki/Pantalone" title="Pantalone">Pantalone</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harlequin" title="Harlequin">Harlequin</a>, two stock characters from the <i><a href="/wiki/Commedia_dell%27arte" title="Commedia dell'arte">Commedia dell'arte</a></i>, in the <a href="/wiki/Museo_Teatrale_alla_Scala" title="Museo Teatrale alla Scala">Museo Teatrale alla Scala</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the 16th century and on into the 18th century, <a href="/wiki/Commedia_dell%27arte" title="Commedia dell'arte">Commedia dell'arte</a> was a form of <a href="/wiki/Improvisational_theatre" title="Improvisational theatre">improvisational theatre</a>, and it is still performed today. Travelling troupes of players would set up an outdoor stage and provide amusement in the form of <a href="/wiki/Juggling" title="Juggling">juggling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Acrobatics" title="Acrobatics">acrobatics</a> and, more typically, humorous plays based on a repertoire of established characters with a rough storyline, called <i><a href="/wiki/Canovaccio" title="Canovaccio">canovaccio</a></i>. Plays did not originate from written drama but from scenarios called <a href="/wiki/Lazzi" title="Lazzi">lazzi</a>, which were loose frameworks that provided the situations, complications, and outcome of the action, around which the actors would improvise. The characters of the <i>commedia</i> usually represent fixed social types and <a href="/wiki/Stock_character" title="Stock character">stock characters</a>, each of which has a distinct <a href="/wiki/Costumes_in_commedia_dell%27arte" title="Costumes in commedia dell'arte">costume</a>, such as foolish old men, devious servants, or military officers full of false <a href="/wiki/Bravery" class="mw-redirect" title="Bravery">bravado</a>. The main categories of these characters include servants, old men, lovers, and captains.<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[450]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The first recorded Commedia dell'arte performances came from Rome as early as 1551,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKatritzky200682_453-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKatritzky200682-453">[451]</a></sup> and was performed outdoors in temporary venues by professional actors who were costumed and masked, as opposed to <i lang="it" title="Italian-language text">commedia erudita</i>, which were written comedies, presented indoors by untrained and unmasked actors.<sup id="cite_ref-Rudlin_454-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rudlin-454">[452]</a></sup> By the mid-16th century, specific troupes of <i>commedia</i> performers began to coalesce, and by 1568 the <a href="/wiki/I_Gelosi" title="I Gelosi">Gelosi</a> became a distinct company. <i>Commedia</i> often performed inside in court theatres or halls, and also as some fixed theatres such as Teatro Baldrucca in Florence. Flaminio Scala, who had been a minor performer in the Gelosi published the scenarios of the <i>commedia dell'arte</i> around the start of the 17th century, really in an effort to legitimize the form—and ensure its legacy. These scenari are highly structured and built around the symmetry of the various types in duet: two <i lang="it" title="Italian-language text">zanni</i>, <i lang="it" title="Italian-language text">vecchi</i>, <i lang="it" title="Italian-language text">inamorate</i> and <i lang="it" title="Italian-language text">inamorati</i>, among others.<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[453]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dario_Fo_in_Venice_Film_Festival_02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Dario_Fo_in_Venice_Film_Festival_02.jpg/220px-Dario_Fo_in_Venice_Film_Festival_02.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Dario_Fo_in_Venice_Film_Festival_02.jpg/330px-Dario_Fo_in_Venice_Film_Festival_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Dario_Fo_in_Venice_Film_Festival_02.jpg/440px-Dario_Fo_in_Venice_Film_Festival_02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3595" data-file-height="2461"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dario_Fo_in_Venice_Film_Festival_02.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Dario_Fo" title="Dario Fo">Dario Fo</a>, one of the most widely performed playwrights in modern theatre, received international acclaim for his highly <a href="/wiki/Improvisational_theatre" title="Improvisational theatre">improvisational</a> style.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[454]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[455]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In <i>commedia dell'arte</i>, female roles were played by women, documented as early as the 1560s, making them the first known professional actresses in Europe since antiquity. <a href="/wiki/Lucrezia_Di_Siena" title="Lucrezia Di Siena">Lucrezia Di Siena</a>, whose name is on a contract of actors from 10 October 1564, has been referred to as the first Italian actress known by name, with <a href="/wiki/Vincenza_Armani" title="Vincenza Armani">Vincenza Armani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Flaminia" title="Barbara Flaminia">Barbara Flaminia</a> as the first primadonnas and the first well documented actresses in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458">[456]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ballet" title="Ballet">Ballet</a> dance genre also originated in Italy. It began during the Italian Renaissance court as an outgrowth of court pageantry,<sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[457]</a></sup> where aristocratic weddings were lavish celebrations. Court musicians and dancers collaborated to provide elaborate entertainment for them.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[458]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Domenico_da_Piacenza" title="Domenico da Piacenza">Domenico da Piacenza</a> was one of the first dancing masters. Along with his students, <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Cornazzano" title="Antonio Cornazzano">Antonio Cornazzano</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guglielmo_Ebreo" class="mw-redirect" title="Guglielmo Ebreo">Guglielmo Ebreo</a>, he was trained in dance and responsible for teaching nobles the art. Da Piacenza left one work: <i> De arte saltandi et choreus ducendi</i> (On the art of dancing and conducting dances), which was put together by his students. </p>
      <p>At first, ballets were woven in to the midst of an opera to allow the audience a moment of relief from the dramatic intensity. By the mid-seventeenth century, Italian ballets in their entirety were performed in between the acts of an opera. Over time, Italian ballets became a more beloved and important part of theatrical life: ballet companies in Italy's major opera houses employed an average of four to twelve dancers; in 1815 many companies employed anywhere from eighty to one hundred dancers.<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">[459]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Carlo_Goldoni" title="Carlo Goldoni">Carlo Goldoni</a>, who wrote a few scenarios starting in 1734, superseded the comedy of masks and the comedy of intrigue by representations of actual life and manners through the characters and their behaviours. He rightly maintained that Italian life and manners were susceptible of artistic treatment such as had not been given them before. Italian theatre has been active in producing contemporary European work and in staging important revivals, including the works of <a href="/wiki/Luigi_Pirandello" title="Luigi Pirandello">Luigi Pirandello</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dario_Fo" title="Dario Fo">Dario Fo</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Teatro_di_San_Carlo" title="Teatro di San Carlo">Teatro di San Carlo</a> in Naples is the oldest continuously active venue for public opera in the world, opening in 1737, decades before both the Milan's <a href="/wiki/La_Scala" title="La Scala">La Scala</a> and Venice's <a href="/wiki/La_Fenice" title="La Fenice">La Fenice</a> theatres.<sup id="cite_ref-SanCarlo_462-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SanCarlo-462">[460]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Italy" title="Music of Italy">Music of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Giacomo_Puccini_pianoforte.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Giacomo_Puccini_pianoforte.jpg/220px-Giacomo_Puccini_pianoforte.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Giacomo_Puccini_pianoforte.jpg/330px-Giacomo_Puccini_pianoforte.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Giacomo_Puccini_pianoforte.jpg/440px-Giacomo_Puccini_pianoforte.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1152" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Giacomo_Puccini_pianoforte.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Giacomo_Puccini" title="Giacomo Puccini">Giacomo Puccini</a>, Italian composer whose operas, including <i><a href="/wiki/La_boh%C3%A8me" title="La bohème">La bohème</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Tosca" title="Tosca">Tosca</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Madama_Butterfly" title="Madama Butterfly">Madama Butterfly</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Turandot" title="Turandot">Turandot</a></i>, are among the most frequently worldwide performed in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_important_operas" class="mw-redirect" title="List of important operas">standard repertoire</a><sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[461]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[462]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>From <a href="/wiki/Italian_folk_music" title="Italian folk music">folk music</a> to <a href="/wiki/European_classical_music" class="mw-redirect" title="European classical music">classical</a>, music has always played an important role in Italian culture. Instruments associated with classical music, including the piano and violin, were invented in Italy,<sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465">[463]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[464]</a></sup> and many of the prevailing classical music forms, such as the <a href="/wiki/Symphony" title="Symphony">symphony</a>, concerto, and <a href="/wiki/Sonata" title="Sonata">sonata</a>, can trace their roots back to innovations of 16th- and 17th-century Italian music. </p>
      <p>Italy's most famous composers include the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Renaissance_composers#Italian" title="List of Renaissance composers">Renaissance composers</a> <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Pierluigi_da_Palestrina" title="Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina">Palestrina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Claudio_Monteverdi" title="Claudio Monteverdi">Monteverdi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Gesualdo" title="Carlo Gesualdo">Gesualdo</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Baroque_composers" title="List of Baroque composers">Baroque composers</a> <a href="/wiki/Domenico_Scarlatti" title="Domenico Scarlatti">Scarlatti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arcangelo_Corelli" title="Arcangelo Corelli">Corelli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Vivaldi" title="Antonio Vivaldi">Vivaldi</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Classical_era_composers" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Classical era composers">Classical composers</a> <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Paisiello" title="Giovanni Paisiello">Paisiello</a>, <a href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Paganini" title="Niccolò Paganini">Paganini</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gioachino_Rossini" title="Gioachino Rossini">Rossini</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Romantic-era_composers" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Romantic-era composers">Romantic composers</a> <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Verdi" title="Giuseppe Verdi">Verdi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Giacomo_Puccini" title="Giacomo Puccini">Puccini</a>. Modern Italian composers such as <a href="/wiki/Luciano_Berio" title="Luciano Berio">Berio</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luigi_Nono_(composer)" class="mw-redirect" title="Luigi Nono (composer)">Nono</a> proved significant in the development of <a href="/wiki/Experimental_music" title="Experimental music">experimental</a> and <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic music</a>. While the classical music tradition still holds strong in Italy, as evidenced by the fame of its innumerable opera houses, such as <i><a href="/wiki/La_Scala" title="La Scala">La Scala</a></i> of Milan and <i><a href="/wiki/Teatro_di_San_Carlo" title="Teatro di San Carlo">San Carlo</a></i> of Naples (the oldest continuously active venue for public opera in the world),<sup id="cite_ref-SanCarlo_462-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SanCarlo-462">[460]</a></sup> and performers such as the pianist <a href="/wiki/Maurizio_Pollini" title="Maurizio Pollini">Maurizio Pollini</a> and tenor <a href="/wiki/Luciano_Pavarotti" title="Luciano Pavarotti">Luciano Pavarotti</a>, Italians have been no less appreciative of their thriving contemporary music scene. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg/220px-Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg/330px-Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg/440px-Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="334"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Luciano_Pavarotti_in_Saint_Petersburg.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Luciano_Pavarotti" title="Luciano Pavarotti">Luciano Pavarotti</a>, considered one of the finest tenors of the 20th century and the "King of the <a href="/wiki/High_C" class="mw-redirect" title="High C">High Cs</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[465]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy is widely known for being the birthplace of opera.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.co.uk_468-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.co.uk-468">[466]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Italian_opera" title="Italian opera">Italian opera</a> was believed to have been founded in the early 17th century, in cities such as <a href="/wiki/Mantua" title="Mantua">Mantua</a> and <a href="/wiki/Venice" title="Venice">Venice</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.co.uk_468-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.co.uk-468">[466]</a></sup> Later, works and pieces composed by native Italian composers of the 19th and early 20th centuries, such as <a href="/wiki/Rossini" class="mw-redirect" title="Rossini">Rossini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vincenzo_Bellini" title="Vincenzo Bellini">Bellini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donizetti" class="mw-redirect" title="Donizetti">Donizetti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Verdi" class="mw-redirect" title="Verdi">Verdi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Puccini" class="mw-redirect" title="Puccini">Puccini</a>, are among the most famous operas ever written and today are performed in opera houses across the world. La Scala operahouse in Milan is also renowned as one of the best in the world. Famous Italian opera singers include <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Caruso" title="Enrico Caruso">Enrico Caruso</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Bonci" title="Alessandro Bonci">Alessandro Bonci</a>. </p>
      <p>Introduced in the early 1920s, <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a> took a particularly strong foothold in Italy, and remained popular despite the xenophobic cultural policies of the Fascist regime. Today, the most notable centres of jazz music in Italy include Milan, Rome, and Sicily. Later, Italy was at the forefront of the <a href="/wiki/Progressive_rock" title="Progressive rock">progressive rock</a> and pop movement of the 1970s, with bands like <a href="/wiki/Premiata_Forneria_Marconi" title="Premiata Forneria Marconi">PFM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banco_del_Mutuo_Soccorso" title="Banco del Mutuo Soccorso">Banco del Mutuo Soccorso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Le_Orme" title="Le Orme">Le Orme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goblin_(band)" title="Goblin (band)">Goblin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pooh_(band)" title="Pooh (band)">Pooh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[467]</a></sup> The same period saw diversification in the <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Italy" title="Cinema of Italy">cinema of Italy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cinecitt%C3%A0" title="Cinecittà">Cinecittà</a> films included complex scores by composers including <a href="/wiki/Ennio_Morricone" title="Ennio Morricone">Ennio Morricone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armando_Trovaioli" class="mw-redirect" title="Armando Trovaioli">Armando Trovaioli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piero_Piccioni" title="Piero Piccioni">Piero Piccioni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Piero_Umiliani" title="Piero Umiliani">Piero Umiliani</a>. In the early 1980s, the first star to emerge from the <a href="/wiki/Italian_hip_hop" title="Italian hip hop">Italian hip hop</a> scene was singer <a href="/wiki/Jovanotti" title="Jovanotti">Jovanotti</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470">[468]</a></sup> Popular Italian metal bands such as <a href="/wiki/Rhapsody_of_Fire" title="Rhapsody of Fire">Rhapsody of Fire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lacuna_Coil" title="Lacuna Coil">Lacuna Coil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elvenking_(band)" title="Elvenking (band)">Elvenking</a>, <a href="/wiki/Forgotten_Tomb" title="Forgotten Tomb">Forgotten Tomb</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fleshgod_Apocalypse" title="Fleshgod Apocalypse">Fleshgod Apocalypse</a> are also seen as pioneers of various heavy metal subgenres.<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[469]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Giorgio_Moroder_Melt!_2015_02_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Giorgio_Moroder_Melt%21_2015_02_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Giorgio_Moroder_Melt%21_2015_02_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Giorgio_Moroder_Melt%21_2015_02_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Giorgio_Moroder_Melt%21_2015_02_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Giorgio_Moroder_Melt%21_2015_02_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Giorgio_Moroder_Melt%21_2015_02_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3703" data-file-height="2429"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Giorgio_Moroder_Melt!_2015_02_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Giorgio_Moroder" title="Giorgio Moroder">Giorgio Moroder</a>, pioneer of <a href="/wiki/Italo_disco" title="Italo disco">Italo disco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Electronic_dance_music" title="Electronic dance music">electronic dance music</a>, is known as the "Father of Disco."<sup id="cite_ref-Moroder_472-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moroder-472">[470]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy was also an important country in the development of <a href="/wiki/Disco" title="Disco">disco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic music</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Italo_disco" title="Italo disco">Italo disco</a>, known for its futuristic sound and prominent use of synthesisers and <a href="/wiki/Drum_machine" title="Drum machine">drum machines</a>, being one of the earliest electronic dance genres, as well as European forms of disco aside from <a href="/wiki/Euro_disco" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro disco">Euro disco</a> (which later went on to influence several genres such as <a href="/wiki/Eurodance" title="Eurodance">Eurodance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nu-disco" title="Nu-disco">Nu-disco</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473">[471]</a></sup> By circa 1988, the genre had merged into other forms of European dance and electronic music, such as <a href="/wiki/Italo_house" title="Italo house">Italo house</a>, which blended elements of Italo disco with traditional house music; its sound was generally uplifting, and made strong usage of piano melodies. Some bands of this genre are <a href="/wiki/Black_Box_(band)" title="Black Box (band)">Black Box</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Side_Beat" title="East Side Beat">East Side Beat</a>, and <a href="/wiki/49ers_(band)" class="mw-redirect" title="49ers (band)">49ers</a>. By the latter half of the 1990s, a subgenre of Eurodance known as <a href="/wiki/Italo_dance" class="mw-redirect" title="Italo dance">Italo dance</a> emerged. Taking influences from Italo disco and Italo house, Italo dance generally included synthesizer riffs, a melodic sound, and the usage of vocoders. Notable Italian DJs and remixers include <a href="/wiki/Gabry_Ponte" title="Gabry Ponte">Gabry Ponte</a> (member of the group <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_65" title="Eiffel 65">Eiffel 65</a>), <a href="/wiki/Benny_Benassi" title="Benny Benassi">Benny Benassi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gigi_D%27Agostino" title="Gigi D'Agostino">Gigi D'Agostino</a>, and the trio <a href="/wiki/Tacabro" title="Tacabro">Tacabro</a>. </p>
      <p>Producers such as <a href="/wiki/Giorgio_Moroder" title="Giorgio Moroder">Giorgio Moroder</a>, who won three <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award">Academy Awards</a> and four <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Globe Award">Golden Globes</a> for his music, were highly influential in the development of <a href="/wiki/Electronic_dance_music" title="Electronic dance music">electronic dance music</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Moroder_472-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moroder-472">[470]</a></sup> Today, Italian pop music is represented annually with the <a href="/wiki/Sanremo_Music_Festival" title="Sanremo Music Festival">Sanremo Music Festival</a>, which served as inspiration for the <a href="/wiki/Eurovision" class="mw-redirect" title="Eurovision">Eurovision</a> song contest, and the <a href="/wiki/Festival_of_Two_Worlds" class="mw-redirect" title="Festival of Two Worlds">Festival of Two Worlds</a> in <a href="/wiki/Spoleto" title="Spoleto">Spoleto</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[472]</a></sup> Singers such as <a href="/wiki/Mina_(Italian_singer)" title="Mina (Italian singer)">Mina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Bocelli" title="Andrea Bocelli">Andrea Bocelli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grammy" class="mw-redirect" title="Grammy">Grammy</a> winner <a href="/wiki/Laura_Pausini" title="Laura Pausini">Laura Pausini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zucchero_Fornaciari" title="Zucchero Fornaciari">Zucchero</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eros_Ramazzotti" title="Eros Ramazzotti">Eros Ramazzotti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tiziano_Ferro" title="Tiziano Ferro">Tiziano Ferro</a> have attained international acclaim. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Gigliola_Cinquetti" title="Gigliola Cinquetti">Gigliola Cinquetti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toto_Cutugno" title="Toto Cutugno">Toto Cutugno</a>, and <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A5neskin" title="Måneskin">Måneskin</a> have won the <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest" title="Eurovision Song Contest">Eurovision Song Contest</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_1964" title="Eurovision Song Contest 1964">1964</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_1990" title="Eurovision Song Contest 1990">1990</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2021" title="Eurovision Song Contest 2021">2021</a> respectively. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Italy" title="Cinema of Italy">Cinema of Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The history of Italian cinema began a few months after the <a href="/wiki/Auguste_and_Louis_Lumi%C3%A8re" title="Auguste and Louis Lumière">Lumière brothers</a> began motion picture exhibitions. The first Italian film was a few seconds, showing <a href="/wiki/Pope_Leo_XIII" title="Pope Leo XIII">Pope Leo XIII</a> giving a blessing to the camera. The Italian film industry was born between 1903 and 1908 with three companies: the <a href="/wiki/Societ%C3%A0_Italiana_Cines" class="mw-redirect" title="Società Italiana Cines">Società Italiana Cines</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ambrosio_Film" title="Ambrosio Film">Ambrosio Film</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Itala_Film" title="Itala Film">Itala Film</a>. Other companies soon followed in Milan and in Naples. In a short time these first companies reached a fair producing quality, and films were soon sold outside Italy. Cinema was later used by <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a>, who founded Rome's renowned <a href="/wiki/Cinecitt%C3%A0" title="Cinecittà">Cinecittà</a> studio for the production of Fascist propaganda until World War II.<sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475">[473]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cinecitt%C3%A0_-_Entrance.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Cinecitt%C3%A0_-_Entrance.jpg/220px-Cinecitt%C3%A0_-_Entrance.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Cinecitt%C3%A0_-_Entrance.jpg/330px-Cinecitt%C3%A0_-_Entrance.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Cinecitt%C3%A0_-_Entrance.jpg/440px-Cinecitt%C3%A0_-_Entrance.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3830" data-file-height="2758"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cinecitt%C3%A0_-_Entrance.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Entrance to <a href="/wiki/Cinecitt%C3%A0" title="Cinecittà">Cinecittà</a> in Rome, the largest film studio in Europe
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the war, Italian film was widely recognised and exported until an artistic decline around the 1980s. <a href="/wiki/List_of_film_directors_from_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="List of film directors from Italy">Notable Italian film directors</a> from this period include <a href="/wiki/Vittorio_De_Sica" title="Vittorio De Sica">Vittorio De Sica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federico_Fellini" title="Federico Fellini">Federico Fellini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Leone" title="Sergio Leone">Sergio Leone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pier_Paolo_Pasolini" title="Pier Paolo Pasolini">Pier Paolo Pasolini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luchino_Visconti" title="Luchino Visconti">Luchino Visconti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michelangelo_Antonioni" title="Michelangelo Antonioni">Michelangelo Antonioni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Rossellini" title="Roberto Rossellini">Roberto Rossellini</a>; some of these are recognised among the greatest and most influential filmmakers of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[474]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[475]</a></sup> Movies include world cinema treasures such as <i><a href="/wiki/Bicycle_Thieves" title="Bicycle Thieves">Bicycle Thieves</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/La_dolce_vita" class="mw-redirect" title="La dolce vita">La dolce vita</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/8%C2%BD" title="8½">8½</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Good,_the_Bad_and_the_Ugly" title="The Good, the Bad and the Ugly">The Good, the Bad and the Ugly</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Once_Upon_a_Time_in_the_West" title="Once Upon a Time in the West">Once Upon a Time in the West</a></i>. The mid-1940s to the early 1950s was the heyday of <a href="/wiki/Italian_neorealism" title="Italian neorealism">neorealist films</a>, reflecting the poor condition of post-war Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478">[476]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">[477]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As the country grew wealthier in the 1950s, a form of neorealism known as pink neorealism succeeded, and other <a href="/wiki/Film_genre" title="Film genre">film genres</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Sword-and-sandal" title="Sword-and-sandal">sword-and-sandal</a> followed as <a href="/wiki/Spaghetti_Western" title="Spaghetti Western">Spaghetti Westerns</a>, were popular in the 1960s and 1970s. Actresses such as <a href="/wiki/Sophia_Loren" title="Sophia Loren">Sophia Loren</a>, <a href="/wiki/Giulietta_Masina" title="Giulietta Masina">Giulietta Masina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gina_Lollobrigida" title="Gina Lollobrigida">Gina Lollobrigida</a> achieved international stardom during this period. Erotic Italian thrillers, or <i><a href="/wiki/Giallo" title="Giallo">giallos</a></i>, produced by directors such as <a href="/wiki/Mario_Bava" title="Mario Bava">Mario Bava</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dario_Argento" title="Dario Argento">Dario Argento</a> in the 1970s, also influenced the horror genre worldwide. In recent years, the Italian scene has received only occasional international attention, with movies like <i><a href="/wiki/Life_Is_Beautiful" title="Life Is Beautiful">Life Is Beautiful</a></i> directed by <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Benigni" title="Roberto Benigni">Roberto Benigni</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Il_Postino:_The_Postman" title="Il Postino: The Postman">Il Postino: The Postman</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Massimo_Troisi" title="Massimo Troisi">Massimo Troisi</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Great_Beauty" title="The Great Beauty">The Great Beauty</a></i> directed by <a href="/wiki/Paolo_Sorrentino" title="Paolo Sorrentino">Paolo Sorrentino</a>. </p>
      <p>The aforementioned <a href="/wiki/Cinecitt%C3%A0" title="Cinecittà">Cinecittà</a> studio is today the largest film and television production facility in continental Europe and the centre of the Italian cinema, where many of the biggest box office hits are filmed, and one of the biggest production communities in the world. In the 1950s, the number of international productions being made there led to Rome's being dubbed "<i><a href="/wiki/Hollywood_on_the_Tiber" title="Hollywood on the Tiber">Hollywood on the Tiber</a></i>". More than 3,000 productions have been made on its lot, of which 90 received an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award">Academy Award</a> nomination and 47 of these won it, from some cinema classics to recent rewarded features (such as <i><a href="/wiki/Roman_Holiday" title="Roman Holiday">Roman Holiday</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Ben-Hur_(1959_film)" title="Ben-Hur (1959 film)">Ben-Hur</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Cleopatra_(1963_film)" title="Cleopatra (1963 film)">Cleopatra</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Romeo_and_Juliet_(1968_film)" title="Romeo and Juliet (1968 film)">Romeo and Juliet</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_English_Patient_(film)" title="The English Patient (film)">The English Patient</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Passion_of_the_Christ" title="The Passion of the Christ">The Passion of the Christ</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Gangs_of_New_York" title="Gangs of New York">Gangs of New York</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480">[478]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy is the most awarded country at the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award">Academy Awards</a> for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">Best Foreign Language Film</a>, with 14 awards won, 3 <a href="/wiki/Academy_Honorary_Award" title="Academy Honorary Award">Special Awards</a> and 31 <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_submissions_for_the_Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Italian submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">nominations</a>. As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Italy&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Italian films have also won 12 <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">Palmes d'Or</a> (the second-most of any country), 11 <a href="/wiki/Golden_Lion" title="Golden Lion">Golden Lions</a> and 7 <a href="/wiki/Golden_Bear" title="Golden Bear">Golden Bears</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Italy" title="Sport in Italy">Sport in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Italy_national_football_team_Euro_2012_final.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Italy_national_football_team_Euro_2012_final.jpg/220px-Italy_national_football_team_Euro_2012_final.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Italy_national_football_team_Euro_2012_final.jpg/330px-Italy_national_football_team_Euro_2012_final.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Italy_national_football_team_Euro_2012_final.jpg/440px-Italy_national_football_team_Euro_2012_final.jpg 2x" data-file-width="656" data-file-height="433"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Italy_national_football_team_Euro_2012_final.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">The <i>Azzurri</i></a> in 2012. Football is the most popular sport in Italy
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The most popular sport in Italy is <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481">[479]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482">[480]</a></sup> Italy's <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">national football team</a> is one of the world's most successful teams with four <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> victories (1934, 1938, 1982 and 2006).<sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483">[481]</a></sup> Italian clubs have won 48 major European trophies, making Italy the <a href="/wiki/List_of_UEFA_club_competition_winners#By_country" title="List of UEFA club competition winners">second most successful country in European football</a>. Italy's top-flight club football league is named <a href="/wiki/Serie_A" title="Serie A">Serie A</a> and is followed by millions of fans around the world. </p>
      <p>Other popular team sports in Italy include <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rugby_football" title="Rugby football">rugby</a>. Italy's <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_volleyball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Italy national volleyball team">male</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italy_women%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Italy women's national volleyball team">female</a> national volleyball teams are often <a href="/wiki/FIVB_World_Rankings" class="mw-redirect" title="FIVB World Rankings">featured among the world's best</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Italian_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian national basketball team">Italian national basketball team</a>'s best results were gold at <a href="/wiki/Eurobasket_1983" class="mw-redirect" title="Eurobasket 1983">Eurobasket 1983</a> and <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_1999" title="EuroBasket 1999">EuroBasket 1999</a>, as well as silver at the Olympics in <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics" title="Basketball at the 2004 Summer Olympics">2004</a>. <a href="/wiki/Lega_Basket_Serie_A" title="Lega Basket Serie A">Lega Basket Serie A</a> is widely considered one of the most competitive in Europe. <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">Rugby union</a> enjoys a good level of popularity, especially in the north of the country. Italy's <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_rugby_union_team" title="Italy national rugby union team">national team</a> competes in the <a href="/wiki/Six_Nations_Championship" title="Six Nations Championship">Six Nations Championship</a>, and is a regular at the <a href="/wiki/Rugby_World_Cup" title="Rugby World Cup">Rugby World Cup</a>. Italy ranks as a tier-one nation by <a href="/wiki/World_Rugby" title="World Rugby">World Rugby</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Italy_men%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Italy men's national volleyball team">men's volleyball team</a> won three consecutive <a href="/wiki/FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship">World Championships</a> (in 1990, 1994, and 1998) and earned the <a href="/wiki/Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="Olympics">Olympic</a> silver medal in 1996, 2004, and 2016. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Giro_d%27Italia_2017,_dumoulin_pozzovivo_(34766910580).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Giro_d%27Italia_2017%2C_dumoulin_pozzovivo_%2834766910580%29.jpg/220px-Giro_d%27Italia_2017%2C_dumoulin_pozzovivo_%2834766910580%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Giro_d%27Italia_2017%2C_dumoulin_pozzovivo_%2834766910580%29.jpg/330px-Giro_d%27Italia_2017%2C_dumoulin_pozzovivo_%2834766910580%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Giro_d%27Italia_2017%2C_dumoulin_pozzovivo_%2834766910580%29.jpg/440px-Giro_d%27Italia_2017%2C_dumoulin_pozzovivo_%2834766910580%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1575" data-file-height="1050"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Giro_d%27Italia_2017,_dumoulin_pozzovivo_(34766910580).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Starting in 1909, the <a href="/wiki/Giro_d%27Italia" title="Giro d'Italia">Giro d'Italia</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Tour_(cycling)" title="Grand Tour (cycling)">Grands Tours</a>' second oldest.<sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484">[482]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italy has a long and successful tradition in individual sports as well. <a href="/wiki/Bicycle_racing" class="mw-redirect" title="Bicycle racing">Bicycle racing</a> is a very familiar sport in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-485" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-485">[483]</a></sup> Italians have won the <a href="/wiki/UCI_Road_World_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_road_race" title="UCI Road World Championships – Men's road race">UCI World Championships</a> <a href="/wiki/UCI_Road_World_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_road_race#Medalists_by_nation" title="UCI Road World Championships – Men's road race">more than any other country</a>, except <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Giro_d%27Italia" title="Giro d'Italia">Giro d'Italia</a> is a cycling race held every May, and constitutes one of the three <a href="/wiki/Grand_Tour_(cycling)" title="Grand Tour (cycling)">Grand Tours</a>, along with the <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_France" title="Tour de France">Tour de France</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Vuelta_a_Espa%C3%B1a" title="Vuelta a España">Vuelta a España</a>, each of which last approximately three weeks. <a href="/wiki/Alpine_skiing" title="Alpine skiing">Alpine skiing</a> is also a very widespread sport in Italy, and the country is a popular international skiing destination, known for its ski resorts.<sup id="cite_ref-486" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-486">[484]</a></sup> Italian skiers achieved good results in <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">Winter Olympic Games</a>, <a href="/wiki/FIS_Alpine_Ski_World_Cup" title="FIS Alpine Ski World Cup">Alpine Ski World Cup</a>, and <a href="/wiki/FIS_Alpine_World_Ski_Championships" title="FIS Alpine World Ski Championships">World Championship</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2020_Formula_One_tests_Barcelona,_Ferrari_SF1000,_Leclerc.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/2020_Formula_One_tests_Barcelona%2C_Ferrari_SF1000%2C_Leclerc.jpg/220px-2020_Formula_One_tests_Barcelona%2C_Ferrari_SF1000%2C_Leclerc.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="113" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/2020_Formula_One_tests_Barcelona%2C_Ferrari_SF1000%2C_Leclerc.jpg/330px-2020_Formula_One_tests_Barcelona%2C_Ferrari_SF1000%2C_Leclerc.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/2020_Formula_One_tests_Barcelona%2C_Ferrari_SF1000%2C_Leclerc.jpg/440px-2020_Formula_One_tests_Barcelona%2C_Ferrari_SF1000%2C_Leclerc.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1025"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2020_Formula_One_tests_Barcelona,_Ferrari_SF1000,_Leclerc.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Ferrari_SF1000" title="Ferrari SF1000">Ferrari SF1000</a> by <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Ferrari" title="Scuderia Ferrari">Scuderia Ferrari</a>, the oldest surviving and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_Grand_Prix_winners_(constructors)" title="List of Formula One Grand Prix winners (constructors)">most successful</a> <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> team<sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487">[485]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">Tennis</a> has a significant following in Italy, ranking as the fourth most practised sport in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488">[486]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Open_(tennis)" title="Italian Open (tennis)">Rome Masters</a>, founded in 1930, is one of the most prestigious tennis tournaments in the world. Italian professional tennis players won the <a href="/wiki/Davis_Cup" title="Davis Cup">Davis Cup</a> in 1976 and the <a href="/wiki/Fed_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="Fed Cup">Fed Cup</a> in 2006, 2009, 2010 and 2013. <a href="/wiki/Motorsports" class="mw-redirect" title="Motorsports">Motorsports</a> are also extremely popular in Italy. Italy has won, by far, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Grand_Prix_motorcycle_racing_World_champions#By_country" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Grand Prix motorcycle racing World champions">the most MotoGP World Championships</a>. Italian <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Ferrari" title="Scuderia Ferrari">Scuderia Ferrari</a> is the oldest surviving team in <a href="/wiki/Grand_Prix_motor_racing" title="Grand Prix motor racing">Grand Prix</a> racing, having competed since 1948, and statistically the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_Grand_Prix_winners_(constructors)" title="List of Formula One Grand Prix winners (constructors)">most successful Formula One team in history</a> with a record of 232 wins. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Grand_Prix" title="Italian Grand Prix">Italian Grand Prix</a> of <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula 1</a> is the fifth oldest surviving Grand Prix, having been held since 1921. It is also one of the two Grand Prix present in every championship since the first one in <a href="/wiki/1950_Formula_One_season" title="1950 Formula One season">1950</a>. Every Formula 1 Grand Prix (except for the <a href="/wiki/1980_Italian_Grand_Prix" title="1980 Italian Grand Prix">1980</a>) has been held at <a href="/wiki/Autodromo_Nazionale_di_Monza" class="mw-redirect" title="Autodromo Nazionale di Monza">Autodromo Nazionale Monza</a>. Formula 1 was also held at <a href="/wiki/Imola_Circuit" title="Imola Circuit">Imola</a> (1980–2006, <a href="/wiki/2020_Emilia_Romagna_Grand_Prix" title="2020 Emilia Romagna Grand Prix">2020</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Mugello_Circuit" title="Mugello Circuit">Mugello</a> (<a href="/wiki/2020_Tuscan_Grand_Prix" title="2020 Tuscan Grand Prix">2020</a>) </p>
      <p>Historically, Italy has been successful in the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>, taking part from the <a href="/wiki/1896_Summer_Olympics" title="1896 Summer Olympics">first Olympiad</a> and in 47 Games out of 48. <a href="/wiki/Italy_at_the_Olympics" title="Italy at the Olympics">Italian sportsmen</a> have won 522 medals at the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a>, and another 106 at the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">Winter Olympic Games</a>, for a combined total of 628 medals with 235 golds, which makes them the <a href="/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table" title="All-time Olympic Games medal table">fifth most successful nation in Olympic history</a> for total medals. The country hosted two Winter Olympics and will host a third (in <a href="/wiki/1956_Winter_Olympics" title="1956 Winter Olympics">1956</a>, <a href="/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics" title="2006 Winter Olympics">2006</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2026_Winter_Olympics" title="2026 Winter Olympics">2026</a>), and one Summer games (in <a href="/wiki/1960_Summer_Olympics" title="1960 Summer Olympics">1960</a>). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion_and_design">Fashion and design</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Italian_fashion" title="Italian fashion">Italian fashion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_design" title="Italian design">Italian design</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Prada_milano.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Prada_milano.JPG/220px-Prada_milano.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Prada_milano.JPG/330px-Prada_milano.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Prada_milano.JPG/440px-Prada_milano.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Prada_milano.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Prada" title="Prada">Prada</a> shop in Milan
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Italian fashion has <a href="/wiki/History_of_Italian_fashion" title="History of Italian fashion">a long tradition</a>, and is regarded as one most important in the world. Milan, Florence and Rome are Italy's main <a href="/wiki/Fashion_capital" title="Fashion capital">fashion capitals</a>. According to <i>Top Global Fashion Capital Rankings</i> 2013 by <a href="/wiki/Global_Language_Monitor" title="Global Language Monitor">Global Language Monitor</a>, Rome ranked sixth worldwide when Milan was twelfth.<sup id="cite_ref-489" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489">[487]</a></sup> Major Italian fashion labels, such as <a href="/wiki/Gucci" title="Gucci">Gucci</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armani" title="Armani">Armani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prada" title="Prada">Prada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Versace" title="Versace">Versace</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valentino_SpA" class="mw-redirect" title="Valentino SpA">Valentino</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dolce_%26_Gabbana" title="Dolce &amp; Gabbana">Dolce &amp; Gabbana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Missoni" title="Missoni">Missoni</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fendi" title="Fendi">Fendi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moschino" title="Moschino">Moschino</a>, <a href="/wiki/Max_Mara" title="Max Mara">Max Mara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trussardi" title="Trussardi">Trussardi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ferragamo" class="mw-redirect" title="Ferragamo">Ferragamo</a>, to name a few, are regarded as among the finest fashion houses in the world. Jewellers like <a href="/wiki/Bvlgari" class="mw-redirect" title="Bvlgari">Bvlgari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Damiani" title="Damiani">Damiani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buccellati" title="Buccellati">Buccellati</a> have been founded in Italy. Also, the fashion magazine <a href="/wiki/Vogue_Italia" title="Vogue Italia">Vogue Italia</a>, is considered one of the most prestigious fashion magazines in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490">[488]</a></sup> The talent of young, creative fashion is also promoted, as in the ITS young fashion designer competition in Trieste.<sup id="cite_ref-491" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-491">[489]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Italy is also prominent in the field of design, notably interior design, <a href="/wiki/Architectural_design" class="mw-redirect" title="Architectural design">architectural design</a>, <a href="/wiki/Industrial_design" title="Industrial design">industrial design</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urban_design" title="Urban design">urban design</a>. The country has produced some well-known furniture designers, such as <a href="/wiki/Gio_Ponti" title="Gio Ponti">Gio Ponti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ettore_Sottsass" title="Ettore Sottsass">Ettore Sottsass</a>, and Italian phrases such as <i>"Bel Disegno"</i> and <i>"Linea Italiana"</i> have entered the vocabulary of furniture design.<sup id="cite_ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492">[490]</a></sup> Examples of classic pieces of Italian <a href="/wiki/White_goods" class="mw-redirect" title="White goods">white goods</a> and pieces of furniture include <a href="/wiki/Zanussi" title="Zanussi">Zanussi</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Washing_machine" title="Washing machine">washing machines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fridge" class="mw-redirect" title="Fridge">fridges</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Insight_Guides_2004_p._220_493-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Insight_Guides_2004_p._220-493">[491]</a></sup> the "New Tone" sofas by Atrium,<sup id="cite_ref-Insight_Guides_2004_p._220_493-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Insight_Guides_2004_p._220-493">[491]</a></sup> and the post-modern bookcase by Ettore Sottsass, inspired by <a href="/wiki/Bob_Dylan" title="Bob Dylan">Bob Dylan</a>'s song "<a href="/wiki/Stuck_Inside_of_Mobile_with_the_Memphis_Blues_Again" title="Stuck Inside of Mobile with the Memphis Blues Again">Stuck Inside of Mobile with the Memphis Blues Again</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-Insight_Guides_2004_p._220_493-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Insight_Guides_2004_p._220-493">[491]</a></sup> Today, <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">Milan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turin" title="Turin">Turin</a> are the nation's leaders in <a href="/wiki/Architectural_design" class="mw-redirect" title="Architectural design">architectural design</a> and <a href="/wiki/Industrial_design" title="Industrial design">industrial design</a>. The city of Milan hosts <a href="/wiki/Fiera_Milano" title="Fiera Milano">Fiera Milano</a>, Europe's largest design fair.<sup id="cite_ref-wiley.com_494-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wiley.com-494">[492]</a></sup> Milan also hosts major design and architecture-related events and venues, such as the "<i>Fuori Salone</i>" and the <a href="/wiki/Salone_del_Mobile" class="mw-redirect" title="Salone del Mobile">Salone del Mobile</a>, and has been home to the designers <a href="/wiki/Bruno_Munari" title="Bruno Munari">Bruno Munari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lucio_Fontana" title="Lucio Fontana">Lucio Fontana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Castellani" title="Enrico Castellani">Enrico Castellani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Piero_Manzoni" title="Piero Manzoni">Piero Manzoni</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-495" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-495">[493]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">Italian cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Italian_food.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Italian_food.JPG/220px-Italian_food.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Italian_food.JPG/330px-Italian_food.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Italian_food.JPG/440px-Italian_food.JPG 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Italian_food.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Clockwise from top left; some of the most popular Italian foods: <a href="/wiki/Pizza" title="Pizza">pizza</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pizza_Margherita" title="Pizza Margherita">Margherita</a>), <a href="/wiki/Pasta" title="Pasta">pasta</a> (<a href="/wiki/Carbonara" title="Carbonara">Carbonara</a>), <a href="/wiki/Espresso" title="Espresso">espresso</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gelato" title="Gelato">gelato</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Italian <a href="/wiki/Cuisine" title="Cuisine">cuisine</a> has developed through centuries of social and political changes, with <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Roman_cuisine" title="Ancient Roman cuisine">roots</a> as far back as the 4th century BC. Italian cuisine in itself takes heavy influences, including <a href="/wiki/Etruscan_civilization" title="Etruscan civilization">Etruscan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_cuisine" title="Ancient Greek cuisine">ancient Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Roman_cuisine" title="Ancient Roman cuisine">ancient Roman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_cuisine" title="Byzantine cuisine">Byzantine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jewish_cuisine" title="Jewish cuisine">Jewish</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-496" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-496">[494]</a></sup> Significant changes occurred with the discovery of the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a> with the introduction of items such as <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">potatoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tomato" title="Tomato">tomatoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bell_pepper" title="Bell pepper">bell peppers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a>, now central to the cuisine but not introduced in quantity until the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-497" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-497">[495]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-498" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-498">[496]</a></sup> Italian cuisine is noted for its regional diversity,<sup id="cite_ref-499" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-499">[497]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-500" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-500">[498]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-501" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-501">[499]</a></sup> abundance of difference in taste, and is known to be one of the most popular in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502">[500]</a></sup> wielding strong influence abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-503" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-503">[501]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_diet" title="Mediterranean diet">Mediterranean diet</a> forms the basis of Italian cuisine, rich in <a href="/wiki/Pasta" title="Pasta">pasta</a>, fish, fruits and vegetables and characterised by its extreme simplicity and variety, with many dishes having only four to eight ingredients.<sup id="cite_ref-504" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-504">[502]</a></sup> Italian cooks rely chiefly on the quality of the ingredients rather than on elaborate preparation.<sup id="cite_ref-505" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-505">[503]</a></sup> Dishes and recipes are often derivatives from local and familial tradition rather than created by <a href="/wiki/Chef" title="Chef">chefs</a>, so many recipes are ideally suited for <a href="/wiki/Home_cooking" class="mw-redirect" title="Home cooking">home cooking</a>, this being one of the main reasons behind the ever-increasing worldwide popularity of Italian cuisine, from America<sup id="cite_ref-506" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-506">[504]</a></sup> to Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-507" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-507">[505]</a></sup> Ingredients and dishes vary widely by <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Italy" title="Regions of Italy">region</a>. </p>
      <p>A key factor in the success of Italian cuisine is its heavy reliance on traditional products; Italy has the most <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_products_with_protected_designation_of_origin" title="List of Italian products with protected designation of origin">traditional specialities</a> protected under <a href="/wiki/Geographical_indications_and_traditional_specialities_in_the_European_Union" title="Geographical indications and traditional specialities in the European Union">EU law</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-508" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-508">[506]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_cheeses" title="List of Italian cheeses">Cheese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salumi" title="Salumi">cold cuts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_wine" title="Italian wine">wine</a> are a major part of Italian cuisine, with many regional declinations and <a href="/wiki/Protected_Designation_of_Origin" class="mw-redirect" title="Protected Designation of Origin">Protected Designation of Origin</a> or <a href="/wiki/Protected_Geographical_Indication" class="mw-redirect" title="Protected Geographical Indication">Protected Geographical Indication</a> labels, and along with <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a> (especially <a href="/wiki/Espresso" title="Espresso">espresso</a>) make up a very important part of the Italian <a href="/wiki/Gastronomic" class="mw-redirect" title="Gastronomic">gastronomic</a> culture.<sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509">[507]</a></sup> Desserts have a long tradition of merging local flavours such as <a href="/wiki/Citrus_fruits" class="mw-redirect" title="Citrus fruits">citrus fruits</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pistachio" title="Pistachio">pistachio</a> and <a href="/wiki/Almonds" class="mw-redirect" title="Almonds">almonds</a> with sweet cheeses like <a href="/wiki/Mascarpone" title="Mascarpone">mascarpone</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ricotta" title="Ricotta">ricotta</a> or exotic tastes as cocoa, vanilla and cinnamon. <a href="/wiki/Gelato" title="Gelato">Gelato</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-510" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-510">[508]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tiramis%C3%B9" class="mw-redirect" title="Tiramisù">tiramisù</a><sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511">[509]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Cassata" title="Cassata">cassata</a> are among the most famous examples of Italian desserts, cakes and patisserie. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_holidays_and_festivals">Public holidays and festivals</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Italy" title="Public holidays in Italy">Public holidays in Italy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Festival_di_Venezia_2018.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Festival_di_Venezia_2018.jpg/220px-Festival_di_Venezia_2018.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Festival_di_Venezia_2018.jpg/330px-Festival_di_Venezia_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Festival_di_Venezia_2018.jpg/440px-Festival_di_Venezia_2018.jpg 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="960"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Festival_di_Venezia_2018.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Venice_Film_Festival" title="Venice Film Festival">Venice Film Festival</a> is the oldest film festival in the world and one of the "<a href="/wiki/Film_festival#Notable_festivals" title="Film festival">Big Three</a>" alongside <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Berlin_International_Film_Festival" title="Berlin International Film Festival">Berlin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-VeniceFilmFest_512-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VeniceFilmFest-512">[510]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-513" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-513">[511]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Public holidays celebrated in Italy include religious, national and regional observances.<sup id="cite_ref-514" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-514">[512]</a></sup> Italy's National Day, the <i><a href="/wiki/Festa_della_Repubblica" title="Festa della Repubblica">Festa della Repubblica</a></i> (<i>Republic Day</i>) is celebrated on 2 June each year, and commemorates the <a href="/wiki/Italian_institutional_referendum,_1946" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian institutional referendum, 1946">birth of the Italian Republic</a> in 1946. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Saint_Lucy%27s_Day#Italy" title="Saint Lucy's Day">Saint Lucy's Day</a>, which take place on 13 December, is very popular among children in some Italian regions, where she plays a role similar to Santa Claus.<sup id="cite_ref-alio_515-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alio-515">[513]</a></sup> In addition, the <a href="/wiki/Epiphany_(holiday)" title="Epiphany (holiday)">Epiphany</a> in Italy is associated with the <a href="/wiki/Italian_folklore" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian folklore">folkloristic</a> figure of the <a href="/wiki/Befana" title="Befana">Befana</a>, a broomstick-riding old woman who, in the night between 5 and 6 January, bringing good children gifts and sweets, and bad ones charcoal or bags of ashes.<sup id="cite_ref-516" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-516">[514]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Assumption_of_Mary" title="Assumption of Mary">Assumption of Mary</a> coincides with <i><a href="/wiki/Ferragosto" title="Ferragosto">Ferragosto</a></i> on 15 August, the summer vacation period which may be a long weekend or most of the month.<sup id="cite_ref-517" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-517">[515]</a></sup> Each city or town also celebrates a public holiday on the occasion of the festival of the local patron saint, for example: Rome on 29 June (<a href="/wiki/Feast_of_Saints_Peter_and_Paul" title="Feast of Saints Peter and Paul">Saints Peter and Paul</a>) and Milan on 7 December (<a href="/wiki/Ambrose" title="Ambrose">Saint Ambrose</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-518" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-518">[516]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are many festivals and festivities in Italy. Some of them include the <a href="/wiki/Palio_di_Siena" title="Palio di Siena">Palio di Siena</a> horse race, <a href="/wiki/Holy_Week#Italy" title="Holy Week">Holy Week</a> rites, <a href="/wiki/Saracen_Joust" title="Saracen Joust">Saracen Joust</a> of Arezzo, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Ubaldo_Day" title="Saint Ubaldo Day">Saint Ubaldo Day</a> in Gubbio, <a href="/wiki/Giostra_della_Quintana" title="Giostra della Quintana">Giostra della Quintana</a> in Foligno, and the <a href="/wiki/Calcio_Fiorentino" title="Calcio Fiorentino">Calcio Fiorentino</a>. In 2013, <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> has included among the <a href="/wiki/Intangible_cultural_heritage" title="Intangible cultural heritage">intangible cultural heritage</a> some Italian festivals and <a href="/wiki/Paso_(float)" title="Paso (float)">pasos</a> (in Italian "macchine a spalla"), such as the <a href="/wiki/Varia_di_Palmi" title="Varia di Palmi">Varia di Palmi</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Macchina_di_Santa_Rosa" title="Macchina di Santa Rosa">Macchina di Santa Rosa</a> in <a href="/wiki/Viterbo" title="Viterbo">Viterbo</a>, the Festa dei Gigli in <a href="/wiki/Nola" title="Nola">Nola</a>, and <i>faradda di li candareri</i> in <a href="/wiki/Sassari" title="Sassari">Sassari</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-519" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-519">[517]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other festivals include the <a href="/wiki/Carnival_in_Italy" title="Carnival in Italy">carnivals</a> in <a href="/wiki/Carnival_of_Venice" title="Carnival of Venice">Venice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carnival_of_Viareggio" title="Carnival of Viareggio">Viareggio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carnival_of_Satriano_di_Lucania" title="Carnival of Satriano di Lucania">Satriano di Lucania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mamoiada" title="Mamoiada">Mamoiada</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ivrea" title="Ivrea">Ivrea</a>, mostly known for its <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Oranges" title="Battle of the Oranges">Battle of the Oranges</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Venice_International_Film_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Venice International Film Festival">Venice International Film Festival</a>, awarding the "<a href="/wiki/Golden_Lion" title="Golden Lion">Golden Lion</a>" and held annually since 1932, is the oldest film festival in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-VeniceFilmFest_512-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VeniceFilmFest-512">[510]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style>
      <div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha"> 
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734">
      <div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width" style="column-width: 30em;"> 
       <ol class="references"> 
        <li id="cite_note-171"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-171">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Official French maps show the border detouring south of the main summit, and claim the highest point in Italy is Mont Blanc de Courmayeur (4,748&nbsp;m or 15,577&nbsp;ft), but these are inconsistent with an 1861 convention and topographic watershed analysis.</span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-350"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-350">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to Mitrica, an October 2005 Romanian report estimates that 1,061,400 Romanians are living in Italy, constituting 37% of 2.8&nbsp;million immigrants in that country<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[348]</a></sup> but it is unclear how the estimate was made, and therefore whether it should be taken seriously.</span> </li> 
       </ol>
      </div>

</li> 
        <li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/table.do?tab=table&amp;init=1&amp;language=en&amp;pcode=tessi190&amp;plugin=1">"Gini coefficient of equivalised disposable income – EU-SILC survey"</a>. <i>ec.europa.eu</i>. <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.
